text: Setup: Beech chair type position at 45 degrees (venous drainage) or supine. Sandbag behind shoulders, head turned away.

Landmarks: C2 Lower border mandible, C3 Hyoid, C4/5 Thyroid cartilage, C6 Cricoid cartilage (only complete tracheal ring), Carotid tubercle (tubercle on ant. aspect of C6 TP), SCM Mastoid process to sternum, Carotid Art. Posterolateral under SCM.
Internervous Plane: Superficial - Platysma (facial nerve supply is proximal so no dennervation). Deeper - Between SCM (Spinal Accessory) & Strap muscles (C1,2,3 segmental nerves).

Approach: Inject adrenaline first. Left sided approach preferred – R Recurrent Laryngeal more vulnerable. Transverse/oblique incision from SCM medial border to midline. Incise epimycium over platysma and divide platysma longitudinally. Identify then divide deep cervical fascia along SCM medial edge. Exposes SCM & Strap muscles (sternohyoid & sternothyroid). Allows SCM to be retracted laterally & straps medially.

Fascia layers encountered and incised: Deep Cervical Fascia (Deep to platysma, surrounds whole neck and encase SCM & Trapezius, incised on medial border SCM to allow retraction laterally), Pre-Tracheal Fascia (Attaches to lateral border carotid sheath, covers sheath & strap muscles which cover T&O, incise on medial border carotid sheath to allow retraction), Pre-vertebral fascia (Covers longus coli muscles, sympathetic chain lies superficial to fascia & in line with TPs, incise in midline to avoid damage to sympathetic chain).
Nerves at Risk: Recurrent Laryngeal nerves - Left leaves vagus and arches round aortic arch – ascends between T&O. Right leaves vagus, arches round subclavian – ascends between T&O.
Right recurrent laryngeal: Ascends to a higher level. Branches from vagus (leaves carotid sheath) at a higher level. May cross towards the midline.
Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Accompanies the superior thyroid artery by piercing pre-tracheal fascia. Even if artery divided nerve must be preserved.
Spinal Accessory (SCM) & Facial nerve (Platysma) shouldn’t be in field. Nerves to longus coli & strap muscles: Segmental & not at risk.

Sympathetic chain: Lie on pre-vertebral fascia anterior to longus coli. In line with TPs. Upper – C3; Middle C6; Inferior (stellate) C8/T1. Protected by midline incision & retraction under longus coli.
Carotid Sheath: Contains: 1. Common carotid artery (divides into internal & external at C4) 2. Vagus nerve 3. Internal jugular vein. Carotid artery is medial to Internal jugular vein.
Superior & Inferior Thyroid arteries: Leave carotid sheath and pierce pre-tracheal fascia. May limit exposure above C3/4 – ligate.
Vertebral Artery: Within foramen transversarium lateral to TPs. Very vulnerable if dissection strays of bone laterally.
Oesophagus: Fragile therefore avoid overzealous retraction. All structures are protected by retractor placement beneath longus coli.

Palmar interossei are unipennate and arise from the volar aspect of the 2nd, 4th, and 5th metacarpals. They insert onto the dorsal extensor expansions. The index finger's palmar interossei do not arise from the long finger metacarpal, and they allow for adduction towards the third metacarpal.
All interossei exert a flexion force at the metacarpophalangeal joint (MCPJ) and an extension force at the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIPJ).

Adductor Pollicis is the deepest muscle in the palm, situated with the interossei. It is bipennate, with oblique and transverse heads that arise from the 2nd and 3rd metacarpals to attach to the proximal phalanx and the ulnar sesamoid of the thumb.

The hand is divided into 10 compartments: 4 dorsal interossei, 3 palmar interossei, Adductor Pollicis, Thenar muscles, and Hypothenar Muscles. The fingers lack intrinsic muscles, but Cleland's and Grayson's ligaments can cause neurovascular compromise if swollen.
The carpal tunnel is not a distinct compartment but a potential space for edema. It is routinely decompressed.

Decompression techniques involve dorsal incisions over the 2nd and 4th metacarpals to decompress all interossei and Adductor Pollicis. Thenar and hypothenar incisions are also used, along with mid-axial incisions centered at the PIPJ for severely swollen fingers. These incisions are safe as they are dorsal to the neurovascular bundle (NVB).

During decompression, the flexor sheath is incised volumetrically and longitudinally, releasing the A1 pulley while preserving A2 and A4. Graysons ligament is incised, and the bone is exposed between the flexor sheath and the NVB.

Extensor tendons are vascular and possess a paratenon, receiving blood supply from afferent arterioles. They are covered by a synovial sheath only at the extensor retinaculum, making them largely extrasynovial.

The long extensors include ECRL, ECRB, EDC, ECU, EIP, EDM, EPL, EPB, and APL, all of which pass under the extensor retinaculum. ECRL is innervated by the radial nerve, while the others are innervated by the Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN). ECRL is the second muscle innervated at the elbow after the Brachioradialis (BR).

ECRL, ECRB, and EDC originate from the lateral epicondyle, while others arise from the proximal ulna or interosseous membrane (IOM). ECRL inserts at the base of the 2nd metacarpal, ECRB at the base of the 3rd metacarpal (most central), and ECU at the base of the 5th metacarpal. EIP, EDC, EPB, and EDM form the extensor apparatus of the fingers and thumb. In the index finger, EIP is always ulnar to the EDC tendon.

There are six extensor compartments at the wrist, with the first five being fibro-osseous and the sixth being fibrous. These compartments house the tendons: 1st: APL, EPV (De Quervains); 2nd: ECRL, ECRB (Intersection syndrome); 3rd: EPL (lies over Lister's tubercle); 4th: EDC, EIP, PIN; 5th: EDM (lies over DRUJ); 6th: ECU.

The extensor mechanism is composed of contributions from the long extensors and the seven interossei and four lumbricals. The intrinsics are volar to the MCPJ and dorsal to the IPJs, causing flexion at the MCPJ and extension at the IPJ. The extrinsics extend all joints.

Sagittal bands arise from the volar plate and insert onto the extrinsic EDC at the MCPJ level, stabilizing the extensor tendon. Disruption leads to subluxation, with the radial sagittal band more commonly disrupted, causing ulnar subluxation.
The extensor hood is formed by the merging of intrinsic and extrinsic tendons over the MCPJ and proximal phalanx (P1). The intrinsics, being volar to the MCPJ, cause flexion.

The extensor tendon trifurcates at the distal proximal phalanx (P1) into a central slip and two lateral bands. The central slip attaches to P2 and extends the PIPJ, while the lateral bands attach to P3 to extend the DIPJ.
Lateral bands arise from the extrinsic tendon trifurcation and are conjoined, receiving contributions from the intrinsics, forming a continuation of the intrinsic contribution to the extensor hood.
The transverse ligament runs between the volar plate of the PIPJ and the lateral bands, preventing dorsal subluxation of the lateral bands.
The triangular ligament lies dorsal to the lateral bands over the P2, preventing volar subluxation of the lateral bands by holding them together. Rupture can lead to a boutonniere deformity.

The oblique retinacular ligament arises from the volar plate of the PIPJ with the transverse ligament and runs obliquely to attach to the terminal extensor tendon at the DIPJ. It links and coordinates PIPJ and DIPJ extension. In mallet fractures, the ORL contributes to extension, and it becomes contracted in chronic boutonniere deformity.

The flexor tendons are long, extrinsic tendons, with FDP, FDS, FPL, FCR, PL, and FCU being the main ones. The little finger FDS is absent in 20% of people. The long and little finger FDP tendons share a common muscle belly, while the index finger FDP has its own belly. Testing FDS involves flexing the PIPJ with other fingers extended, and for isolated index finger FDS testing, a pincer grip with hyperextended index DIPJ is used.

Flexor tendons are primarily intrasynovial, with the index, middle, and ring fingers entering the synovial sheath at the metacarpal neck. The thumb and little finger have a synovial sheath throughout the palm. Nutrition occurs via longitudinal vessels (vincula system) and passive diffusion from synovial fluid, which relies on motion.

The FDS is volar to the FDP in the forearm and palm, splitting to go around the FDP tendon for insertion at P2, occurring at the Chiasma of Camper over P1. Both FDS and FDP receive blood supply via the vinculum longus and brevis.

There are four lumbricals that arise from the radial aspect of the FDS proximal to the MCPJ. They pass dorsally and insert into the extensor mechanism at the radial aspect of the distal PIPJ, contributing to the extensor hood and lateral bands. Lumbricals cause MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension.

The pulley system consists of annular pulleys (A1-5, with A2 and A4 being most important) and cruciate pulleys (C1-3). These pulleys prevent tendon bowstringing and maintain proximity to the joint's center of rotation, maximizing power. The flexor retinaculum also acts as a pulley.

The thumb has two annular and one oblique pulley. The oblique pulley is crucial for stability and runs from the proximal phalanx's ulnar to distal radial aspect. A1 and A2 annular pulleys arise from the volar plates of the MCP and IP joints.

topic: Surgical Approaches to the Hand & Wrist
text: The dorsal approach to the wrist involves a longitudinal incision centered on Lister's tubercle. The inter-nervous plane is absent as all structures are tendinous and supplied proximally. Dissection involves sharp incision of the extensor retinaculum, retraction of EPL, and elevation of extensor compartments. The whole radius can be exposed, and closure involves repairing the extensor retinaculum.

topic: Surgical Approaches to the Hand & Wrist
text: Dangers of the dorsal approach include potential injury to the radial artery and superficial radial nerve if straying too radially. Anatomical points include the fibro-osseous compartments created by septa between the bone and extensor retinaculum, and the fact that EPL wraps around Lister's at 45 degrees.

topic: Volar Approach to median nerve (carpal tunnel)
text: The incision for the carpal tunnel approach is a line from the 3rd web space to the ulnar edge of the Palmaris longus (PL), not extending beyond Kaplan's line. There is no inter-nervous plane as no muscles are encountered. Dissection involves careful incision of the superficial fascia to the Transverse Carpal Ligament (TCL).

topic: Volar Approach to median nerve (carpal tunnel)
text: During dissection, fibers of the Abductor Pollicis Brevis (APB) may be encountered and can be safely incised. The abherent palmar cutaneous nerve should be avoided. The TCL is incised under stretch with a self-retainer, staying ulnar to the median nerve to protect the abherent palmar cutaneous nerve.

topic: Volar Approach to median nerve (carpal tunnel)
text: Dangers of the carpal tunnel approach include the palmar cutaneous branch, for which ulnar stay during superficial dissection is recommended. The lateral terminal branch and motor branch also require ulnar management to minimize risk. The superficial palmar arch is at the level of the first web space and is safe if the TCL is released under direct vision.

topic: Volar Approach to Ulna Nerve (Guyon’s Canal)
text: The incision for Guyon's canal follows the radial border of the hypothenar eminence, curved over the wrist crease at 60 degrees, and then proximally over the FCU tendon. The proximal extension is between the FCU (ulnar nerve) and FDS (median nerve). Dissection involves incising the FCU sheath and retracting it, followed by careful incision of the superficial fascia (volar carpal ligament), which forms the roof of Guyon's canal, to reveal the ulnar nerve and artery.

topic: Volar Approach to Ulna Nerve (Guyon’s Canal)
text: Dangers in approaching Guyon's canal include the ulnar nerve, artery, and terminal branches, which are protected by careful dissection. Extension distally involves Brunner's zig-zag.

topic: Volar Approach to the Flexor Tendons
text: Incisions for the flexor tendons can be Brunner's zig-zag, angled between joint creases (ideally 90 degrees), or longitudinal with 60-degree Z-plasties to minimize flap necrosis. There is no inter-nervous plane. Dissection involves raising thick, vascularized flaps and longitudinally incising the sheath to expose tendons, releasing A1 but preserving A2 and A4.

topic: Volar Approach to the Flexor Tendons
text: Exposure of the NV bundles requires blunt longitudinal scissor dissection and incision of Graysons ligament. Bone is exposed between the flexor sheath and the NV bundle. Dangers include the NV bundle, especially if dissection strays from the midline or dorsally. Care must be taken not to incise the A2 and A4 pulleys over P1 and P2, as this can lead to skin flap necrosis.

This approach is useful for exploring the NV bundle, flexor tendons, or bone. The incision is made between the dorsal corner of joint creases, in the demarcation between glabrous and non-glabrous skin. Sharp dissection proceeds to the flexor sheath, which is then incised and opened between the pulleys, allowing extension across to the other side of the flexor sheath.

The patient is positioned supine with the wrist extended over a crepe bandage. An Allen's test is performed to confirm ulnar artery patency. There is no inter-nervous plane as FCR is retracted, and APB fiber reflection is minimal. The incision is made between the scaphoid tubercle and in line with FCR, resulting in a radial curve.

Dissection involves incising the FCR sheath and retracting it medially. Distally, the FCR is covered by the TCL, which must be incised. The superficial palmar branch of the radial artery is retracted or ligated if it crosses. Distally, APB fibers are reflected off the capsule. Capsulotomy, including over the scaphotrapezial joint, is performed. Closure involves repairing the volar carpal ligaments and capsule.

This approach is indicated for proximal pole fractures. The wrist is positioned in flexion over a kidney dish. The incision is made radially to Lister's tubercle distally for 3-4 cm, with the posterior edge of the mobile wad skirted. The 3rd extensor compartment (EPL) is opened, and the EPL, ECRB, and ECRL are retracted radially, with the 4th compartment retracted ulnarly. A T-shaped capsulotomy is made at the distal edge of the radius, avoiding stripping the capsule of the distal scaphoid. Maximally flexing the wrist helps deliver the proximal pole.

This approach involves using the snuffbox with the wrist deviated to the ulna to deliver the scaphoid. It offers a similar angle for wire placement but carries a greater danger to the radial artery and superficial radial nerve.

This approach is useful for trapeziectomy and thumb base fractures. The incision is straight and distal to the radial styloid in the skin demarcation, just volar and radial to the APL tendon. Dissection involves retracting the APL dorsally and identifying and protecting the branches of the superficial radial nerve (SRN).

topic: Drainage of Pus in the Hand
text: Paronychia involves a longitudinal incision proximal to the nail corner, elevating the flap, and incising or excising part of the nail plate if needed. Felon (pulp space infection) requires a mid-lateral incision distal to the DIPJ, staying dorsal to the NVB. Web space infections are approached volarly.

Infections of the tendon sheath may require two incisions: a transverse incision over the A1 pulley with longitudinal blunt dissection and pulley incision, or a mid-lateral incision over the distal P2, staying dorsal to the NVB, followed by incision of the flexor sheath for irrigation.

Deep palmar space infections are serious and can lead to poor outcomes if missed. They involve the central compartment of the palm, bordered by the thenar, hypothenar, carpal tunnel, and flexor sheaths. Drainage can be achieved through various mid-palmar incisions. Dangers include digital nerves and the motor branch of the median nerve.

These infections actually refer to flexor sheath infections of the little finger or thumb. The synovial sheath of the thumb and little finger is continuous with the carpal tunnel. Incisions are made mid-laterally in the finger/thumb over P1/P2, opening the flexor sheath and passing a probe distally to assess proximal extension towards the carpal tunnel.

Biomechanics involves the study of forces acting on the body. Newton's three laws of motion are fundamental: Inertia (a body remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a force), Acceleration (force equals mass times acceleration), and Reaction (every action has an equal and opposite reaction).

Force is a mechanical load with direction, which can be plotted on x, y, and z-axes. The Pythagorean theorem helps calculate an unknown force if two other forces are known. A vector introduces the concept of direction, and a force vector represents the direction of a force.

Moment is the effect of a force at a distance, causing rotation or angular movement. Torque is the magnitude of a moment. Couples are pairs of forces creating the same moment, such as opening a bottle cap with two fingers.

The body functions as a system of levers with three classes, determined by the position of the force, fulcrum, and load. First-class levers have the fulcrum in the middle (e.g., atlanto-axial joint, scissors). Second-class levers have the load in the middle (e.g., nutcracker), requiring less force to overcome the load. Third-class levers, the most common in the body, have the force in the middle and require more force to overcome the load (e.g., shovel, forearm).

Free body diagrams are used to analyze static forces and moments acting on a joint. In static analysis, all variables must be zero. Six variables are present: force in x, y, and z axes, and the moments created in these axes. Seven assumptions are made for free body analysis: frictionless joints, only compressive forces, equal internal forces, no antagonistic muscle action, rigid bones, muscle force in the direction of the belly, and concentrated body weight.

Kinematics is the study of motion (acceleration, velocity, displacement) without considering the forces causing it. Work is defined as force multiplied by the degree of displacement. Energy is a measure of work, is never created or destroyed, and is transferred between types and bodies, with the sum total always remaining constant.

Potential energy is stored energy, while kinetic energy is the energy required to stop a moving body (E=1/2MV²). Power is work done per unit time, and momentum is a body's mass multiplied by its velocity. Speed is the measure of distance traveled over time without direction.

In a normal knee, the medial femoral condyle (MFC) is larger and more distal, while the medial tibial plateau is lower and more concave. The lateral tibial plateau is higher and convex. The lower limb mechanical axis passes just medial to the lateral tibial spine, with the normal tibial plateau having a 3-degree varus to the mechanical axis. TKR cuts are perpendicular to prevent uneven loading.

The mechanical axis of the knee is slightly anterior to the midpoint of the plateau, balanced by the posterior capsule and ligaments. The tibial slope is normally 7 degrees posterior, with the lateral plateau having a slightly greater slope. The flexion-extension axis corresponds to the transepicondylar line. Femoral rollback occurs during flexion, increasing the lever arm for the quadriceps.

Differential femoral rollback results in a polycentric instant center of rotation. The lateral femoral condyle (LFC) externally rotates during flexion (relative tibial internal rotation) and internally rotates during extension (relative tibial external rotation). The knee screws home and locks in full extension, a stable position where the cruciates are also taught.

The popliteus muscle arises from the posteromedial tibia and acts to unlock the knee from extension by causing femoral external rotation and tibial internal rotation. The patella functions as a pulley to increase the quadriceps lever arm; patellectomy reduces quadriceps power by 20%.

The Q angle, formed by the quadriceps and patellar tendon lines, is normally 5-20 degrees and tends to be higher in women. Increased Q angle can result from conditions like genu varum, genu valgum, or lateralization of the tibial tuberosity, leading to lateral patellar pull and potential instability. Patellofemoral arthrosis can be caused by increased Q angle, shallow trochlea, or deficient medial patella facet.

Normal patellofemoral motion involves the patella engaging the trochlea at 20 degrees flexion and conforming to the groove in deep flexion. The patella is most prone to instability in extension. Contact pressures are highest on the patella, with the thickest cartilage (1 cm) at the patellofemoral joint.

Restraints to abnormal knee motion include static restraints like the ACL (anteromedial bundle tight in flexion, posterolateral in extension) and PCL (anterolateral tight in flexion, posteromedial in extension), as well as collaterals and the ITB. Dynamic restraints include the quadriceps. Varus is primarily resisted by the LCL and posterolateral corner, while valgus is resisted by the MCL and posteromedial corner.

Knee arthroplasty aims for conformational matching between the femur and tibia to minimize wear and ensure stability. Fully constrained knees move in one plane, reducing wear but increasing stress at the implant-bone interface. Fully unconstrained designs allow greater motion but can lead to edge loading and wear. Failure modes include loosening, instability, maltracking, overstuffing, poor fixation, and infection.

Goals of Total Knee Replacement (TKR) include reducing pain, improving function, maintaining ROM, and avoiding complications through biomechanical principles like restoring the mechanical axis, preserving joint line, creating equal flexion/extension gaps, balancing ligaments, and ensuring durable component fixation.

Design variables in TKR include component conformity (trade-off between wear, ROM, and loosening), fixation method (cemented or uncemented), femoral radius of curvature, polyethylene properties (type, thickness), and level of constraint (PCL retaining vs. sacrificing). Polyethylene thickness is crucial, with an 8mm minimum and 10mm preferred to avoid increased wear.

The tibia is cut perpendicular to the mechanical axis to prevent uneven loading of bearing surfaces. To achieve a rectangular flexion gap, the AP femoral cuts are made with 3 degrees greater external rotation than the epicondylar axis. The distal femoral cut (valgus cut angle) creates a rectangular extension gap, typically set at 5-7 degrees valgus.

Femoral rotation is critical for creating a rectangular flexion gap and proper patella tracking. The epicondylar axis is a reliable landmark, and Whitesides line (deepest femoral sulcus to deepest trochlea) is perpendicular to the femoral axis of rotation. Posterior condyles are parallel to the rotation axis.

Ligament releases for varus deformity are performed from the tibia (osteophytes, deep MCL, PMC & semimembranosus, sup MCL, PCL) and femur (osteophytes, lateral capsule, ITB, popliteus, LCL, lateral head gastrocnemius). For fixed flexion, osteophytes are addressed, the distal femoral cut is increased, and PCL recession may be performed.

The PCL prevents flexion instability by opposing excessive posterior tibial translation. It also permits physiologic femoral rollback, preventing impingement and allowing greater flexion. PCL retaining designs offer advantages in maintaining normal kinematics and femoral rollback.

Patellofemoral joint management is mandatory in TKR for inflammatory arthritis, as the PCL is affected by the disease process, potentially leading to greater instability due to soft tissue factors. Implant types include dome (most common, eliminates rotational issues), anatomic (better conformity but less positioning tolerance), and mobile bearing (allows conformity and reduces stress but has issues with poly spin out).

Alterations in the Q angle or malrotation of components can cause patellofemoral maltracking and impingement pain. These issues can be minimized by lateralizing the patella button or femoral component. Patella baja, caused by elevated joint line or excessive distal femoral resection, can lead to patellar tendon shortening and impingement.

Technical reasons for TKR failure include polyethylene thickness (too thin leads to increased contact pressures and wear), poor conformity (leading to early wear), backside wear of poly (between poly and base plate), and manufacturing issues of poly. Loosening is caused by increased stress on the bone cement or cement-bone interface, especially in highly constrained designs. Instability can result from poor balancing or malrotation.

In a single leg stance, the ground reaction force (GRF) is influenced by the abductor force and body weight. The abductor force counteracts body weight to maintain pelvic elevation and normal gait. In osteoarthritis, the loss of frictionless cartilage increases the abductor force and joint reaction force (JRF), leading to pain.

Increasing the abductor force or moment arm (e.g., carrying a suitcase, lateralizing the greater trochanter, using a high offset stem) increases JRF and pain. Reducing body weight (losing weight, Trendelenberg gait, using a stick) or medializing the cup (small head size, thin polyethylene) can reduce JRF.

Charnley's principles focused on minimizing JRF and friction. Modern acetabular cup implantation aims for the subchondral plate without excessive medialization, with smaller heads used to medialize the center of rotation. Cups have grooves and flanges to increase surface area and cement contact, avoiding deep grooves that compromise polyethylene thickness.

Femoral component offset is advantageous as it increases the abductor lever arm. However, increasing neck length instead of prosthetic design can transfer stress to the implant tip and medial cement mantle, potentially leading to failure. Fixation methods include uncemented, cemented (composite beam), and cemented with uncemented implant interface (taper slip stem). Uncemented and composite beam designs have similar mechanical stresses at the cement-bone interface.

Bearing surfaces for older patients typically use metal on plastic, with well-produced and sterilized polyethylene. For younger patients, other options might be considered. Taper slip stems have different properties at the cement-bone interface, with low shear, minimal tensile stress, and high compressive stress due to cement's viscoelastic properties.

The trochlea-capitellar axis is 6 degrees off a line perpendicular to the humerus, resulting in a valgus carrying angle of the forearm (mean 7 degrees in men, 13 degrees in women, disappearing with flexion). The radiohumeral joint is poorly congruent, while the ulnohumeral joint is highly congruent. The capitellum's smaller radius than the radial head allows rotation in any flexion position, stabilized by the annular ligament.

Elbows have short lever arms for forces, making them inefficient and predisposed to arthritis due to high ulnohumeral joint reaction forces. In a free body diagram, extension moment equals flexion moment, and JRF can be calculated. Forces in extension include hand load, forearm weight, and JRF. Flexion involves the pull of elbow flexors.

The primary static stabilizer of the elbow is the anterior band of the MCL, particularly important for valgus stability and distraction. The radial head is the main secondary stabilizer for valgus, becoming primary if the MCL is damaged. The ulnohumeral articulation is highly congruent, providing stability in full extension, while the coronoid process is a key stabilizer against posterior ulna translation.

Elbow replacements can be linked or unlinked. Unlinked designs rely on collateral ligaments and articular congruity, which are technically challenging to balance. Linked replacements act as 'sloppy hinges' with 6 degrees of freedom, allowing 7-10 degrees of varus-valgus laxity, which reduces bone implant stress and prevents premature loosening or fracture.

The humerus has a neck-shaft angle of 130 degrees and 30 degrees retroversion. The humeral head is eccentric, positioned 9mm posterior to the shaft's central axis. The glenoid is tilted 5 degrees superiorly and retroverted 7 degrees from the scapula's plane, resulting in an overall glenoid anteversion of 25-35 degrees. The clavicle is fixed to the scapula by coracoclavicular ligaments, and ACJ/CC ligament disruption can lead to scapulothoracic instability.

Glenohumeral motion is primarily responsible for the initial 30 degrees of abduction and 60 degrees of flexion/extension. The rotator cuff stabilizes the humeral head and acts as a fulcrum for the deltoid. Scapulothoracic motion involves inferior translation of the humeral head with shoulder movement, requiring scapular movement for glenoid articulation. Loss of this motion can lead to instability.

Glenohumeral stability is achieved through static stabilizers (labrum, articular geometry, GH ligaments, capsule, negative intra-articular pressure, surface area mismatch) and dynamic stabilizers (rotator cuff, biceps tendon, scapular rotators, deltoid, proprioception). The labrum contributes 20% of stability and deepens the glenoid concavity. The IGHL is the primary stabilizer of the abducted shoulder.

The scaphoid spans both carpal rows, creating a distal flexion and proximal extension moment with the radioscaphocapitate ligament as the fulcrum. A scaphoid waist fracture leads to a humpback deformity. SLAC wrist involves disruption of the SL ligament, causing scaphoid flexion and impingement on the radius, leading to arthrosis. SNAC wrist typically results from a fracture, causing a humpback deformity and impingement.

In the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ), the ulna is fixed, and the radius rotates. The ulna's sigmoid notch has a smaller radius of curvature than the distal radius, allowing translation and varied contact pressures. Pronation causes proximal and volar translation of the radius, while supination causes distal and dorsal translation. The TFCC is the primary static stabilizer of the DRUJ.

Principles of tendon transfer include passively mobile joints, greater functional gain than potential loss, sufficient motor power and excursion, a straight line of pull, a single motor per joint, synergistic transfer, and good hand sensibility. Typical upper limb transfers for radial nerve palsy involve PT > ECRB for wrist and thumb extension. For ulnar nerve low lesions, FDS > lateral bands aid pinch grip. For high lesions, FDP tendons are sewn together, and ECRL is used for FPL.

IP joints are single-axis hinge joints, with static stability provided by bony architecture, collateral ligaments, and the volar plate. MP joints allow 2 axes of movement (flexion/extension and abduction/adduction), with the latter occurring only if the proximal phalanx (P1) is flexed 30 degrees. CMC joints of the fingers become progressively more restricted in movement towards the ulna, with the 4th and 5th CMCJs being rigid and transmitting forces to the wrist.

The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint with 2 axes of movement, similar to finger MCPJs. Circumduction occurs due to these two axes. The trapezium and metacarpal base have differing radii of curvature, allowing thumb pronation and increased ROM but reduced stability. The volar oblique ligament is crucial for thumb CMCJ stability but is prone to attenuation/rupture.

Movement is powered by flexors, extensors, and intrinsics, with tendon excursion ranging from 30-70 mm. Wrist flexors and extensors have a 30 mm excursion. The extensor mechanism includes long extensors, intrinsics, and the extensor hood, with lateral bands controlling the distal phalanx and the central slip controlling the middle phalanx.

The FDP is a mass action muscle, with the index finger FDP having some independent action. The 'Quadrigia effect' occurs when shortening or tethering of one FDP tendon causes slight flexion of the other DIPJs. The pulleys prevent tendon bowstringing and maintain tendon proximity to the joint's center of rotation, maximizing power.

Lumbricals arise from the FDP tendon and insert into the extensor hood, fine-tuning tension between flexor and extensor systems. They contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension. In intrinsic paralysis, the 'intrinsic minus' hand occurs, characterized by MCPJ hyperextension and IPJ flexion (claw hand). 'Intrinsic plus' is the opposite, with tight intrinsics causing MCPJ flexion and IPJ extension.

Spinal stability, as defined by White and Panjabi, is the ability to resist displacement under physiologic loading to protect neural structures and prevent deformity and pain. A motion segment consists of two vertebrae and intervening soft tissues, with stability conferred by passive (musculoskeletal), active (musculoskeletal), and neural subsystems.

The passive system includes vertebrae, discs, facet joints, ligaments, and joint capsules. Vertebrae increase in width and depth caudally, with internal structure featuring vertical and horizontal trabeculae. Loss of trabeculae due to osteoporosis predisposes to compression fractures. The saggital shape of the spine allows body weight to be away from the central axis of rotation, aiding balance and gait.

Facet joints determine the type of movement between vertebrae and become more vertical caudally. The cervical spine is susceptible to flexion/extension due to facet obliquity, while the lumbar spine is more resistant. The thoracic spine has added stability from the rib cage. Spinal ligaments, such as the ligamentum flavum, PLL, and ALL, provide resistance to motion and can contribute to stenosis when degenerated.

The active system comprises the spinal musculature, including extensors, abdominal muscles, intercostals, and lower trunk muscles. The neural subsystem refers to proprioception, crucial for maintaining spinal stability during movement. Spinal range of motion includes a neutral zone (high flexibility) and an elastic zone (passive system predominates).

In spinal disease or injury, the neutral zone increases, leading to a wider range of motion and potential for neurologic injury. Muscle strengthening can help minimize this increase in the neutral zone.

topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
text: Functional goals for the foot and ankle include flexibility and rigidity depending on gait phase. The joints transmit significant body weight, acting as a rigid lever arm during push-off and being supple during stance. Movements include dorsiflexion/plantarflexion (sagittal plane), varus/valgus (coronal plane, hindfoot), abduction/adduction (transverse plane, midfoot), and pronation/supination (combined movements at multiple joints).

topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
text: The ankle provides 20 degrees of dorsiflexion (DF) and 30 degrees of plantarflexion (PF), with the foot contributing to the remaining motion. Tibial rotation during gait is approximately 11 degrees. At heel strike, the ankle is in neutral or slight PF, progressing to further PF in early stance and DF during mid-stance.

topic: Biomechanics of the Foot and Ankle
text: Kinetics of the ankle show a large contact area, resulting in less arthritis compared to the hip or knee. However, the ankle is sensitive to disruption. A 1mm taller shift increases contact pressure significantly, potentially leading to early arthritis. Plantarflexors are active during stance to maintain an upright posture.

The Achilles tendon has a spiral configuration, internally rotating distally. Medial fibers insert posteriorly, and lateral fibers insert anteriorly. Lengthening procedures should be perpendicular to these fibers. The DAMP procedure involves distal anterior and proximal medial cuts.

The talus has no muscle attachments and is cradled by tendons and ligaments. The subtalar joint acts as a torque converter, translating tibial rotation into foot supination/pronation. The subtalar joint has 20 degrees of inversion and 5 degrees of eversion, with a normal axis of about 45 degrees. Flat feet have a more horizontal subtalar axis, while cavus feet have a more vertical axis.

Tarsometatarsal joint motion is restricted to less than 5 degrees of dorsiflexion and 15 degrees of plantarflexion, due to bony architecture and strong ligaments. These joints form the transverse arch of the midfoot, with the 2nd tarsometatarsal joint (Lisfranc's joint) at its center. The dorsal aspect is under compression, and the plantar aspect is under tension.

The plantar fascia originates at the calcaneus and inserts into all tarsal joints and the proximal phalanges. It acts as a truss, supporting the arches and operating via the windlass mechanism. When the MTPJs are extended, the plantar fascia tightens, locking the tarsal joints and increasing longitudinal arch height, making the foot a rigid lever for push-off.

First-generation ankle replacements (1970s) were all cemented and either constrained or unconstrained. They failed due to subsidence from cementation in soft bone and loosening at the bone-implant interface. Second-generation designs are semi-constrained with three components, allowing sliding and better conformity, and tend to be uncemented with reduced subsidence and loosening. Indications include OA and rheumatoid arthritis in low-demand elderly patients.

Gait can be assessed clinically or with a gait analysis lab. Prerequisites for normal walking include stable stance phase, adequate step distance, foot clearance during swing, energy conservation, and pre-positioning of the foot in swing. Gait smoothness is achieved by pelvic tilt, lateral displacement, and rotation, along with knee flexion and ankle/foot motion.

The gait cycle begins with foot strike and ends with the same foot striking again, comprising stance (60%) and swing (40%) phases. It is divided into eight sub-phases from heel strike to heel strike. Key definitions include step length, stride length, cadence, and double support phase.

Age-related changes to gait include a broad-based stiff knee gait at 18 months, adult gait by 7 years, with minimal changes until 70 years. After 70, velocity and step length decrease, and the double support phase increases. Females tend to have a faster cadence due to shorter stature but similar velocity.

Clinical gait analysis involves inspecting for wasting, scars, asymmetry, malalignment, and prosthetics, and observing normal movements of the pelvis, hips, knees, ankles, and feet during the gait cycle. Pelvic rotation occurs at heel strike and toe-off, with tilting during swing for clearance. Hip flexion aids clearance, and extension prevents collapse.

Abnormalities of gait include Trendelenberg gait (due to abductor weakness or short lever arm), anterior trunk bending (often from knee extension failure or weak hip extensors), posterior trunk bending (to overcome hip extension inability), and increased lumbar lordosis (compensating for hip flexion deformity).

Abnormal hip rotation can result from femoral version or muscle imbalance, leading to altered foot progression angles. Excessive knee extension is often seen in quad weakness, causing anterior bending to compensate. Excessive knee flexion can be due to fixed flexion or spastic hamstrings.

Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion causes foot slap and toe drag. Insufficient push-off occurs with gastrocnemius weakness or Achilles rupture. Wide-based gait is adopted for stability in conditions like ataxia or obesity. Pathologic gaits include steppage gait (equinus deformity), hip scissoring gait (spastic adductors), and antalgic gait (limping to reduce pain).

During gait, dorsiflexors are concentric throughout swing, while plantarflexors are inactive. Dorsiflexors are eccentric at initial contact (1st rocker), plantarflexors are eccentric at midstance (2nd rocker), and plantarflexors are concentric at pre-swing (toe-off, 3rd rocker). Glutei are inactive in swing and active throughout stance, while quads and hamstrings show eccentric activity at various phases.

The embryo develops from four germ cell layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm, and neural crest. Limb bud development follows proximodistal, craniocaudal, and dorsoventral axes, regulated by genes like Homeobox and Sonic Hedgehog. Formation of joints and ossification centers involves mesenchymal cell differentiation into chondrocytes, followed by resorption and cavitation.

Long bone primary ossification centers are present by 12 weeks, with the humerus appearing first. Secondary ossification centers begin to appear at 36 weeks, starting with the distal femur. Physeal growth involves four zones: reserve, proliferative, hypertrophic, and metaphyseal, each with distinct cell behavior and blood supply.

Articular cartilage is composed of water (75%), collagen (20% dry weight), chondrocytes (5%), and proteoglycans (10%). It forms a 3D cartilaginous framework with four layers: superficial gliding, middle transitional, deep radial, and calcified zones. Collagen fibers in the superficial zone are parallel to the surface, resisting shear, while those in the deep radial zone are perpendicular, resisting compression.

The tidemark represents the calcified boundary between the calcified and uncalcified cartilage. The calcified zone is anchored to subchondral bone by hydroxyapatite crystals. Collagen synthesis occurs in stages, involving pro-collagen and tropo-collagen. Type 2 collagen is the primary component, providing tensile strength, while type 10 collagen predominates in the calcified zone.

Proteoglycans, primarily Aggrecan, attract water and are responsible for compressive strength. Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), such as chondroitin sulfate and keratin sulfate, are proteoglycan subunits. Chondrocytes are derived from mesenchymal stem cells and produce collagen, proteoglycans, and enzymes for cartilage metabolism.

Articular cartilage is avascular, with nutrition supplied by diffusion from the synovial fluid. Loading squeezes out waste products and allows nutrient influx. Biomechanical properties include a low coefficient of friction, high shock absorption capacity, viscoelasticity, biphasicity, and anisotropy. It undergoes creep and stress relaxation under loading.

Pathological states of articular cartilage include superficial lacerations (avascular, do not heal) and deep lacerations (in the calcified zone, heal by fibrocartilage). Osteoarthritis involves two inciting mechanisms: increased degrading enzyme concentration and direct trauma, leading to collagen damage, increased water content, and reduced stiffness.

A neuron, the functional unit of nerve, consists of a cell body, axon, and dendrites. Glial cells anchor neurons and form the myelin sheath. Myelinated axons are covered by Schwann cells, enhancing saltatory conduction. Unmyelinated axons are bundled together in Remak bundles.

Nerve structure involves axons grouped into fibers, fibers into bundles, bundles into fascicles, and fascicles into a nerve trunk, all surrounded by connective tissue sheaths (endoneurium, perineurium, epineurium). The blood supply to nerves is intrinsic and extrinsic.

Nerve biomechanics are visco-elastic, making them susceptible to traction injury. They can become ischemic with 15% strain and rupture at around 20% strain. Metabolism is ATP-dependent, making nerves vulnerable to ischemia, anoxia, and hypothermia. Transport of nutrients and neurotransmitters occurs anterograde along the axon.

Peripheral nerve injuries can occur through crush, traction, laceration, or compression. Seddon's classification includes neuropraxia (conduction block with intact nerve), axonotmesis (axonal damage with intact endoneurium), and neurotmesis (complete nerve discontinuity). Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the injury zone in axonotmesis and neurotmesis.

Factors affecting nerve recovery include patient age, high-energy injury, associated vascular or bony injury, crush or traction injury, proximal injury location, nerves supplying multiple sites, and large gaps. Management principles involve electrodiagnostic studies, non-operative treatment (splinting, physiotherapy), and surgical repair or grafting.

The basic structural unit of muscle is the sarcomere, and the smallest functional unit is the myofibril. Myofibrils are composed of actin and myosin filaments, arranged in bands (A, H, I) and lines (M, Z) that contribute to contractility. Muscle fibers are grouped into fascicles, and fascicles form the whole muscle.

The muscle cell membrane comprises the sarcoplasmic reticulum and T-tubules, which relay nerve signals and facilitate calcium entry for contraction. Blood supply to muscle comes from one main artery forming vascular arcades. Muscle contraction occurs via the sliding filament mechanism, involving the interaction of actin and myosin filaments, regulated by troponin and tropomyosin.

Force generation is proportional to muscle cross-sectional diameter and velocity of contraction is related to muscle length. Power is a function of both force and velocity. Innervation involves motor neurons supplying multiple muscle fibers, with action potential size related to the number of innervated fibers. Muscle spindles provide proprioceptive feedback.

The neuromuscular junction is the synapse between a nerve terminal and muscle fiber, where acetylcholine is released to stimulate muscle contraction. Myotendinous junctions are the weakest part of a muscle unit and are prone to injury. Muscle repair involves vascularity and innervation, with healing progressing through hematoma/inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling phases.

Tendons and ligaments differ in their composition and structure. Cells in both include fibroblasts and tenocytes. The matrix is primarily collagen (90% type 1 in tendons, type 3 in proliferative phase of healing in ligaments) and proteoglycans. Elastin provides recoil, more abundant in ligaments. Tendons have a longitudinal collagen arrangement, while ligaments have layered, parallel fibers.

Tendons insert indirectly or directly, acting as springs and transmitting tensile loads. Ligaments insert directly and stabilize joints. Blood supply to tendons is via paratenon (vascular) or synovial sheath/vinculae (avascular), with avascular areas healing poorly. Ligaments receive blood supply from insertion sites.

Mechanical properties are described by stress-strain curves, featuring a toe region (uncoupling of crimped fibers), a linear region (stiffness), and plastic deformation. Dips in the curve indicate sequential fiber failure. Viscoelastic properties include creep, stress relaxation, and hysteresis. Injury can be mid-substance or at the insertion site, with insertion site disruption occurring between calcified and uncalcified fibrocartilage zones.

The medial meniscus is semi-circular and asymmetric, with a larger posterior horn and less mobility compared to the lateral meniscus. The lateral meniscus is circular, more mobile, and attached to the tibia by a coronary ligament, with a hiatus for the popliteus tendon. Both menisci are completely vascularized at birth, with a central avascular area developing in adults.

The meniscus functions in load transmission, articular conformity, lubrication, joint stability, and proprioception. Meniscal tears are classified by position (peripheral, intermediate, central) and tear pattern (vertical, horizontal, complex). Peripheral tears ('red on red') have a better chance of healing and are amenable to repair.

The intervertebral disc develops from sclerotomes and the notochord, forming the nucleus pulposus and annulus fibrosus. Discs increase in size caudally, with L4/5 being the largest. They are thicker anteriorly in the cervical and lumbar spine, contributing to lordosis. L5/S1 is the most avascular and thickest anteriorly.

The annulus fibrosus consists of an outer annulus (Type 1 collagen, lamellar, resists shear/torsion) and an inner annulus (Type 2 collagen, resists compression). The nucleus pulposus is rich in proteoglycans and provides compressive strength. The disc is a biphasic material, with hoop stresses in the annulus resisting compression.

Disc degeneration occurs with age due to dehydration and impaired nutrition, leading to decreased proteoglycan content, increased collagen content, and reduced vascularity. This results in fissures, cracks, altered mechanics, and potential facet joint arthrosis and pain. Herniation involves anular tears and nuclear bulging, with most herniations being asymptomatic.

Growth plates in long bones are either horizontal (physis, primary ossification center) or spherical (epiphysis, secondary ossification center). The physis has four zones: reserve, proliferative, hypertrophic, and metaphyseal, each with distinct cellular activity and matrix density. The hypertrophic zone is the weakest part of the growth plate and most prone to fracture.

Long bone growth is influenced by mechanical and hormonal factors. Heuter-Volkmann's law states that increased compression through the physis leads to decreased growth, and growth plate shape is determined by forces. Normal physeal growth varies by bone and age, with most growth occurring away from the elbow in the upper limb and around the knee in the lower limb.

Nerve fibers are classified as afferent (sensory) and efferent (motor), with further categorization based on myelination, diameter, and velocity (Aα, Aβ, Aδ, B, C fibers). Nerve receptors include mechanoreceptors, thermoreceptors, and nociceptors. The autonomic nervous system involves pre- and post-ganglionic neurons.

The nervous system develops from the ectoderm, with the neural tube forming the spinal cord and the neural crest forming the PNS, basal ganglia, and sympathetic chain. Organization includes the CNS, PNS, and autonomic systems, with spinal nerves dividing into dorsal (sensory) and ventral (motor) rami.

Mechanoreceptors are superficial (Meissner, Merkel) or deep (Pacinian, Ruffini), providing sensory feedback. The autonomic nervous system controls involuntary functions, with nerves originating from the spinal cord and synapsing in paravertebral ganglia.

Achondroplasia is characterized by an altered Fibroblast Growth Factor receptor 3 (FGFR3), affecting the proliferative zone and thus longitudinal growth. Intramembranous and appositional ossification, including skull bones, remain unaffected, leading to macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and limb shortening.
Spondyloepiphyseal Dysplasia and Multiple Epiphyseal Dysplasia affect the epiphysis, resulting in small, weakened epiphyses.
Trevor's Disease involves epiphyseal hyperplasia, leading to epiphyseal osteochondromas, commonly seen in the ankle and knee.

Rickets affects the hypertrophic zone, specifically the provisional zone of calcification, where there is a failure of calcification. The uncalcified matrix becomes invaded by disordered blood vessels, resulting in a widened, hazy, and thick physis, along with characteristic metaphyseal flaring (cupping) due to a lack of metaphyseal calcification.

topic: Conditions affecting various parts of the Physis & Epiphysis
text: Epiphyseal conditions include Multiple Epiphyseal Dysplasia and Trevor's disease (Epiphyseal Hyperplasia). The reserve zone can be affected by Gaucher's Disease and Pseudoachondroplasia. The proliferative zone is impacted by Achondroplasia (reduced growth) and Gigantism (increased growth). The hypertrophic zone can be affected by fractures, SUFE, mucopolysaccharidoses, and enchondromas. The provisional zone of calcification is affected in Rickets and Osteomalacia, while the metaphysis can be affected by Rickets, SUFE (renal failure related), osteomyelitis, scurvy, and osteogenesis imperfecta.

Bone serves as a primary calcium reservoir, is involved in hemopoiesis, and provides mechanical support for soft tissues and organs. Its structure includes woven (immature) and lamellar (mature) bone, with cortical bone being denser and stronger than cancellous bone. The periosteum is a vascular, osteogenic layer responsible for bone diameter growth.

Woven bone is characterized by a disorganized collagen arrangement, making it weaker but containing more cells per unit volume compared to lamellar bone. It is isotropic, meaning its properties do not vary with the type of loading, and has a high turnover rate. Examples include the embryonic and neonatal skeleton, pediatric callus, and the metaphysis up to 4 years old.

Lamellar bone, both cortical and cancellous, is stronger due to its stress-oriented collagen fibers arranged in parallel lamellae with cement lines. Cortical bone, comprising 80% of bone density, is significantly denser and stiffer than cancellous bone. It is arranged in osteons, which provide resistance to torsion and bending.

Cancellous bone, found in metaphyses and epiphyses, forms a 3D trabecular lattice with canaliculi and osteocytes similar to cortical bone. It has lower tensile strength and is more elastic, with higher turnover due to a larger surface area. It is more subject to Wolff's law for remodeling.

Bone is composed of approximately 90% matrix and 10% cellular components, including osteoblasts (secrete osteoid), osteocytes (maintain bone), bone lining cells, osteoclasts (resorb bone), and osteoprogenitor cells. Osteoblasts are formed from mesenchymal stem cells and are responsible for bone formation.

The body strives to maintain normal serum calcium, and imbalances in metabolic bone disorders reflect this effort. Calcium is primarily stored in bone as hydroxyapatite crystals. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in calcium and phosphate absorption, acting on the duodenum, bone, and parathyroid gland. PTH secretion is regulated by serum calcium and phosphate levels.

Calcitonin reduces serum calcium by inhibiting osteoclast activity. Corticosteroids can decrease serum calcium by increasing renal excretion and reducing gut absorption, potentially leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Estrogen is bone-protective, inhibiting osteoclast absorption and bone production.

Growth hormone increases gut calcium absorption and maintains bone stock. Thyroid hormones influence bone turnover, with hyperthyroidism leading to decreased bone density. Growth factors like BMPs and TGF-beta are osteoinductive, stimulating bone formation. Osteoporosis is characterized by reduced bone mass and micro-architectural deterioration, increasing fracture risk, and can be primary (Type 1: postmenopausal, Type 2: age-related) or secondary (steroids, immobilization).

Osteopetrosis is characterized by increased bone sclerosis due to deficient osteoclast activity, resulting in dense but brittle bone. It can be autosomal recessive (infantile malignant, severe) or autosomal dominant (benign, Albers-Schonberg disease). Diagnosis may reveal anemia or cranial nerve palsy, and histology shows osteoclasts lacking a ruffled border and calcified bars within trabeculae. Radiographically, there is a loss of medullary cavities and symmetric, uniform sclerosis.

Paget's disease is a metabolic bone disorder with disordered osteoclast and osteoblast activity, leading to abnormal bone. It is more common in men and increases with age. The pathophysiology involves initial osteoclast overactivity, followed by compensatory osteoblastic activity, resulting in accelerated but disorganized bone formation. Clinical presentation is often incidental, with fractures, arthritis, bone pain, and nerve compression being potential complications. Malignant transformation to osteosarcoma occurs in about 30x increased risk, particularly in long-standing polyostotic disease.

Bone formation occurs through three types: enchondral, intramembranous, and appositional. Enchondral ossification, the main type, involves replacing a cartilage model with bone, as seen in long bone growth and callus formation. Intramembranous ossification forms bone directly from undifferentiated cells in membranes, seen in flat bones. Appositional ossification contributes to bone width.

Fracture type is determined by the forces imparted, with cortical bone being stiffer and anisotropic. Bone is also visco-elastic, changing properties with loading rate. Energy transfer to bone increases with mass and velocity, with velocity being more influential. Rapid loading absorbs more energy, making bone stiffer, stronger, and more brittle, which can dissipate energy as a fracture.

Primary bone healing requires absolute stability and rigid fixation under compression, creating a low-strain environment for intramembranous ossification. Healing proceeds through contact healing, gap healing, cutting cones, and remodeling. Secondary bone healing requires relative stability and involves periosteal (bony) and endosteal (fibrocartilaginous) callus formation.

Bone grafts are used for structural support, to aid bone formation (fusion), and in non-unions. Properties include osteogenic (living cells), osteoconductive (scaffold), and osteoinductive (biologic stimulus). Classification includes autografts (from the same individual, best but limited volume), allografts (from same species, cells destroyed), xenografts (different species), and synthetic grafts.

Autografts carry risks of graft site morbidity. Allografts carry risks of infection transmission, immune reaction, and malignant cell implantation. Cancellous autografts incorporate faster than cortical due to greater cell volume. Graft incorporation involves inflammatory response, creeping substitution (osteoblast activity and osteoclast resorption), and remodeling according to Wolff's law.

Non-union is defined as the absence of clinical or radiographic healing 3 months after the expected time. Risk factors include patient factors (smoking, alcoholism, malnutrition), fracture characteristics (high energy, bone loss, pathology), and fixation issues (distraction, periosteal stripping). Classification includes hypertrophic (adequate biology, poor mechanics) and atrophic (inadequate biology) non-unions.

Diagnosis of non-union relies on clinical union (pain-free, stable fracture) and radiographic indicators like persistent fracture gaps, sclerotic bone ends, or metalware failure. Bridging callus and obliterated fracture gaps indicate union. Treatment depends on the cause, with hypertrophic non-unions managed by improving the strain environment and atrophic non-unions by debriding the site, drilling for bleeding, bone grafting, and rigid fixation.

Bone cement is composed of a liquid (monomer MMA, accelerator, inhibitor) and a powder (polymer PMMA, initiator, barium sulfate, antibiotics). Polymerization occurs upon mixing via an exothermic reaction, progressing through mixing, waiting (dough), working, hardening, and setting phases. Macroscopically, the stages are sandy, stringy, doughy, and final.

The mechanical properties of cement include weak tensile strength, moderate shear strength, and strong compressive strength. It is brittle and highly notch-sensitive, acting as a grout rather than an adhesive. Factors affecting cement properties include atmospheric conditions (temperature/humidity), mixing technique (vacuum/centrifuge reduce porosity), and implantation technique (pressurization, retention of cancellous bone, avoiding voids).

Complications of bone cement use include heat generation (causing bone necrosis if the mantle is too thick), systemic effects (hypotension thought to be due to micro-embolization), and cement fracture due to crack propagation. Commonly used cements include Palacos R (zirconium dioxide, gentamicin impregnated) and Simplex P (barium sulfate, tobramycin impregnated).

Metals used in orthopaedics have crystalline structures with defects like grain boundaries, dislocations, and cracks that affect mechanical properties. Alloys are combinations of metals with improved properties. Ductility can be reduced by adding large metal ions or small ions like carbon. Nickel and chromium increase corrosion resistance, while cobalt and molybdenum increase strength. Manufacturing processes include machining and casting, with grain size influenced by cooling rate.

Forging is a common method of shaping metal implants, aligning grain boundaries and improving properties. Cold working increases strength and brittleness through plastic deformation, while hot working yields a more ductile material. Heat treatments like annealing, quenching, and tempering alter metal properties. Surface finishes like polished, matte, grit blasted, sintered beads, plasma spray, and porous metal improve performance.

Commonly used materials include 316L Stainless Steel (strong, ductile, corrosion-resistant) and Titanium 64 (less stiff than CoCr/Steel but fatigue resistant). Cobalt Chrome (CoCr) is widely used in TKA and THR due to its wear properties and biocompatibility. Tantalum, with its high porosity, allows rapid bone ingrowth and is desirable for revision surgery.

Polyethylene, a polymer of ethylene, forms chains held by van der Waals forces. Its strength can be increased by increasing molecular weight, creating cross-links, reducing crystallinity, and optimizing manufacturing and sterilization methods. UHMWPE's strength and wear resistance are enhanced by increased chain length, number of chains, and amorphous proportion.

Cross-linking polyethylene, often via gamma irradiation, improves wear rates and tensile strength by forming cross-links between chains. However, oxidation degrades polyethylene, especially in the presence of oxygen and free radicals. Better sterilization methods include gas plasma or ethylene oxide (minimizing oxidation) or gamma irradiation in inert gas (promoting cross-links).

Highly cross-linked UHMWPE, produced by prolonged irradiation, offers even better wear resistance. However, this degree of cross-linking can reduce fatigue resistance and fracture toughness. Polyethylene in TKR can fail due to fatigue fracture, while poorly positioned THR cups are susceptible to edge loading and fatigue wear. Polyethylene manufacturing methods include RAM bar extrusion, compression molding, and direct compression molding (gold standard).

Ceramics used in orthopaedics include bioinert materials like Alumina, Zircona, and Oxinium, and bioactive materials like Hydroxyapatite (HA) and Tricalcium Phosphate. Alumina is the most common ceramic, offering better quality. Zirconia is less used due to high fracture rates. Oxinium is oxidized zirconia. Hydroxyapatite is osteoconductive and promotes bone growth.

Ceramic manufacturing involves pressing powder into a cast, followed by sintering (hot isostatic pressing) to increase density, toughness, and strength. Other processes include platelet-like crystals and transformational toughening (using zircona). Good properties of ceramics include inertness, stiffness, hardness, low surface roughness, and scratch profile. Brittleness and weakness in tension are disadvantages.

Oxidized Zirconium (Oxinium) is a metallic alloy with a ceramic surface, offering hardness, smoothness, scratch resistance, inertness, and wettability, with reduced poly wear. Ceramic fracture can generate third bodies, leading to accelerated wear and osteolysis, necessitating synovectomy to clear debris. Revision may be required for Morse taper damage.

Tribology studies friction and wear. Polyethylene's strength is influenced by molecular weight, cross-linking, crystallinity, manufacturing, and sterilization. UHMWPE's properties are based on increased chain length, number of chains, and amorphous areas, leading to strength and wear resistance. Cross-linking enhances wear resistance but can reduce fatigue resistance and fracture toughness.

Friction is the resistance to sliding between two bodies in contact, influenced by surface adherence and fluid viscosity. Three laws of friction describe the relationship between frictional force, coefficient of friction, and applied load. Frictional wear is proportional to sliding distance. Asperities, or surface projections, contribute to roughness and friction.

Joint lubrication prevents wear. Boundary lubrication involves surfaces separated by a molecularly thin lubricant, predominant in prosthetic joints. Fluid film lubrication occurs when a thicker fluid film separates surfaces, dominating in native joints and MoM articulations. Hydrodynamic lubrication relies on the generation of a fluid wedge. Elastohydrodynamic lubrication involves articular cartilage deformation.

Squeeze film lubrication occurs during non-sliding contact, building pressure to maintain a gap. Boosted lubrication involves pressurizing synovial fluid into the cartilage, creating a more viscous fluid. Weeping lubrication involves compression eluting lubricant fluid. The predominant lubrication type varies with gait cycle phase.

In prosthetic joints, boundary and some fluid film lubrication may occur. Wettability describes a material's affinity for lubricant, with ceramics being highly wettable. Large diameter articulations benefit from true fluid film lubrication if the effective radius is large and surface roughness is low.

Stress is force applied per unit area, measured in Pascals. Strain is the change in length relative to original length, a unitless measure. Material properties are subject to applied forces; isotropic materials have properties independent of force direction, while anisotropic materials vary. The stress-strain curve illustrates these relationships.

The stress-strain curve shows the toe region (uncoiling of fibers), elastic region (linear, Hooke's Law applies), proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, strain hardening, ultimate tensile strength, and fracture. Strain energy is the area under the elastic portion of the curve.

Brittle materials have little plastic behavior, with yield and fracture points close together (e.g., ceramic). Ductile materials have a large plastic region (e.g., metals). Hardness is a surface property. Fatigue failure occurs due to repetitive stress below ultimate tensile strength, represented by the S-N curve. Stiffness refers to resisting deformation, while rigidity is structural ability to resist deformation.

Cerclage wire's tensile strength is proportional to its diameter, and it is notch sensitive. Cables have higher fatigue resistance. Screws convert rotatory load to linear motion, producing compression. Pullout force increases with screw diameter, embedded length, bone quality, surface area, cortical purchase, and pitch. Cannulated screws have lower pullout strength due to reduced core diameter.

Nails are advantageous as they reside within the bone's axis and act as load-sharing devices. Metaphyseal fractures are problematic due to bending moments and lack of cortical contact around the nail. Plates are more susceptible to failure than nails due to lower bending rigidity and reliance on fracture reduction.

Locking plates form fixed-angle constructs, eliminating the weak screw-plate interface and screw pullout. Their stiffness depends on screw thickness and material. They preserve periosteal blood supply and can be inserted minimally invasively. Proper articular reduction and fixation are crucial before applying locking screws.

External fixation devices depend on the desired effect (temporary or definitive). Working length is critical, similar to nails and plates. Placing bars closer to the skin reduces working length and increases construct stiffness. Stiffness can be increased by larger pin/bar size, shorter working length, more pins, multiple planes, anatomical reduction, and underdrilling holes.

Bone is subjected to combined forces: shear, bending, torsion, compression, and tension. Strength is the ability to resist deformation, dependent on material properties and shape. Rectangular structures resist bending, while tubular structures are more vulnerable to torsion. Stiffness is a material property related to stress/strain, while rigidity is a structural property.

Types of data include continuous (numeric, quantitative, e.g., age) and categorical (nominal, ordinal, qualitative, e.g., race). Parametric data typically follow a normal Gaussian distribution, where mean, median, and mode are similar. Non-parametric data are often skewed, with median or mode used to assess central tendency.

Measures of spread/variability include interquartile range (describes deviation from the mean in 25% quartiles) and standard deviation (describes deviation of individual values from the mean, used in normal distributions). Variance is the standard deviation squared. Confidence intervals indicate the accuracy of a measurement.

topic: P values, Errors and Power analysis
text: The null hypothesis assumes observed differences are due to chance. A p-value indicates the probability that a difference is not due to chance, with a p-value < 0.05 typically used to reject the null hypothesis. Type 1 (alpha) errors are false positives (incorrectly rejecting the null hypothesis), while Type 2 (beta) errors are false negatives (incorrectly accepting the null hypothesis).

Study designs include retrospective, prospective, cross-sectional, longitudinal, observational, and experimental. The hierarchy of study types places RCTs and meta-analyses of RCTs at the highest level of evidence. Cohort studies are prospective observational designs with a control group, while case-control studies are retrospective.

RCTs progress through five phases: Pre-clinical (animal studies), Phase 1 (safety in healthy volunteers), Phase 2 (efficacy in a small patient group), Phase 3 (superiority against standard treatment), and Phase 4 (post-market surveillance).

Randomization reduces bias in studies by ensuring baseline characteristics of groups are similar, thereby avoiding confounding factors. Post-hoc power analysis can indicate the significance of positive findings.

Primary bone healing requires absolute stability and rigid fixation, leading to intramembranous ossification. Secondary bone healing involves relative stability and strain, with periosteal (bony) and endosteal (fibrocartilaginous) callus formation.

Bone healing progresses through stages: hematoma/inflammation, soft callus formation (fibrocartilage), hard callus formation (woven bone), and remodeling (lamellar bone according to Wolff's law). Wolff's law states that bone remodels according to mechanical stresses, with osteoblasts dominating compression and osteoclasts dominating tension.

Perren’s Strain Theory posits that fracture healing tissue type is dictated by interfragmentary strain. Too little strain leads to non-union, while too much strain impairs hard callus formation and can cause hypertrophic non-union or pseudoarthrosis. Adverse effects on healing include compromised blood supply, smoking, NSAIDs, and head injury.

Bias is the introduction of systematic prejudice into a study that skews its results. Types of bias include selection, observational, recall, and publication bias. Stratifying before randomization can also introduce bias.
A confounding error is a factor that skews study results but was not introduced, anticipated, or controllable by the observer.

Deciding on an appropriate statistical test involves considering data distribution (normal/Gaussian vs. non-parametric), data type (discrete vs. continuous), number of variables, the research question (group differences vs. associations), and variance equality between groups.

Parametric tests include the Unpaired Student T Test (compares means of two independent, normally distributed groups with similar variance) and ANOVA (used for multiple observations or categories, where groups are not completely independent). The Paired T Test compares two observations in the same subject.

Non-parametric tests are used for discrete data and include Chi Squared (analyzes differences between two categorical groups), Mann Whitney U, and Fishers Exact Test (used for small sample sizes, n<5, as a substitute for Chi Squared).

Correlation tests measure the association between two variables, applicable to both parametric and non-parametric data. The value ranges from -1 to +1, indicating direct association. Pearson's correlation is used for parametric data, while Spearman's Rank Correlation is for non-parametric data.

Screening involves testing a large population for a disease of importance with low prevalence. WHO criteria for a screening test (1968) include the disease being important, having known incidence and natural history, available treatment, and the test being safe, inexpensive, cost-effective, sensitive, and specific.

Incidence refers to the number of new diagnoses in a defined population over time, often expressed as an incidence rate. Prevalence is the number of people with a condition at a given time (a snapshot). Sensitivity measures the test's ability to correctly identify those with the disease (true positives), minimizing false negatives (TP/(TP+FN)). Specificity measures the test's ability to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives), minimizing false positives (TN/(TN+FP)).

Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the likelihood that a positive test result is truly positive (TP/(TP+FP)). Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the likelihood that a negative test result is truly negative (TN/(TN+FN)). Accuracy is the proportion of all true results (TP+TN)/(TP+FP+TN+FN). Odds Ratio, used in case-control studies, compares the likelihood of a positive finding in the study group versus the control group.

Validity refers to how accurately a test measures what it is supposed to. Internal validity relates to the confidence in the cause-and-effect relationship, while external validity concerns the applicability of results to the general population. Reliability refers to the reproducibility of a test, assessed by intra-observer and inter-observer agreement. ROC curves illustrate the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity.
Quality-Adjusted Life Years (QUALYS) are used to assess the cost-effectiveness of therapies, considering life expectancy, costs, and time.

Survival analysis plots outcome data against time to assess survival. Methods include the actuarial method (survival calculated at set time points) and the Kaplan-Meier Product Limit method (recalculates survival after each failure). Life table analysis combines both methods. Reliable survival analysis requires clearly defined endpoints, failure criteria, and consistent treatment of loss to follow-up and death.

Survivorship analysis determines the number of joints followed and the number of failures and censored patients on a yearly basis. Censored patients include those withdrawn or lost to follow-up. Survival calculations are based on surviving implants divided by patients at risk, with adjustments for censored patients.

Analgesics include opioids (mimic endogenous opioids, act on mu receptors via G proteins) and NSAIDs (inhibit prostaglandin production via COX enzymes). Paracetamol weakly inhibits COX and prostaglandins and has a central action. Local anesthetics block sodium channels in neurons, preventing action potential formation.

Glucocorticoids have anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, modifying gene transcription and suppressing macrophage function. Side effects are numerous, encapsulated by the mnemonic 'I WAS HOPPING MAD'. Anti-coagulants like warfarin (inhibits Vitamin K-dependent factors) and heparin (complexes with antithrombin III) are used to prevent clotting.

LMWH also complexes with antithrombin III but selectively inhibits factor 10a. Fondaparinaux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that selectively inhibits factor 10a. Rivaroxaban acts directly on factor 10a, while Dabigatran inhibits thrombin. Aspirin inhibits COX-1 and prostaglandin production, preventing platelet aggregation.

Bone remodeling is a cyclic process involving cytokines (IL6) recruiting osteoclasts, which secrete enzymes to resorb bone. Factors within the bone, like IGF-1, then recruit osteoblasts to lay down osteoid, which is mineralized by hydroxyapatite. IL6 from osteoblasts then recruits osteoclasts, restarting the cycle. Bisphosphonates inhibit osteoclast activity and are resistant to metabolism.

Strontium has anabolic (increases bone formation) and catabolic (decreases bone resorption) effects. Anti-rheumatic drugs include non-disease modifying (steroids, cyclophosphamide) and disease-modifying agents (methotrexate, sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine), as well as biologic response modifiers (entanercept, infliximab, rituximab).

A prosthesis is a device designed to replace the function and appearance of a body part. Successful prosthetic use depends on patient and prosthesis factors, including pre-morbid activity level, contralateral limb status, trunk control, balance, motivation, and co-morbidities. Prosthetic factors include ease of use, aesthetics, durability, and comfort.

Pre-operative assessment for successful wound healing involves evaluating nutrition (low albumin, lymphocyte count, transferrin), vascularity (ABPI, transcutaneous oxygen tension), and planning myoplastic or myodesis techniques for muscle and bone management. General technical points include clean nerve transection, beveled bone ends, avoiding non-absorbable sutures, adequate scar formation, and appropriate stump shape.

Prosthetic fitting should occur after wound healing, with mature scar and controlled edema/neuropathy. Early fitting (<30 days) generally yields better outcomes in the upper limb. Optimal amputation levels provide sufficient stump length for the prosthesis and its mechanism, considering factors like weight-bearing surface and suspension.

Gait abnormalities in transfemoral amputees can stem from prosthetic issues such as short prosthesis, weak abductors, or poor fit (lateral trunk bending), poor socket fit (abducted gait), excess knee friction or long prosthesis (circumducted gait), long prosthesis or poor suspension (vaulted gait), stiff heel or loose socket (foot rotation at heel-strike), and painful stump or loose knee (short stance phase).

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities or weakness, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, cosmetic appeal, durability, washability, comfort, and freedom from pressure areas. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, total contact, and kinaesthetic reminders.

Orthoses can limit motion (e.g., KO for knee hyperextension), correct deformity (e.g., Ponseti boots for clubfoot), or provide a combination of these. They influence joint moments and forces through control of bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of the ground reaction force (GRF).

Materials used in orthotics include traditional metals, leather, and rubber, as well as plastics like thermosetting and thermoforming plastics, and polyurethane foam. Foot orthoses include insoles (simple or total contact), functional orthotics (e.g., UCBL), shoe alterations (heel raises, rocker bottoms, metatarsal bars, heel wedges, arch supports), and custom-made shoes.

Ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) like Posterior Leaf Spring (for weak dorsiflexors), Ground Reaction AFO (GRAFO), and Dynamic AFO (DAFO) help control ankle and knee motion.
