Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.
Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions and inversions.

Navigation in TKR is beneficial for addressing pre-operative femoral or tibial deformities and has been shown to improve the consistency of recreating correct mechanical axes in primary TKR, although its correlation with improved clinical outcomes is not yet established.
Custom cutting blocks offer an alternative for difficult or primary knee replacements, with knees templated from pre-operative MRI or CT scans to create personalized blocks.

Catastrophic wear in Total Knee Replacement (TKR) is distinct from long-term wear from submicron particles and is influenced by polyethylene thickness, manufacturing, sterilization, articular geometry, and sagittal plane kinematics. Minimum acceptable polyethylene thickness is 8mm, with thinner components having lower yield strength. Flatter polyethylene leading to decreased congruency and higher contact pressures causes accelerated wear, such as edge loading and fatigue failure.

PE sterilization methods include oxidation (weakening PE) and irradiation (cross-linking). Oxidized PE is weaker and more prone to wear, particularly in the subsurface white band. Highly cross-linked UHMWPE, produced by prolonged irradiation, offers improved strength and wear resistance. Direct compression molding is the preferred method of polyethylene manufacturing.

topic: Total Knee Replacement In Specific Situations
text: TKR after previous high tibial osteotomy (HTO) or patellectomy can present challenges. HTO may result in worse TKR outcomes and more difficult lateral closing wedge osteotomies. Previous patellectomy leads to reduced quadriceps power, potentially causing flexion instability and maltracking. Neuropathic arthropathy (e.g., Charcot) generally has worse outcomes, requiring careful management and potential grafting.

Periprosthetic fractures, particularly acetabular fractures, can occur intra-operatively (due to bone quality, impaction, or component issues) or post-operatively (due to trauma, infection, or loosening). Management depends on fracture displacement, component stability, extent, and bone stock. Femoral fractures are influenced by bone quality, stem design, and intra-operative factors like excessive femoral bow.

Hip instability after THA can be caused by surgical factors (component malposition, inadequate offset, impingement, shortening, poor soft tissue repair) or patient factors (cognitive impairment, high ROM, contact sports). Determinants of hip stability include component design, position, and soft tissue tension/function. Primary arc range, determined by the head-neck ratio, is crucial for stability.

Excursion distance, determined by head size, is the distance the head travels before dislocation. Larger heads offer greater primary arc range and excursion distance, increasing stability. Narrower tapers increase the head-neck ratio and stability. Acetabular augmentation (hooded cups) can improve stability but may lower the primary arc range. Component positioning aims for the center of the functional range to allow leeway.

Soft tissue tension, primarily from abductors, stabilizes the hip. Reduced offset or neck length can lead to abductor de-tensioning or trochanteric impingement. Soft tissue dysfunction, often neurogenic or multifactorial in the elderly, can cause instability. Management of dislocated THA involves addressing causes like eccentric poly wear and component malposition, with revision often indicated for recurrent dislocations.

Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head results from microvascular coagulation, leading to venous congestion and arterial occlusion. Causes include corticosteroids, trauma, alcohol, sickle cell disease, and irradiation. Ficat and Steinberg classifications stage AVN, with Management Options including non-operative measures and surgical interventions like core decompression, osteotomy, arthroplasty, and arthrodesis.

Femoral osteotomies are indicated for hip conditions like acetabular development issues in children, predominant femoral deformity, or inadequate coverage with pelvic osteotomy. Arthrodesis is an option for young patients with severe dysplasia or advanced OA, but it sacrifices joint motion. Resection arthroplasty is a salvage procedure for non-ambulatory patients.

The knee is a condylar joint, while the patellofemoral joint is a saddle joint. The tibia has a posterior slope and varus alignment, with a higher lateral plateau. The femur has a larger MFC and wider LFC. The patella has thickest articular cartilage and three facets. Wiberg classification categorizes patellar morphology.

Biomechanics of the knee involve joint reaction forces that vary with activity. Ligaments, including the ACL and PCL, provide static and dynamic stability, with the ACL's anteromedial bundle tight in flexion and posterolateral in extension. Menisci contribute to load sharing and joint conformity, with lateral meniscus tears being more common and increasing contact pressure after meniscectomy.

ACL injuries are common, often non-contact, and associated with haemarthrosis. Lachman test has high sensitivity and specificity for ACL tears. Concurrent injuries like meniscal tears and patellofemoral lesions are frequent. Management aims for a stable, asymptomatic knee, with non-operative treatment for minor sprains and surgical reconstruction for significant instability.

PCL injuries result from direct posterior tibial translation. Management includes non-operative treatment for less severe tears and reconstruction for Grade 3 injuries or combined ligament injuries. Surgical options for PCL reconstruction include single or double bundle techniques, tibial onlay or trans-tibial inlay, and graft selection from hamstring, BPTB, or allograft.

The Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) is the primary static restraint to valgus, with three layers: superficial (fan-shaped), deep (thickened capsule), and dynamic stabilizers. MCL injuries are most common and typically managed non-operatively with bracing and rehabilitation. Operative treatment is reserved for chronic instability or acute tears requiring repair or reconstruction.

Patellar dislocations and subluxations are common, with recurrence higher after a first event. Risk factors include patella alta, trochlear dysplasia, increased Q angle, and soft tissue laxity. Mechanism of injury is often non-contact pivot. Examination involves assessing swelling, patellar tracking, and tenderness. Management ranges from non-operative measures to surgical correction of underlying causes.

Patellar and quadriceps tendon pathology often results from repetitive sports activities or metabolic risk factors. Diagnosis is based on history and examination, with imaging aiding in identifying tendon thickening and bone spurs. Management can be non-operative (activity modification, eccentric exercises) or operative (tendon debridement, repair, or transfer).

topic: Management of Articular Cartilage Defects of the Knee
text: Articular cartilage defects in the knee can cause pain, future arthritis, and mechanical symptoms. Treatment options include non-operative modalities and surgical interventions such as debridement, bone marrow stimulation (microfracture), osteochondral grafting (auto- or allograft), and chondrocyte implantation. Prognosis is influenced by patient age, lesion size, and complexity.

Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) involves a subchondral fracture or detached fragment of cartilage and bone. It can be hereditary, vascular, or traumatic in etiology. Location is typically medial or lateral, with lateral lesions often traumatic and unstable. Classification (Berndt & Hardy, Cahill) is based on XR and MRI findings. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical debridement or grafting.

Achilles tendinopathy affects middle-aged athletes and can be non-insertional (2-6 cm from insertion) or insertional (often with Haglund's deformity). Pathoanatomy involves fibrocartilaginous metaplasia and attritional tears. Rupture can occur in asymptomatic tendons. Management includes non-operative measures (activity modification, heel raises) and surgical interventions (debridement, tendon transfer).

The Achilles tendon transfers approximately 10 times body weight during terminal stance and pre-swing. Clinical features of tendinopathy include activity-related pain and swelling. Examination involves assessing swelling location and using tests like Symmonds test for tendon continuity. Imaging may show Haglund's deformity or calcaneal cystic changes.

Peroneal tendon problems include degenerate tears (more common in peroneus brevis) and instability due to SPR tears. Pathoanatomy involves the peroneal tendons originating from the fibula and passing over the CFL, stabilized by the SPR. Tears can be longitudinal or complete. Instability is caused by SPR tearing, strongly associated with ankle instability and shallow fibula groove.

Ligamentous stabilizers of the ankle include the lateral ligaments (ATFL, CFL, PTFL, SPR, IPR, IER, AITFL, PITFL, IOTFL), talocalcaneal ligaments, deltoid ligament, and spring ligament. The ATFL is the primary restraint to anterior translation, while the PITFL is the strongest lateral stabilizer. Instability is classified based on functional or mechanical criteria and risk factors include hindfoot varus and equinus.

Ankle impingement can be anterior, posterior, medial, or lateral. Anterior impingement is most common, caused by soft tissue synovitis or bony spurs. Posterior impingement involves posterior structures like the PITFL or Os Trigonum. Clinical features include pain and mechanical symptoms. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical options like arthroscopic debridement or spur excision.

topic: Pes Cavus & Charcot Marie Tooth Disease
text: Pes cavus and Charcot Marie Tooth disease (CMT) are common inherited neuropathies, with an autosomal dominant pattern being most frequent. CMT affects peripheral nerve myelination and can cause foot deformities like cavus, cavovarus, and hammer toes. Surgery aims to maintain flexibility with transfers and osteotomies, while fusion is generally avoided in young patients.

Hallux valgus is a common forefoot deformity, more prevalent in women, with predisposing factors including joint laxity, shoewear, hormonal influences, and genetics. Pathogenesis theories involve metatarsus primus varus and 1st TMTJ hypermobility. Clinical evaluation assesses gait, passive correction, MTPJ OA, and foot shape. Management includes non-operative options like footwear modifications and surgical procedures such as cheilectomy, osteotomy, and arthroplasty.

Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism leading to intra-articular accumulation of monosodium urate crystals, causing pain, inflammation, and arthropathy. It is more common in men and older adults, often affecting the first MTPJ, ankle, and lesser metatarsal/mid-tarsal/subtalar joints. Inciting factors include alcohol, purine-rich foods, trauma, post-surgical states, and certain medications. Diagnosis relies on clinical features, joint aspiration revealing needle-shaped crystals, and XR findings of erosions and soft tissue swelling.

Pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), is characterized by intra-articular deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals, causing acute inflammatory arthritis that can mimic septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals. Management is symptomatic with NSAIDs, rest, and activity modification.

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are a group of inflammatory arthritides that are rheumatoid factor-negative. They primarily affect entheses rather than articular joints and commonly present with Achilles tendinopathy, TP tendinopathy, and plantar fasciitis. Psoriatic arthritis, a common seronegative spondyloarthropathy, can cause joint destruction, particularly in the foot's lesser DIPJs, and is associated with dactylitis and nail pitting. Management involves medical treatment with NSAIDs and DMARDs, and surgical joint fusions if necessary.

Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) affects individuals under 16 and presents as inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic manifestations. It is similar to adult rheumatoid arthritis, but RF is rarely positive. Clinical features can include wrist ulnar deviation and finger radial deviation at the MCPJ. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints, ANA positive), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgical interventions.

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy that occurs secondary to genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections. It typically affects the knee and can involve enthesitis and spondylolitis. Extra-articular manifestations, such as conjunctivitis and urethritis, are key to diagnosis. Management is primarily medical, with supportive therapy for the self-limiting condition.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome is a group of inherited connective tissue disorders affecting collagen, characterized by joint hypermobility and excessive skin laxity. Clinical features include fragile, lax, easily scarred skin, and severe kyphoscoliosis. Management requires aggressive treatment for scoliosis and potential surgery for associated deformities.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures to prevent further injury.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas typically cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas resemble osteosarcomas but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine and can metastasize late. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup depend on the suspected tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are called sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults and affects the foot, while clear cell sarcoma is also a soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand and may be mistaken for benign lesions. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.
