Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexes, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Forearm and arm replantation requires establishing arterial flow first if possible, minimizing warm ischemia time, and performing prophylactic fasciotomies for all patients.
Ring avulsion injuries involve the avulsion of soft tissues and neurovascular structures from the finger.

The Urbaniak Classification categorizes ring avulsion injuries into three types: Type 1 involves circumferential laceration with viable neurovascular structures and is treated as a soft tissue injury. Type 2 indicates vascular insufficiency, with replantation considered if bone/tendon are intact. Type 3 involves complete avulsion with exposed bone, necessitating amputation.

Nail and finger tip injuries are common, with long fingers most frequently affected. Mechanisms include crush injuries (potentially causing tuft fractures and nail matrix/plate avulsions) and sharp injuries (leading to soft tissue loss or exposed bone). The nail plate is composed of keratin and arises from the germinal matrix, which contributes 90% of the nail's thickness. The sterile matrix is adherent to the nail plate and produces keratin.

topic: Goals of treatment in finger tip injuries
text: The primary goals of treatment for finger tip injuries are to maintain length, achieve sensate finger pulp, prevent contracture, and restore full function.

topic: Management of nail bed injury without soft tissue loss
text: Subungual hematomas can be drained with a needle if they involve less than 50% of the nail plate. If a large hematoma is present, the nail plate may need to be removed, with inspection and repair of the underlying sterile or germinal matrix. Early surgical treatment of nail bed injuries yields the best results, and replacing the nail plate guides new nail growth.
Complications of finger tip injuries include hook nail, nail ridging, and cold hypersensitivity (50%).

topic: Management of finger tip injury with soft tissue loss
text: Classification of finger tip injuries with soft tissue loss is descriptive, referring to the orientation of the residual stump (transverse, volar oblique, dorsal oblique, lateral oblique). Bone exposure determines the management approach. For wounds with no exposed bone and pulp loss <1cm, secondary intention healing or a full-thickness skin graft are options. For exposed bone, volar oblique injuries may require a cross-finger or thenar flap, while transverse or dorsal oblique injuries might need an Atasoy VY advancement or Kutler VY advancement.

Dupuytren's contracture is a benign fibroproliferative disease affecting the palmar fascia, with risk factors including male sex, Northern European heritage, alcohol use, smoking, family history, manual labor, diabetes, and anti-epileptic drugs. It involves proliferation of fascia and abnormal collagen cross-linking, leading to nodule and cord formation and a characteristic progression through proliferative, involutional, and residual stages.

Dupuytren's diasthesis is a syndrome of severe Dupuytren's contracture characterized by strong family history, affliction of radial digits (thumb and index), ectopic disease (penis-peyronie's, feet-Ledderhose), Garrod's pads, bilateral involvement, and young presentation.

Hand infections can be superficial (paronychia, felon, web space abscess) or deep (flexor sheaths, bursae, palmar spaces). The most common pathogen is Staphylococcus Aureus. Paronychia involves nail fold infection, while felon is a pulp space infection requiring incision and drainage. Web space infections may present as collar stud abscesses. Deep infections carry significant risks.

Infection of the palmar spaces is characterized by severe pain, high fever, and absence of fusiform swelling. Management involves optimizing diabetic control and vascular perfusion, and may include antibiotics, debridement, and wound care. Amputation may be necessary for severe infections.

Infections can be caused by various organisms, including Staphylococcus Aureus (coagulase-positive) and Staphylococcus Epidermis (coagulase-negative). Biofilms, communities of bacteria coated in glycocalyx, enhance resistance to phagocytosis and adherence. Antibiotics like Beta-lactams inhibit cell wall synthesis, while macrolides and aminoglycosides inhibit protein synthesis.

Nerve conduction studies (NCS) and EMG are used to assess nerve function. Latency, amplitude, and velocity provide information about nerve conduction quality and quantity. Factors affecting nerve conduction include age, temperature, limb, and nerve location. Radial nerve lesions can occur in the upper arm (fracture, palsy), elbow (PIN palsy, radial tunnel syndrome), or forearm. Median nerve lesions include pronator syndrome and anterior interosseous syndrome.

Typical transfers for radial nerve palsy aim to restore wrist and thumb extension. For nerve transfers, the focus is on restoring function, replacing ruptured tendons, or rebalancing deformities. Graft selection considers autograft (low morbidity) or allograft (faster recovery but potential immunogenicity).

The hand has complex biomechanics involving IP, MP, and CMC joints, each with specific axes of movement and stability. The thumb CMCJ is a saddle joint enabling crucial functions like opposition. Tendons are organized into zones based on their location and the pulley system that prevents bowstringing.

Flexor tendons are extrinsic and intrinsic, with FDP being a mass action muscle. The "Quadrigia effect" occurs when one FDP tendon is tethered, causing slight flexion in other digits. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension. Intrinsic paralysis leads to a "intrinsic minus" hand with MCPJ hyperextension.

The carpus comprises two rows of bones, with the proximal row being an intercalated segment stabilized by bony geometry and extrinsic ligaments. Carpal kinematics involve flexion/extension at the radiocarpal joint and radial/ulna deviation at the midcarpal joint. Carpal instability is classified as dissociative (within rows) or non-dissociative (between rows), with CID and CIC representing complex patterns.

Carpal instability can be dissociative (intrinsic ligament failure), non-dissociative (between rows), or complex (combination of both). DISI and VISI patterns describe specific postures of the lunate. Mayfield's classification of peri-lunate dislocations stages the injury based on the degree of carpal uncoupling.

Replantation of amputated digits or limbs requires establishing arterial flow, minimizing warm ischemia time, and performing prophylactic fasciotomies. The Urbaniak Classification categorizes ring avulsion injuries based on the severity of vascular and soft tissue damage.

Nail and finger tip injuries are common, with crush mechanisms potentially causing tuft fractures and nail matrix/plate avulsions, while sharp injuries lead to soft tissue loss. Nail structure includes the nail plate (keratin), germinal matrix (nail production), and sterile matrix (adherent to nail plate).

Reconstructive options for soft tissue defects include primary closure, secondary intention, skin grafts (split-thickness and full-thickness), local flaps, and free flaps. Healing by secondary intention is generally not advised for exposed tendons, nerves, or bones. Skin grafts receive blood supply via diffusion, and their failure can be due to shear stress or hematoma.

Flaps provide a tissue unit with blood supply, which can be axial or random in pattern. Axial flaps are based on a named artery, while random flaps rely on random diffusion. Flaps can be classified by tissue type (cutaneous, fasciocutaneous, musculocutaneous, osteocutaneous) and blood supply pattern. Management of finger tip injuries with soft tissue loss involves classification based on bone exposure and pulp loss, guiding choices between non-operative measures and surgical reconstruction.

Extensor tendons are vascular and covered by a synovial sheath at the extensor retinaculum. They are organized into six compartments at the wrist. The extensor mechanism involves contributions from long extensors and intrinsics, with sagittal bands stabilizing the extensor hood. The fingers' extensor mechanism allows for MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension.

Flexor tendons are organized into zones based on their location in the finger and hand. Zone 2 is critical due to the tight, non-distensible sheath and intimate relationship between FDS and FDP, making it vulnerable to adhesions and rupture. Tendon nutrition relies on the vincula system and passive diffusion. The "Quadrigia effect" occurs when one FDP tendon is shortened, causing slight flexion in other digits.

Flexor tendons are primarily intrasynovial, with the index, middle, and ring fingers entering the sheath at the MC neck. Thumb and little finger tendons have a synovial sheath throughout the palm. Nutrition occurs via longitudinal vessels (vincula) and passive diffusion from synovial fluid, which relies on motion.

The pulley system, comprising annular (A1-5) and cruciate pulleys, prevents tendon bowstringing and maintains proximity to the joint's center of rotation, optimizing power transmission. The flexor retinaculum also functions as a pulley. Annular pulleys are thick and fibrous, while cruciate pulleys are flimsy.

Thumb deformities include boutonniere (MCPJ problem), swan neck (CMCJ problem), and instability. Fusion procedures are the mainstay for stable grip. Management depends on the specific deformity and involves options like fusion, arthroplasty, or soft tissue procedures. Classification of rheumatoid thumb (Naelbuff) categorizes deformities into six types.

Kienbock's disease is a condition affecting the lunate, often associated with negative ulnar variance and unstable carpus. It progresses from ischemic changes to necrosis, sclerosis, structural failure, and arthritis. Diagnosis relies on XR and MRI, with management options including conservative measures and surgical procedures like radial shortening osteotomy or scapholunate fusion.

Hallux valgus is a common forefoot deformity affecting the MTPJ, with etiology involving genetic and environmental factors. Clinical evaluation assesses gait, passive correction, and MTPJ OA. Management includes non-operative measures (footwear modification) and surgical options like cheilectomy, osteotomy, and arthroplasty. Sesamoids are normally centered under the MTPJ, and medial deviation of the 1st MT leads to their uncovering.

Hallux rigidus is a condition of the first MTPJ causing stiffness and pain, more common in women and often bilateral. Etiology can be idiopathic, inflammatory, post-traumatic, or infective. Natural history varies, with some cases improving. XR features include osteophytes and joint space narrowing. Management involves non-operative measures and surgical options such as cheilectomy, osteotomy, arthroplasty, and arthrodesis.

Bunionette deformity (tailor's bunion) involves a prominent 5th metatarsal head, often associated with RA and hallux valgus. Classification is based on the cause, with Type 1 involving a large 5th metatarsal head, Type 2 a bowed 5th metatarsal shaft, and Type 3 an increased 4th-5th IM angle. Management is primarily non-operative, with surgical options including bunionette excision or osteotomy.

Adult acquired flat foot is primarily caused by Tibialis Posterior tendinopathy or rupture, which compromises the medial longitudinal arch's static restraints. Other causes include inflammatory arthritis, tarsal coalition, and neurological imbalance. Gait mechanics are altered, with pronation and supple midfoot during stance, and a rigid lever arm for propulsion. Management involves conservative measures and surgical correction of deformities.

The medial longitudinal arch provides shock absorption and propulsion. It is not rigid but varies its function during gait. Stabilizers include the plantar fascia, spring ligament, and other ligaments. During gait, tibial rotation and subtalar joint motion allow for arch adaptation.

topic: Pes Cavus & Charcot Marie Tooth Disease
text: Pes cavus and Charcot Marie Tooth disease (CMT) are inherited neuropathies affecting peripheral nerves. CMT is predominantly a motor neuropathy causing muscle imbalance and foot deformities like cavus, cavovarus, and hammer toes. Surgery aims to maintain flexibility with transfers and osteotomies, while fusion is generally avoided in young patients. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical correction.

Peroneal tendon problems include degenerate tears (more common in peroneus brevis) and instability due to SPR tears. Pathoanatomy involves the peroneal tendons originating from the fibula and passing over the CFL, stabilized by the SPR. Tears can be longitudinal or complete. Instability results from SPR tearing, often associated with ankle instability and shallow fibula groove.

Ankle instability is classified as functional or mechanical, with risk factors including hindfoot varus and equinus. Examination assesses laxity and instability. Management includes non-operative measures for stable sprains and surgical intervention for significant instability or tears requiring repair or reconstruction.

Ankle impingement can be anterior, posterior, medial, or lateral. Anterior impingement is most common, caused by soft tissue synovitis or bony spurs. Posterior impingement involves posterior structures like the PITFL or Os Trigonum. Clinical features include pain and mechanical symptoms. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical arthroscopic debridement or spur excision.

Osteochondral lesions of the talus (OCLs) occur from injury, often minor, and can be medial or lateral. Lateral lesions are more commonly traumatic and unstable. Classification systems (Berndt & Hardy, Cahill) are based on XR and MRI findings. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical arthroscopic debridement or grafting.

topic: High Tibial Osteotomy for Varus Knee
text: High tibial osteotomy (HTO) is indicated for varus malalignment with medial compartment OA, pain, or instability. It aims to restore mechanical alignment and protect cartilage. Contraindications include severe OA, fixed deformities, and patellar instability. Management involves closing lateral wedge or opening medial wedge osteotomies, with careful consideration of bone stock and potential complications.

The ACL has anteromedial and posterolateral bundles, crucial for preventing anterior tibial translation and hyperextension. Injury typically results from non-contact pivoting or deceleration. Immediate hemarthrosis and Lachman test are key diagnostic findings. Management involves non-operative measures for stable sprains and surgical reconstruction for instability.

PCL injuries result from direct posterior tibial translation and varus/valgus stress. The PCL is a secondary stabilizer. Management includes non-operative measures for less severe tears and reconstruction for Grade 3 injuries or combined ligament injuries. Surgical options for PCL reconstruction involve graft selection from hamstring, BPTB, or allograft.

The MCL is the primary static restraint to valgus, with superficial and deep layers. MCL injuries are common and typically managed non-operatively. Operative treatment is indicated for chronic instability or acute tears requiring repair or reconstruction. Combined ACL and MCL injuries necessitate careful timing of treatment.

Patellofemoral instability involves symptomatic patellar dislocation/subluxation, usually lateral. Risk factors include patella alta, trochlear dysplasia, increased Q angle, and soft tissue laxity. Examination assesses alignment, Q angle, and patellar tracking. Management includes non-operative measures and surgical correction of underlying causes.

TKR design principles focus on restoring normal knee biomechanics, including alignment, joint line, and ligament balance. Modern TKRs aim for normal femoral rollback, with PCL retaining or substituting designs. Mobile bearing knees offer conformity but may have poly spin out issues. Causes of TKR failure include osteolysis, aseptic loosening, wear, instability, and infection.

TKR after previous HTO or patellectomy presents challenges. HTO can lead to worse outcomes and more difficult procedures. Previous patellectomy compromises quadriceps power. Neuropathic arthropathy generally has worse outcomes. Management of bone loss involves classification and reconstructive options like impaction grafting, augments, and cages.

Shoulder anatomy includes the humerus, glenoid, and clavicle. Glenohumeral motion is driven by the rotator cuff and deltoid. Scapulothoracic motion is essential for glenoid articulation. Glenohumeral stability relies on static stabilizers (labrum, geometry, ligaments) and dynamic stabilizers (muscles, proprioception).

The carpus has two rows of bones, with the proximal row being an intercalated segment stabilized by bony geometry and ligaments. Carpal kinematics involve flexion/extension at the radiocarpal joint and radial/ulna deviation at the midcarpal joint. Carpal instability is classified as dissociative or non-dissociative, with complex patterns involving both.

Extensor tendons are vascular and have a paratenon. They are organized into six compartments at the wrist. The extensor mechanism involves long extensors, intrinsics, and the extensor hood. Flexor tendons are extrinsic and intrinsic, with FDP being a mass action muscle. Tendon nutrition relies on the vincula system and synovial fluid.

The hand's biomechanics involve IP, MP, and CMC joints with specific movements and stability. The thumb CMCJ's saddle joint allows crucial functions like opposition. Tendons are organized into zones, with the pulley system preventing bowstringing. Lumbricals fine-tune tendon tension, and interossei contribute to MCPJ flexion and PIPJ extension.

Spinal stability is maintained by passive (vertebrae, discs, ligaments), active (musculature), and neural subsystems. The spine's saggital shape and facet joint orientation influence movement and stability. Age-related changes lead to disc degeneration, reduced mobility, and increased risk of spinal canal stenosis.

Intervertebral discs, composed of annulus fibrosus and nucleus pulposus, provide shock absorption and mobility. Disc degeneration involves dehydration and changes in collagen and proteoglycan content. Herniation occurs when the annulus tears, potentially causing nerve impingement. Spinal ligaments (ALL, PLL, ligamentum flavum) are crucial for stability.

Bone metabolism is regulated by calcium and phosphate homeostasis, influenced by Vitamin D, PTH, and calcitonin. Osteoblasts produce osteoid and RANKL, while osteoclasts resorb bone, regulated by RANKL and OPG. Bone matrix consists of inorganic (hydroxyapatite) and organic (collagen) components.

Bone tumors are classified as benign or malignant. Benign tumors include osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma, chondroma, enchondroma, non-ossifying fibroma, and aneurysmal bone cysts. Malignant tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Management strategies vary based on tumor type, grade, and location.

Malignant soft tissue tumors, or sarcomas, are classified by tissue of origin. They are more common in older patients and males, presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI is often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management involves wide local excision and adjuvant therapy, with prognosis varying by tumor type and grade.

Prosthetic components include the socket, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee disarticulations have specific socket needs, and hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices for support, correction, or compensation. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations, while AFOs and KAFOs support the lower limb. THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes, including 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Imaging techniques include plain X-rays, CT scans (3D images based on voxel attenuation), MRI (utilizing magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils), bone scans (assessing blood flow and osteoblast activity), and DEXA scans (measuring bone mineral density). Hounsfield Units quantify CT attenuation.

Operating room design emphasizes infection control through proper ventilation and air filtration. Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are precisely controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from personnel, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with MRSA having resistance to Beta-lactams.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves cartilage changes and altered proteoglycan function. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular, and polyarticular. Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious, and gout involves uric acid crystal deposition.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis and orthopaedic manifestations like joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature and joint hypermobility. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity. Management includes supportive care, genetic counseling, and surgical correction of deformities.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management involves non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.

Prostheses replace body parts to restore function and appearance, with successful use depending on patient and prosthesis factors. Amputations require pre-operative assessment of nutrition, vascularity, and appropriate surgical techniques. Optimal amputation levels are crucial for prosthetic fitting. Transfemoral gait abnormalities can result from prosthetic issues or patient factors.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Prosthetic components include the socket/interface, suspension mechanism, and terminal device. Trans-tibial prostheses have sockets that distribute load. Transfemoral prostheses require careful socket design and suspension. Knee and ankle disarticulations have specific socket needs. Hip prostheses involve acetabular cups and femoral stems, with various fixation methods.

Orthotics are external devices that support, correct, or compensate for deformities, improving function. Ideal characteristics include ease of use, lightness, durability, and comfort. Functional characteristics involve 3-point pressure, end-point control, and total contact. Foot orthoses include insoles and shoe alterations. AFOs and KAFOs assist lower limb function, while THPBs are used for fracture healing.

Orthoses influence joint moments and forces by controlling bending moments, translation, axial force, and the line of ground reaction force (GRF). Materials include plastics, leather, and rubber. Different orthotic types are used for specific conditions, such as TLSO for spinal support and posterior leaf spring AFOs for weak dorsiflexors.

Chromosomes, composed of DNA, RNA, and proteins, carry genetic information. Humans have 46 chromosomes: 22 pairs of autosomes and sex chromosomes (XX female, XY male). Genes are DNA sequences coding for protein synthesis. Autosomal dominant inheritance requires one affected allele for expression, while autosomal recessive inheritance requires two. X-linked conditions are more common in males.

Chromosomal abnormalities include monosomy (e.g., Turner Syndrome) and trisomy (e.g., Down Syndrome). Structural abnormalities involve point mutations, deletions, and inversions. Penetrance describes how consistently a genotype expresses a phenotype. Understanding genetic inheritance patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing hereditary conditions.

Plain X-rays use differential absorption of tissues by high-energy radiation. CT scans create 3D images from voxel data, with Hounsfield Units quantifying tissue attenuation. MRI uses magnetic fields and radiofrequency coils to image tissues based on proton behavior, with T1, T2, and TR parameters influencing contrast. Bone scans assess blood flow and osteoblast activity, while DEXA scans measure bone mineral density.

Operating room design includes zones for patient flow and infection control, with sterile environments maintained through proper ventilation and air filtration (HEPA). Temperature, humidity, light, and ventilation are carefully controlled. Bacterial contamination is primarily airborne from people, with acceptable CFU/m³ limits for different cleanliness levels. Ventilatory systems like plenum and laminar flow manage airborne organisms. Appropriate clothing, drapes, masks, and gloves are essential for infection control.

Inflammation involves vascular changes and cellular responses. Chronic infections are often caused by resistant organisms, with mononuclear cells predominating. Bacteria are prokaryotic and possess a cell wall. Gram staining differentiates bacteria based on cell wall properties. Antibiotics target bacterial processes like cell wall synthesis and protein synthesis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is crucial for preventing surgical site infections, with different antibiotic classes having specific mechanisms and examples. MRSA has a modified penicillin-binding protein, conferring resistance.

Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease with primary or secondary causes. Pathology involves altered proteoglycan function, reduced subchondral drainage, and cartilage changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory polyarthropathy affecting the synovium, leading to joint destruction and systemic manifestations. Management includes medical therapies and surgery. Seronegative spondyloarthropathies include ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and reactive arthritis.

JIA affects individuals under 16 and presents as an inflammatory polyarticular disease with systemic features. Subtypes include systemic (Still's disease), oligoarticular (<5 joints), and polyarticular (>5 joints). Management involves medical treatments and possible surgery. Reactive arthritis is post-infectious and typically affects the knee, with extra-articular manifestations aiding diagnosis. Gout is a metabolic disorder of purine metabolism causing uric acid crystal deposition in joints.

Pyrophosphate arthropathy results from calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition, mimicking septic arthritis. Radiographs may show chondrocalcinosis, with the wrist and knee most commonly affected. Aspiration reveals positively birefringent pyrophosphate crystals.

Scleroderma is a systemic autoimmune disease affecting connective tissues, leading to sclerosis. Orthopaedic manifestations include joint contractures and digital changes. Management may involve sympathectomy for digital ischemia.

SLE is an autoimmune condition affecting multiple systems, including joints, causing deformities like ulnar deviation at the MCPJ and volar subluxation. It can also lead to joint laxity and osteonecrosis. Management involves DMARDs, NSAIDs, steroids, and fusion.

Marfan's Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of collagen, causing tall stature, joint hypermobility, and cardiovascular abnormalities. Clinical signs include positive wrist and thumb tests. Management involves ECHO referral and genetic counseling. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves collagen defects leading to joint hypermobility and skin laxity, requiring aggressive treatment for kyphoscoliosis.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta is a genetic disorder of collagen type 1, causing brittle bones and recurrent fractures. Clinical features include short stature, scoliosis, and tooth defects. Management includes non-surgical options like bisphosphonates and growth hormone, and surgical fixation of fractures.

Benign bone tumors are classified histologically and by Enneking stage. Osteoid Osteomas cause night pain and are managed with NSAIDs or excision. Osteoblastomas are locally aggressive and treated surgically. Paraosteal osteomas grow on the bone surface, while bone islands are asymptomatic lesions. Osteopikilosis causes multiple bone islands, and enchondromas can undergo malignant transformation.

Chondroblastomas are epiphyseal lesions. Chondromyxoid fibromas are rare, locally aggressive metaphyseal tumors managed with curettage and grafting. Haemangiomas are benign vascular tumors with characteristic radiographic findings. Non-ossifying fibromas are common in children. Giant Cell Tumours are locally aggressive and treated surgically.

Malignant bone tumors include osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chordoma, lymphoma, myeloma, and metastatic bone disease. Osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor, affects young patients and is treated with chemotherapy and surgery. Chondrosarcomas have variable grades and prognoses, requiring wide resection for high-grade tumors.

Fibrosarcomas are similar to osteosarcoma but lack osteoid. Chordomas occur in the midline spine. Lymphoma and myeloma are systemic diseases. Metastatic bone disease spreads hematogenously or via venous plexuses, commonly affecting the spine and pelvis. Imaging and diagnostic workup vary by tumor type.

Malignant soft tissue tumors are sarcomas, typically affecting older adults and presenting with rapid growth and pain. MRI scans are often indeterminate, requiring biopsy. Management includes wide local excision and adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy for Ewing's and rhabdomyosarcoma). Synovial sarcoma is common in young adults, while clear cell sarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot.

Epithelioid sarcoma is common in the hand. MFH is the most common sarcoma in older adults. Liposarcoma is the second most common soft tissue sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue tumor of childhood. Neurofibrosarcomas arise from Schwann cells, and angiosarcomas are highly malignant with poor prognosis.
