Exploration should be considered if there's no activity by 3 months, or if the palsy occurs after reduction in a Holstein-Lewis fracture pattern (though the benefit is not definitively proven).

Workup for non-union should identify contributing factors like smoking or infection. Treatment typically involves ORIF with bone grafting and compression plating. Compression plating alone may suffice for hypertrophic non-unions.

topic: Hemiarthroplasty for Proximal Humerus Fractures: Patient and Fracture Factors
text: Hemiarthroplasty is indicated for low-demand patients, generally over 75 years old unless very fit, and more commonly in females due to osteoporotic bone. Fracture factors favoring hemiarthroplasty include head-split fractures, delayed fracture-dislocations, and initial varus malalignment greater than 20 degrees where anatomical reduction of the medial hinge cannot be achieved. It is also a salvage option for failed ORIF, AVN, non-union, or malunion.

topic: Key Factors for Successful Hemiarthroplasty of the Proximal Humerus
text: Successful hemiarthroplasty relies on accurate tuberosity reduction and healing, with the greater tuberosity positioned 10-15 mm from the top of the prosthesis. Humeral head height should not be too proud to avoid tuberosity detachment or too short, which compromises cuff mechanics. The top of the pectoralis major tendon should be approximately 5.6 cm below the top of the head, and the tuberosity should be 10-15 mm below the head. Correct humeral head version is crucial, aiming for 20-30 degrees to prevent posterior instability; excessive retroversion is a common mistake.

topic: Complications and Outcomes of Proximal Humerus Hemiarthroplasty
text: Complications include dislocation, glenoid erosion, iatrogenic fracture, tuberosity non-union or malunion, and poor cuff function (especially with pre-existing cuff disease). Best outcomes are achieved when hemiarthroplasty is performed early (<2 weeks), as a primary procedure (not salvage), and when the tuberosities heal in an anatomical position. Expected outcomes include 90 degrees of abduction, 30 degrees of external rotation, and 100 degrees of forward flexion.

topic: Trauma Severity Scores: Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS)
text: The Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) ranks injuries from 1 (minor) to 6 (unsurvivable). This ranking system is used to calculate the Injury Severity Score (ISS).

topic: Trauma Severity Scores: Injury Severity Score (ISS)
text: The ISS is an anatomical scoring system that grades the overall severity of an injury. It is calculated by squaring the AIS scores of the three most severely injured body regions and summing them. An AIS score of 6 in any region automatically results in an ISS of 75. A rising ISS score correlates with mortality, with scores above 25 indicating a severe injury potentially requiring transfer to a trauma center, and scores above 40 indicating a life-threatening injury.

topic: Disadvantages of the Injury Severity Score (ISS)
text: The ISS has several disadvantages: any error in AIS coding increases the ISS, it does not weight body areas independently, multiple injury patterns can yield the same ISS score, and it only allows one score per body area, excluding multiple injuries within a single region.

topic: Trauma Severity Scores: New Injury Severity Score (NISS)
text: The NISS is a modification of the ISS that allows the top AIS scores to come from the same body segment. This provides a more realistic assessment of a patient's survival potential, as it scores multiple injuries within a single area separately.

topic: Evaluation and Management of Limb Deformity: History and Examination
text: A thorough history should inquire about the onset of the deformity, pain, functional limitations, and signs of sepsis. Examination involves manual stressing of the malunion site to assess for pain or movement, evaluating soft tissues for surgical amenability and signs of infection, assessing range of motion (ROM) of adjacent joints to identify compensatory deformities, evaluating functional problems like gait, and measuring leg lengths. Neurovascular status must also be documented.

Full-length, weight-bearing views are preferred when possible. True AP and lateral films of the affected segments are essential to assess overall limb alignment, mechanical and anatomical axes, deformity plane, joint deformity, and the Center of Rotation of Angulation (CORA). Joint orientation lines help determine if the deformity is near the joint or within the diaphysis.

topic: Key Angles for Lower Limb Deformity Assessment
text: Important angles to assess include the Lateral Proximal Femoral Angle (LPFA), mechanical and anatomical Lateral Distal Femoral Angle (mLDFA, aLDFA), Joint Line Congruence Angle (JLCA), Medial Proximal Tibia Angle (MPTA), Lateral Distal Tibia Angle (LDTA), Medial Neck Shaft Angle (MNSA), and Mechanical Axis Deviation (MAD) distance at the knee. The MAD quantifies how far the mechanical axis deviates from the knee's center, crucial for calculating varus/valgus alignment.

topic: Center of Rotation of Angulation (CORA) in Limb Deformity
text: CORA plotting is used to analyze deformities, which are often multiplanar with translational and rotational elements. The CORA represents the point in space between the mechanical axes of the deformed bone segments and illustrates the necessary osteotomy site for correction. It is important to note that CORA is based on 2D X-rays and does not account for rotation. While a uniplanar angular deformity's CORA is at the site of angulation, translation combined with angulation will place the CORA away from the apparent angulatory deformity.

The bisector is a line that bisects the CORA and the angle formed by the two mechanical axes creating the deformity. Any point along the bisector can serve as a CORA for correction. Osteotomies made further along the bisector from the CORA require larger openings for correction.

The general principles for correcting limb deformities follow an order: Angulation > Translation > Length > Rotation > +/- Translation. Correction of rotation can sometimes induce secondary translational deformities that require further correction. Soft tissue considerations are vital, as stretching on the concave side during correction can compromise neurovascular bundles. Osteotomies (opening or closing wedge, dome) should ideally be performed at or along the bisector of the CORA, though this is not always feasible.

Simple osteotomies with plate or IM nail fixation are suitable for uniplanar deformities where the CORA is at the deformity site. For multiplanar deformities or when length adjustment is needed, Ilizarov or Taylor Spatial Frames are preferred, avoiding multiple osteotomies and soft tissue violations. The principles of defining the deformity, CORA, and bisector remain consistent across these methods.

Segmental bone defects (SBDs) can result from high-energy trauma, chronic infection requiring debridement, or non-union with osteolysis. Management depends on defect size, location, and patient/surgeon factors. A critical size defect is generally considered 2 cm or more, or a loss of 50% of the bone's circumference. Options include amputation, acute shortening, autologous cancellous bone grafting, bone transport (distraction osteogenesis), Masqulet technique, free vascularized bone transfer, and local fibula grafting.

topic: Acute Shortening for Segmental Bone Defects
text: Acute shortening is better tolerated in the upper limb and single bone segments (humerus/femur) up to 5 cm. In the tibia, it may be acceptable for defects under 3 cm if the fibula is also comminuted. Advantages include immediate stability, initiation of healing, relaxation of soft tissues for closure/grafting, and a low complication rate. The primary drawback is limb length inequality, which may require future correction, and potential redundant skin if excessive shortening occurs.

Autologous cancellous bone graft remains the gold standard due to its osteoinductive, osteoconductive, and osteogenic properties. It is generally considered treatable for defects up to 5-7 cm. Iliac crest is the preferred donor site, with posterior crest offering better volume and anterior being easier to harvest. RIA (reamed irrigation aspirator) can yield higher quality and volumes of graft but raises concerns about iatrogenic fractures. While cancellous grafts are a reasonable, cheap option for smaller defects (<4cm) requiring no special expertise, they can lead to unpredictable and prolonged union times, with graft site morbidity. Grafting should ideally occur after 6 weeks to allow wound healing and soft tissue revascularization, combined with bone end freshening. The posterolateral approach is traditional for the tibia, laying the graft around the defect and on the interosseous membrane.

topic: Masqulet Technique (Induced Membranes) for Bone Defects
text: This technique is primarily used for defects with concurrent severe soft tissue injury. In Stage 1, a cement spacer is inserted after debridement, and soft tissue reconstruction is performed. A synovial-like membrane, rich in blood supply and growth factors, is theorized to form around the cement block. In Stage 2, the spacer is removed, and autologous cancellous graft is inserted into the membrane to augment healing. The efficacy of this technique lacks strong evidence, and disruption of the membrane during spacer removal is a concern.

topic: Distraction Osteogenesis (Bone Transport) for Bone Defects
text: Bone transport can manage intermediate to large defects (up to 30cm) and allows for soft tissue management and correction of malalignment using frames. Advantages include the potential for high-quality bone regeneration. However, problems include patient compliance, long treatment duration, and pin site infections causing chronic issues. Techniques include the Ilizarov frame (most common, allows alignment correction but can cause soft tissue problems), unilateral rail frames (less demanding but offer less alignment control), and lengthening over a nail (maintains alignment but nail may interfere with regenerate). Corticotomy should be metaphyseal, with a 5-day latent period before distraction begins at a maximum of 1mm per day, followed by a consolidation phase of at least equal duration to the distraction phase. Overall recommendations favor distraction using an Ilizarov frame if expertise is available, or a rail frame, with initial shortening followed by distraction.

This technique, most commonly using the fibula, can be used for very large defects and has a high success rate in post-traumatic defects. It requires leaving sufficient length at the harvest site to prevent ankle, knee, and peroneal nerve issues. Problems include donor site morbidity (chronic pain, neurogenic pain, instability), graft fracture if it fails to hypertrophy, and the need for an available artery for anastomosis. It demands considerable expertise, cost, and time.

topic: Local Fibula Graft for Bone Defects
text: A local fibula graft involves osteotomizing the fibula and fixing it to the tibia, either within or on the lateral aspect. Advantages include acute spanning of the defect and ease of performance. However, it offers poor muscle function, is not always possible, and the graft may be weak and at high fracture risk if it does not hypertrophy.

topic: Soft Tissue Management in Bone Reconstruction
text: Large soft tissue defects require emergent management, ideally with free flap transfer within one week before wound colonization. All bone reconstructive procedures have higher success rates in a healed soft tissue envelope.

For subchondral defects, grafts require high initial compressive strength and osteoconductivity. Osteogenesis and osteoinductivity are less critical because metaphyseal defects tend to heal spontaneously. The graft must provide stable articular reduction and prevent step-offs or gaps. Calcium phosphate cement is currently considered the best graft for this purpose, with Level 1 RCTs and meta-analyses showing it to be associated with better functional outcomes compared to autologous cancellous graft.

Future treatment possibilities include the use of bone morphogenic proteins (BMPs) and local scaffolds, as well as gene therapy. BMPs, when used with a structural allograft, have shown efficacy equal to cancellous autograft for tibial non-union in Level 1 RCTs.

Options for large diaphyseal defects include free fibula transfer, bone transport, or amputation. Free fibula transfer requires extensive resources and has a relatively high failure rate due to vascular anastomosis issues and graft site morbidity. Bone transport is considered the gold standard for limb salvage of large post-traumatic defects, though it requires patient compliance and carries risks of pin site infection, re-fracture, and non-union. Amputation is a viable option, offering the least complications and cost, and patients should be involved in this decision-making process.

topic: Principles of Ilizarov and Distraction Osteogenesis
text: The Ilizarov method and distraction osteogenesis are powerful techniques for correcting deformity, lengthening limbs, or stabilizing fractures. Key principles involve corticotomy, frame stabilization, a latent period of 7-10 days, distraction at a maximum of 1mm per day in three increments, serial X-ray monitoring of regenerate, and a consolidation phase at least as long as the distraction phase. Regenerate formation involves trabecular columns oriented parallel to the distraction direction, surrounded by blood vessels. Muscle tolerance allows up to 10% lengthening, with nerve and vascular changes generally being temporary.

Ilizarov fixator stability is determined by ring size and connecting bars, with complete rings being more rigid. Reducing ring size increases rigidity, and the smallest possible ring should be used, leaving 2 cm between the skin and the frame. Partial rings are useful around joints, and a minimum of two rings per bone segment is recommended, with intervening free rings for longer distances. Wires should be at a minimum 90-degree crossing angle, with thicker or olive-tip wires offering greater stiffness. Tensioning wires increases stiffness. HA-coated half pins offer better resistance to loosening and are beneficial for deformity correction where frames are in place for extended durations. The Taylor Spatial Frame is easier for deformity correction but can also be achieved with the Ilizarov.

topic: Amputations: Metabolic Cost and Soft Tissue Envelope
text: The metabolic cost of amputation increases with more proximal levels and is inversely proportional to the length of the stump or the number of functional joints. A good soft tissue envelope, ideally with a mobile muscle mass and full-thickness skin, is crucial for prosthesis fit, reducing shear stress, and preventing skin breakdown.

topic: Amputations: Load Transfer and Stump Healing Prerequisites
text: Load transfer to the prosthetic socket can be direct (end-bearing stumps like Syme's or through-knee) or indirect (total contact for long bone amputations). Indirect transfer requires specific joint flexion (10 degrees at the knee for trans-tibial, 10 degrees adduction/flexion at the hip for transfemoral). Prerequisites for stump healing include adequate nutrition, vascularity (ischaemic index minimum 0.5, transcutaneous oxygen >40 mmHg), and good blood oxygenation (Hb >10).

topic: Pediatric Amputations and Amputation After Trauma
text: Pediatric amputations are complicated by bony overgrowth within the stump due to open physes, often requiring revision. Amputation after trauma may offer better outcomes than limb salvage, with the MESS score being a consideration. For upper limb amputations, sensation and prehensile function are paramount, making salvage preferable if possible. Lower limb amputation considerations include plantar sensation loss, but caution is advised if it might be neuropraxia. Technical aspects include full-thickness skin flaps, avoiding dissection between tissue planes, stripping periosteum to minimize heterotopic bone, performing myodesis over myoplasty, securing muscles at resting length, and clean nerve cuts to minimize neuroma formation and phantom pain.

Complications of amputation include wound breakdown/infection, poor stump fitting, phantom pain, CRPS, and localized stump pain, often related to bone ends or neuromas. The energy cost of walking increases significantly with more proximal amputations, with transfemoral amputations requiring the most energy. Bilateral transtibial amputations also have a substantial energy cost.

topic: Soft Tissue Coverage and Microsurgery: Reconstructive Ladder
text: The reconstructive ladder for soft tissue coverage progresses from primary closure and secondary intention to split-thickness skin grafts (STSG), full-thickness skin grafts (FTSG), local flaps, and finally free flap coverage. Healing by secondary intention is not advised for wounds exposing tendon, nerve, or bone. Skin grafts rely on the wound bed for vascular supply; failure can result from shear stress or hematoma.

Split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs) are preferred for dorsal hand wounds, with meshing increasing surface area and preventing hematoma. Full-thickness skin grafts (FTSGs) offer a higher chance of viability, better re-innervation, improved cosmesis, and less scar contraction, making them suitable for palmar defects. Donor sites typically include the anterolateral thigh for STSGs and the volar wrist or forearm for FTSGs.

topic: Flap Classification and Donor Site Location
text: Flaps are tissue units with their own blood supply, transferred to a wound bed. They can be classified by tissue type (cutaneous, fasciocutaneous, musculocutaneous, osteocutaneous), blood supply pattern (axial or random), or donor site location (local or distant). Local flaps include transposition, rotation, advancement, axial flag, and fillet flaps. Distant flaps are used when local tissue is inadequate, such as a hand placed into a groin pouch. Free flaps are distant axial pattern flaps with microvascular anastomosis to local vasculature.

Specific flap choices depend on the defect location: VY advancement for volar fingertip defects, cross-finger or thenar flaps for volar proximal fingers,FDMA or Moberg advancement for volar thumb defects, and groin flaps for dorsal hand coverage. The choice also considers patient age and the need for optimal cosmetic and functional outcomes.

Indications for replantation include multiple digits, thumb amputations, any digit in a child, mid-palmar amputations, and proximal amputations where reimplantation offers better results than prosthetics. Single digits distal to the FDS insertion (flexor zone 1) are a relative indication. Contraindications include single digits proximal to the FDS (flexor zone 2), crush injuries, segmental amputations, and prolonged ischemic times.

topic: Care of Amputated Part and Ischemic Time
text: The amputated part should be placed in saline-soaked gauze within a plastic bag in an ice bath (transport at 4°C). Muscle-containing parts have shorter warm ischemic times (6 hours for hand, 12 hours proximal to the carpus) compared to cold ischemic times (12 hours for hand, 24 hours proximal to the carpus) due to muscle's sensitivity to ischemia.

topic: Order of Replantation and Hand Structures
text: For hand and digit replantation, the recommended order is digit, thumb, middle, ring, little, and index fingers, as this sequence maximizes functional hand recovery. Replantation involves reattaching bone, extensor tendon, flexor tendon, artery, nerve, vein, and skin.

Techniques include structure-by-structure or digit-by-digit replantation, or transpositional replantation where the most viable digit is moved to a more critical location. Prophylactic fasciotomies are standard for all patients. Post-operative management includes hydration, warmth, careful anticoagulation, avoiding vasopressors, and monitoring oxygen saturation and skin temperature. A drop in temperature or absolute low temperature indicates unsatisfactory perfusion.

Complications include early failure due to arterial thrombosis (managed with heparin, warmth, stellate ganglion blockade) and late failure due to venous thrombosis/congestion (treated with leeches or heparin-soaked gauze). Reperfusion injury can occur, managed with Allopurinol. Other complications include myonecrosis, renal failure, infection, hypersensitivity, and cold intolerance.

The best predictor of survival is the mechanism of injury (sharp being better than blunt), followed by ischemic time (optimal results with <8 hours). Digital replantation can achieve approximately 50% range of motion and 10 mm of 2-point discrimination.

topic: Forearm/Arm Replantation and Ring Avulsion Injuries
text: For forearm and arm replantation, establishing arterial flow first is prioritized to minimize warm ischemic time. Ring avulsion injuries are classified: Type 1 (NV viable) is treated as a soft tissue injury; Type 2 (vascular insufficiency) may be replanted if bone/tendon is intact; Type 3 (complete avulsion with exposed bone) requires amputation.

topic: Pediatric Cervical Spine Trauma: Anatomy and Development
text: Pediatric cervical spine injuries are understood through its unique anatomy, including synchondroses (cartilaginous joints) that function like growth plates. The C1-C3 segment is the primary fulcrum of rotation in children under 8 years old, shifting to C5-C6 in older children. This, along with increased ligamentous laxity and a disproportionately large and heavy head, contributes to a higher risk of cervical spine injury in children.

Cervical spine stability in children relies on the congruency of the superior articular facets with the occipital condyles, alar ligaments, joint capsule, and tectorial membrane for the atlanto-occipital region. For the atlanto-axial region, primary static stabilizers include the PPEG and transverse ligament, with secondary checks from the alar and apical ligaments.

topic: Modes of Injury in Pediatric Cervical Spine Trauma
text: Pediatric cervical spine injuries manifest as fractures, fracture-subluxations, subluxations, or SCIWORA (Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiologic Abnormality). Patterns vary with age: children over 8 years often present with adult-like subaxial injuries, while younger children (<8 years) are more prone to axial injuries, subluxations, and end-plate fractures due to their unique spinal biomechanics.

Pseudosubluxation, a common anatomical variant, typically occurs at the C2-C3 level in children under 8 years old. It is characterized by a step of no more than 1mm on the spinolaminar or Swischuk's line, differentiating it from true subluxation which may involve an endplate fracture.

Atlanto-occipital dissociation is a potentially unstable injury in children with a 50% mortality rate. Atlanto-axial AP instability is assessed by the Atlanto-Dental Interval (ADI), with >5mm in children <8 years or >3mm in children >8 years considered abnormal. The Space Available for the Cord (SAC) should be >13mm. Steel's rule of thirds describes the normal proportions of the cord, odontoid, and CSF in the upper cervical spine.

topic: SCIWORA (Spinal Cord Injury Without Radiologic Abnormality)
text: SCIWORA is a diagnosis of exclusion in pediatric cervical spine trauma, where neurological deficits exist without clear radiographic abnormalities. MRI is crucial for diagnosis, though it may be normal in up to 30% of symptomatic cases. The spinal column can stretch significantly, but the cord is injured after stretching more than 1 cm. Neurologic status at presentation is the main predictor of outcome.

topic: Management of Pediatric Cervical Spine Trauma
text: Management includes maintaining blood pressure, advanced imaging, spinal immobilization for 3 months, and activity restriction for an additional 3 months. Outcomes are poor if the injury is complete but reasonable if partial.

Odontoid fractures in children can occur through the synchondrosis and may have an intact periosteal sleeve. They typically result from sudden deceleration and flexion in RTA. Management involves immobilization in a HALO or Minerva brace for 3 months. HALO application requires caution in infants due to thin skulls and open sutures. Surgical stabilization is indicated for gross instability, inability to reduce closed, or neurological deficit requiring decompression.

Triplane ankle fractures are distal tibia epiphyseal fractures that involve coronal, sagittal, and axial planes, primarily affecting adolescents due to irregular physeal closure. They are typically caused by external rotation injuries and are associated with fibula fractures in 50% of cases. Diagnosis relies on AP, lateral, mortise X-rays, and essential CT scans for surgical planning. The fracture can be 2, 3, or 4-part, with 2-part fractures being most common. Management is typically operative for displacements greater than 2mm or joint instability, especially in skeletally immature patients with significant growth remaining. Surgical fixation aims for anatomical reduction and stability, avoiding crossing the physis unless the patient is near skeletal maturity.

topic: Paediatric Supracondylar Fracture of the Humerus
text: Supracondylar fractures of the humerus in children commonly involve nerve palsies: ulnar nerve for flexion-type fractures and anterior interosseous nerve for extension-type fractures. Any nerve can be injured, necessitating clear pre-operative documentation. Nerve injury increases the risk of compartment syndrome. Vascular compromise, indicated by a pulseless but perfused hand, requires immediate theatre intervention. Indications for an anterior approach include pulselessness and pallor, with a transverse or 'boat race' incision. Compartment syndrome is a significant risk, especially with median nerve palsy. If a pulse is lost after reduction, exploration is mandatory to rule out arterial incarceration or kinking. Persistent suspicion of compartment syndrome warrants observation with the arm out of plaster and elevated.

topic: Pinning Patterns for Supracondylar Humerus Fractures
text: Lateral pinning with two or three wires is often sufficient, especially for oblique fractures. Medial pinning is reserved for unstable fractures or those with medial comminution risking varus. Cross wires provide stronger biomechanical configuration. The high lateral wire should be avoided due to radial nerve risk. Assessment of reduction includes maintaining Bauman's angle and the anterior humeral line intersecting the capitellum. Cubitus varus malunion results from fixation in varus, not growth arrest, and has limited remodeling potential.

Cubitus varus malunion can occur due to fixation in varus alignment, not growth disturbance. While the distal humerus has limited remodeling potential, cubitus varus can lead to issues like increased lateral condyle fractures, tardy ulnar nerve palsy, posterolateral instability in adulthood, premature elbow arthritis, and cosmetic dissatisfaction. Correction is typically achieved with a lateral closing wedge osteotomy.

Physeal bars, or bony bridges, form when there is direct contact between the metaphysis and epiphysis, most commonly due to trauma or surgical intervention (e.g., pin placement). The distal femur is most susceptible due to its wavy shape. Growth arrest occurs in about 10% of physeal fractures, more commonly in Type 4 and 5 fractures, but is often not clinically significant in adolescents due to limited remaining growth. Bars typically begin forming around 6 weeks post-injury and can take time to become clinically apparent. X-ray evaluation includes angular deformity, visible bars, and asymmetry of Harris growth recovery lines. CT or MRI is vital for precise bar mapping.

Factors influencing the decision to resect a physeal bar include the aetiology (trauma yields better results than infection), the affected physis and its growth contribution, patient age and remaining growth potential, bar size (maximum 50% cross-section), and bar location (peripheral bars causing angular deformity should be resected, while central bars may cause length discrepancy but not necessarily deformity). Resection is generally recommended for children with at least 2 cm of growth remaining and bars ideally <25% or maximally 50%.

topic: Alternative Options to Physeal Bar Resection
text: Alternatives to bar resection include epiphysiodesis (in older children to prevent angular deformity), osteotomy (to correct existing angulation, often combined with resection), limb lengthening (at skeletal maturity if the bar is irresectable or fails), and delayed hemiepiphysiodesis (opposite the bar to correct angulation once growth is re-established). Resection techniques involve osteotomy or a metaphyseal window, with the resected space filled with an interposition graft (fat or PMMA). Corrective osteotomy may be performed if significant, non-recoverable angular deformity is present.

topic: Pediatric Hip: Femoral Head Blood Supply
text: The blood supply to the pediatric femoral head changes with skeletal maturity. From birth to 4 years, metaphyseal vessels are dominant. Between 4-7 years, the Lateral Epiphyseal Artery (LEA) becomes the sole supply. After 7 years, the LEA remains dominant (80%), with the ligamentum teres contributing 20%. In adults, the LEA, metaphyseal vessels, and ligamentum teres vessels all contribute.

DDH is a developmental condition occurring after birth, affecting 1 in 1000 live births, predominantly in females (80%) and often involving the left hip (60%). Risk factors include genetic predisposition, intrauterine crowding (breech presentation, oligohydramnios, twins), and neuromuscular conditions. Pathophysiology involves a shallow acetabulum and femoral anteversion, leading to abnormal enclavement of the femoral head. Clinical diagnosis relies on leg length assessment, range of motion, and specific tests like Barlow's and Ortolani's. Imaging includes ultrasound (for infants <4 months) and X-rays (once the femoral head ossifies), assessing parameters like Graf angles, Perkins line, Shenton's line, acetabular index, and Center Edge (CE) angle.

topic: Management of Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)
text: Treatment depends on the child's age at diagnosis. For infants 0-4 months with a reducible hip, the Pavlik harness is the first-line treatment. For irreducible hips, failed closed treatment, or very narrow safe zones, open reduction with or without adductor tenotomy and hip spica casting is performed. For older children (4 months to 8 years), open reduction and spica casting are primary, often requiring femoral or pelvic osteotomies if reduction is under tension or the dysplasia is severe. After 8 years, remodelling potential is poor, and surgery is generally reserved for salvage procedures or specific indications.

Pelvic osteotomies are used to improve acetabular coverage. Options include the Salter (redirectional, hinges on pubic symphysis), Pemberton (volume-reducing, pivots near triradiate cartilage), Dega (volume-reducing, better for paralytic conditions), Ganz periacetabular (redirectional, close to the cup), Chiari (salvage, volume-increasing), and shelf procedures (salvage, augments acetabulum). The choice depends on the child's age, the degree of dysplasia, and surgical goals.

SCFE is an endocrine-related condition occurring in adolescence, characterized by the anterior displacement of the femoral neck on the femoral head through the hypertrophic zone of the physis. It is more common in boys, obese children, and often bilateral. Classification is based on stability (stable vs. unstable) and chronicity (acute, acute-on-chronic, chronic). The Southwick angle quantifies slip severity. Radiographic signs include a widened, hazy physis, Klein's line overlap, Steel's blanch sign, and Trethowan's sign. Management goals are to prevent slip progression and avoid complications. Stable SCFE is typically treated with in situ pinning, while unstable SCFE requires urgent fixation, often with in situ pinning, or sometimes surgical dislocation and reduction.

Complications of SCFE include chondrolysis (due to screw/wire penetration), fracture, avascular necrosis (AVN, especially in unstable slips or aggressive reduction), and CAM impingement leading to early osteoarthritis. After treatment, patients are kept non-weight bearing for 6-12 weeks and followed until skeletal maturity to monitor for contralateral SCFE. Late AVN can occur up to a year after initial treatment.

Perthes disease is idiopathic avascular necrosis (AVN) of the proximal femoral epiphysis, typically affecting boys aged 4-8 years. It presents with a limp, hip or knee pain, and stiffness. Diagnosis is usually made via X-ray, though MRI can detect early changes. Stages include necrotic, fragmentation, re-ossification, and remodelling. The Herring's Lateral Pillar Classification is the best prognostic indicator. 'At Risk' signs like Gage sign, horizontal physis, lateral subluxation, calcification lateral to the physis, and metaphyseal cysts correlate with worse outcomes. Management aims to prevent femoral head deformation by preventing lateral extrusion and maintaining containment. Treatment depends on age and extrusion, with older children (>8 years) and those with extrusion generally requiring surgical containment via femoral or pelvic osteotomies.

Developmental coxa vara is characterized by a neck-shaft angle less than 120 degrees, often presenting in children aged 1-5 years with a Trendelenburg gait. It results from an ossification defect in the inferomedial proximal femoral physis. The 'inverted Y' sign on X-ray is pathognomonic. Management is guided by the Hilgenreiner's Epiphyseal Angle (HEA); angles less than 45 degrees usually correct spontaneously, 45-60 degrees require observation, and >60 degrees necessitates surgical correction, typically with a Pawlows Y-shaped osteotomy to place the physis under compression.

Talipes equinovarus, or clubfoot, is a complex deformity affecting the ankle, subtalar, and midtarsal joints, often with bony deformity of the talus and calcaneus. It can be idiopathic, neuromuscular, or teratologic. The Pirani score assesses severity based on anatomical features. Management principles prioritize conservative treatment with the Ponseti method (serial casting and Achilles tenotomy), followed by bracing. Surgical intervention, such as soft tissue release or tendon transfers, is reserved for resistant cases or specific deformities. Severe, stiff deformities may require Ilizarov fixation or triple fusion.

Pes cavus, an excessively high-arched foot, is most commonly associated with neurological conditions like Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. The primary driving force is often a plantarflexed first ray, leading to a varus hindfoot and contracted plantar fascia. Management depends on the underlying cause and foot flexibility; it ranges from accommodative footwear and plantar fascia release to osteotomies, tendon transfers, and triple fusion for stiff, symptomatic feet. Recurrence is common, especially with neurological involvement.

Metatarsus adductus is the forefoot adduction with a normal hindfoot, occurring in about 12% of newborns. It is often associated with DDH and is frequently correctable with passive stretching or serial casting in younger children. Surgery, involving osteotomies to lengthen the medial column or shorten the lateral column, is reserved for older children (>7 years) with stiff deformities.

Skewfoot is a complex, uncommon condition characterized by forefoot adduction and hindfoot valgus, often a packaging disorder. While most cases are asymptomatic, symptomatic deformities require combination osteotomies (medial sliding calcaneal osteotomy for valgus, lateral shortening or medial column lengthening for adduction) which are technically demanding.

topic: Pediatric Foot Disorders: Pes Calcaneovalgus and Congenital Vertical Talus
text: Pes calcaneovalgus is a packaging deformity where the calcaneus is severely dorsiflexed and the foot is in valgus. It is typically passively correctable and resolves spontaneously. Congenital Vertical Talus (CVT) is a more severe condition with an irreducible talonavicular dislocation, resulting in a rigid, rocker-bottom foot. It is often associated with other congenital abnormalities and requires surgical correction, potentially including talectomy or triple fusion.

Pes planovalgus, or flatfoot, is common and often idiopathic, related to generalized ligamentous laxity. While the medial arch is normally flat at birth and develops by age 7, symptomatic cases may present with heel valgus and loss of the longitudinal arch during weight-bearing. Flexible cases are managed conservatively with orthoses and Achilles stretching. Surgery is rarely indicated. A negative Meary's angle on X-ray indicates pes planovalgus.

Tarsal coalition is a failure of mesenchymal differentiation of peritalar joints, resulting in a fibro-osseus bar. It occurs in about 1% of the population, often bilateral and associated with multiple coalitions. The calcaneonavicular coalition is most common, followed by the talocalcaneal. Presentation is typically between 8-15 years with recurrent ankle sprains and difficulty on uneven ground. Management involves conservative measures or surgery (resection or fusion), depending on the coalition type, extent, and presence of arthritis. The 'Anteater sign' is indicative of calcaneonavicular coalition, and the 'C-sign' for talocalcaneal coalition.

topic: Pediatric Foot Disorders: Kohler's Disease and Curly Toes
text: Kohler's disease is idiopathic AVN of the navicular, usually in boys aged 7-15, causing pain and limp. It typically resolves spontaneously within 18 months with restricted weight-bearing. Curly toes are caused by contracture of the flexor digitorum longus or brevis and are best treated with FDL tenotomy around age 3 if symptomatic.

topic: Pediatric Foot Disorders: Polydactyly, Congenital Hallux Varus, and Overlapping Toes
text: Polydactyly involves extra toes, usually on the lateral side, often associated with congenital hallux varus. The most lateral toe is typically ablated around 9-12 months. Congenital hallux varus may require release of the adductor hallucis longus and osteotomy. Overlapping toes, commonly the fifth on the fourth, may cause footwear issues and can be managed with stretching, syndactilisation, or tenotomy.

topic: Pediatric Foot Disorders: Accessory Navicular, Habitual Toe Walking, Ball and Socket Ankle
text: Accessory naviculars are often asymptomatic and may fuse with growth; symptomatic ones can be excised. Habitual toe walking is usually due to a tight Achilles tendon and often resolves spontaneously, though casting or lengthening may be needed. A ball and socket ankle is a compensatory mechanism for rigidity elsewhere, often associated with tarsal coalition or absence of lateral rays.

topic: Pediatric Foot Disorders: Juvenile Bunions and Apophysitis
text: Juvenile bunions are more common in girls and are best managed conservatively with accommodative footwear, as surgery has a high recurrence rate due to growth. Iselin's disease affects the 5th metatarsal base, and Sever's disease affects the calcaneal apophysis, both traction apophysitis conditions managed non-operatively with restricted weight-bearing.

topic: Pediatric Spine: Scoliosis Classification and Epidemiology
text: Scoliosis is defined as a coronal plane deformity >10 degrees (Cobb angle) without a identifiable cause (idiopathic) or due to neuromuscular conditions, congenital vertebral anomalies, or other syndromes. Idiopathic scoliosis is classified by age of onset: infantile (0-3 yrs), juvenile (4-10 yrs), and adolescent (>10 yrs). Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (AIS) is the most common, predominantly affecting girls, with right thoracic curves being most frequent. Early onset AIS (juvenile) and infantile idiopathic scoliosis have a higher incidence of underlying neural abnormalities, necessitating MRI screening.

topic: Idiopathic Scoliosis: Risk Factors and Progression
text: Risk factors for curve progression in idiopathic scoliosis include curve magnitude, Risser sign (immaturity), and Rib-Vertebra Angle Difference (RVAD). Curves greater than 25 degrees in skeletally immature patients, or those with an RVAD greater than 20 degrees, have a higher propensity to progress. Infantile idiopathic scoliosis has a high spontaneous resolution rate, but progressive curves require vigilant monitoring and potential intervention.

topic: Clinical and Radiographic Evaluation of Scoliosis
text: Clinical assessment involves checking for asymmetry in shoulders, leg lengths, pelvic tilt, and rib prominence. Radiographic evaluation includes standing AP and lateral X-rays of the entire spine, along with bending films to assess curve flexibility. MRI is indicated for any neurological findings, unusual curve patterns, or infantile/juvenile scoliosis. Skeletal maturity is assessed using Risser sign, Tanner stages, and triradiate cartilage closure.

Management goals for AIS are to prevent progression, correct deformity, and improve spinal balance and cosmesis. Bracing is used for curves between 25-40 degrees to slow progression. Spinal fusion with instrumentation is recommended for curves greater than 40-50 degrees, as these curves tend to progress into adulthood and can lead to cardiopulmonary compromise and chronic back pain. Posterior spinal fusion is the primary surgical approach, with anterior instrumentation added for severe, stiff curves or in younger patients to prevent the 'crankshaft phenomenon'. Growing rods may be used in younger children with significant remaining growth.

Complications of scoliosis surgery can include the crankshaft phenomenon, neurologic injury (rare), curve progression, pseudoarthrosis, pancreatitis, superior mesenteric artery occlusion, and thromboembolism.

Congenital scoliosis results from failures in vertebral formation (hemivertebra, wedge vertebra), segmentation (unilateral or complete bars), or a combination of both. These malformations lead to uneven spinal growth, causing the curvature. Associations with other congenital anomalies, such as VATER/VACTERL syndrome, and intraspinal anomalies like diastematomyelia or tethered cord, are common and necessitate thorough workup.

Non-operative management, such as bracing, has no place in congenital scoliosis due to the fixed nature of the bony deformities. Observation is reserved for low-risk curves or mild deformities. Operative management typically involves posterior instrumented fusion in situ, often augmented with anterior fusion for younger patients, large curves, or those at risk of crankshaft deformity. Other options include hemiepiphysiodesis or excision of the causative bony bar or hemivertebra.

Neuromuscular scoliosis requires individualized treatment aims, generally focusing on maintaining sitting balance, preventing curve progression, and avoiding thoracic complications. Non-surgical bracing may be suitable for smaller, less aggressive curves with minimal progression. Posterior instrumented fusion is common, often extending to the pelvis, and may require anterior fusion in young patients with severe deformities. Adequate nutrition is crucial pre-operatively due to a higher risk of infection.

Scheuermann's kyphosis is defined by a thoracic kyphosis greater than 45 degrees with anterior wedging of at least three consecutive vertebrae by more than 5 degrees. It is thought to result from a developmental error in collagen causing disturbed endochondral ossification of the endplates. While most commonly thoracic, it can occur in the lumbar spine, often presenting with increased pain and stiffness but rarely neurological compromise.

Non-operative management, such as bracing, may be considered for patients near skeletal maturity with less severe kyphosis and minimal pain. Operative intervention is indicated for kyphosis exceeding 75 degrees, progressive curves in younger patients, significant pain, or rare neurological deficits. Surgery typically involves posterior instrumented fusion with osteotomies, and anterior release may be needed for curves over 90 degrees.

Congenital kyphosis can result from failures of formation, segmentation, or a mix of both vertebral anomalies. Type 1 (failure of formation) carries the highest risk of progression and neurological injury, often resulting in a severe, acute kyphosis. A high association (over 50%) with neural anomalies necessitates thorough workup including MRI. Management involves observation for Type 2 curves, while operative intervention is indicated for neurological deficits, progressive curves, or curves exceeding 50 degrees in young children.

The spine is commonly affected in neurofibromatosis, manifesting as kyphoscoliosis. Dystrophic forms are more aggressive, with vertebral scalloping, tight acute curves, foraminal widening, and pencil-like transverse processes. Intraspinal anomalies are frequent, requiring MRI before intervention. Management principles are similar to idiopathic scoliosis but are more aggressive for the dystrophic type, with a higher rate of pseudoarthrosis post-surgery.

topic: Spondylolisthesis Classification and Risk of Progression
text: Spondylolisthesis is classified by Wiltse into types based on aetiology (dysplastic, isthmic, degenerate, etc.) and by Myerding into grades (1-5) based on the percentage of slippage. High-grade slips (3-4), dysplastic types, female gender, and significant lumbosacral kyphosis are risk factors for progression. Non-operative management with bracing is indicated for low-grade symptomatic cases, while operative intervention is considered for high-grade slips, progression, intractable pain, or neurological compromise.

Diastematomyelia is a congenital condition where a fibrous or osseous bar splits the spinal cord longitudinally, most often in the lumbar spine. This can cause cord tethering and is associated with scoliosis and kyphosis. XR may show interpedicular widening, and MRI confirms the diagnosis. Excision of the bar is recommended prior to correcting any associated spinal deformity, though asymptomatic cases may be observed.

Sacral agenesis involves the absence of the sacrum and lower lumbar spine, often associated with maternal diabetes. Affected individuals present with a prominent lumbar spine and typically sit in a 'Buddha' position. Management options include amputation or spinal-pelvic fusion.

topic: Paediatric Cervical Spine Abnormalities: Atlantoaxial Instability
text: Atlantoaxial instability can be AP or rotatory, often associated with syndromes like Down's or Morquio's. Instability is suspected with an ADI >5mm (adults >4mm) or a SAC <13mm. Basilar invagination, where the odontoid migrates proximally through the foramen magnum, is highly correlated with neurological deficit and requires operative stabilization. Management aims to prevent or stabilize neurological symptoms.

Klippel-Feil syndrome is characterized by the failure of segmentation of the cervical spine, leading to classic features of a stiff neck, low hairline, and webbed neck, although these are present in less than 50% of cases. It is associated with congenital scoliosis, Sprengel's shoulder, renal disease, and cardiac anomalies. Management is usually supportive, but cervical decompression and stabilization may be needed for myelopathy.

Os odontoidum is a failure of the odontoid ossification centers to fuse, resulting in a separate ossicle at the C1-C2 joint. This leads to atlantoaxial instability, potentially causing neurological symptoms, an increased ADI, and reduced SAC. Treatment involves C1-3 fusion.

topic: Intervertebral Disc Calcification and Down's Syndrome in Paediatric Spine
text: Intervertebral disc calcification is an idiopathic, self-limiting condition in children causing neck pain and reduced ROM. Down's syndrome (Trisomy 21) can be associated with atlantoaxial and atlanto-occipital instability; screening and treatment are indicated for symptomatic or severely unstable cases. Management is generally symptomatic, but surgical fusion may be necessary.

topic: Morquio's Syndrome and Torticollis in Paediatric Spine
text: Morquio's syndrome, a mucopolysaccharidosis, has a 100% incidence of atlantoaxial instability due to odontoid hypoplasia, with a higher risk of cord injury than in Down's syndrome, often requiring stabilization. Torticollis, a head tilt with chin rotation, can be acute (muscle spasm, usually self-limiting) or congenital (due to occipitocervical anomalies). Muscular torticollis, the most common orthopaedic cause, results from sternocleidomastoid (SCM) contracture and is treated with physiotherapy or SCM release.

topic: Cerebral Palsy (CP) Classification and Functional Estimation
text: Cerebral Palsy (CP) is a non-progressive brain injury causing neuromuscular imbalance. It's classified by type (spastic, athetoid, ataxic), geographical involvement (quadriplegia, diplegia, hemiparesis), and functional level using the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS). Poor prognostic factors for future function include the presence of primitive reflexes after one year and inability to sit by five or walk by eight.

Orthopaedic management of CP involves a multidisciplinary approach, often deferring surgery until after age three. Treatment progresses from physiotherapy and splinting to medications like baclofen or Botox, and surgical interventions such as soft tissue releases, tendon transfers, osteotomies, and fusions. Common issues addressed include scoliosis (requiring long fusions, often to the pelvis), hip subluxation/dislocation (managed with conservative measures or surgery depending on migration), and foot deformities (planovalgus or equinovarus).

Myelodysplasia (Spina Bifida) is a congenital condition of the spinal cord and column, often associated with hydrocephalus, Arnold-Chiari malformation, tethered cord, and latex allergy. Management is multidisciplinary, addressing neurosurgical (defect closure, shunting) and orthopaedic issues. Orthopaedic goals include managing spinal deformities (scoliosis, kyphosis) with fusions, hip dislocations (often non-operative due to risks), knee and foot deformities, and ensuring a plantigrade, braceable foot.

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder causing progressive muscle weakness, typically leading to inability to walk by 10 and death by 20 from cardiorespiratory failure. Becker Muscular Dystrophy is a less severe X-linked recessive form with reduced, but not absent, dystrophin. Orthopaedic management for DMD focuses on maximizing ambulation, including physiotherapy, steroids, and surgery for scoliosis and contractures, though surgical risks are high. Fascioscapulohumeral Dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting facial muscles and shoulder girdle weakness, with potential for scapulothoracic fusion if symptomatic.

topic: Other Neuromuscular Conditions: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita
text: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita (AMC) is a non-progressive disorder characterized by multiple joint contractures, often affecting the upper limbs (shoulder adduction/internal rotation, elbow extension) and feet (rigid clubfoot, vertical talus). Management involves early physiotherapy, serial casting, and surgical releases or fusions to achieve functional outcomes, aiming for a plantigrade, shoeable foot and improved upper limb function.

topic: Other Neuromuscular Conditions: Larsen's Syndrome and Freidrich's Ataxia
text: Larsen's syndrome involves congenital joint dislocations, particularly affecting the hips, knees, and radial heads, often with cervical spine kyphosis and potential neurological compromise. Freidreich's Ataxia is an autosomal recessive spinocerebellar disorder leading to progressive ataxia, cardiomyopathy, and foot deformities (cavovarus, equinovarus) requiring fusions and scoliosis management.

topic: Other Neuromuscular Conditions: Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) and Polio
text: Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive disorder causing progressive weakness due to anterior horn cell loss. SMA types vary in severity and life expectancy. Orthopaedic management focuses on hip dislocations (often non-operative), scoliosis (requiring aggressive, long fusions), and foot deformities. Polio, a viral infection causing anterior horn cell loss, typically results in unilateral weakness and limb shortening, with management aimed at achieving a plantigrade, braceable foot.

HMSN, including Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, involves progressive distal motor and sensory deficits. HMSN Type 1 involves demyelination, while Type 2 involves axonal degeneration. Both typically cause cavovarus foot deformities and scoliosis, with management aiming to preserve flexibility through transfers and osteotomies, avoiding fusion where possible. HMSN Type 3 (Dejerine-Sottas) is a more severe infantile form. Guillain-Barré syndrome is an acute, self-limiting polyneuropathy.

Fibula hemimelia is the most common limb deficiency, characterized by partial or complete absence of the fibula, often associated with other limb deformities, including hip and knee issues, and ankle valgus. Management is dictated by the overall limb and foot function, with a decision between reconstructive surgery or amputation (especially if >3 foot rays are absent) typically made by age three. Knee preservation is prioritized for prosthetic fitting.

topic: Limb Deficiencies: Proximal Femoral Focal Deficiency (PFFD)
text: PFFD represents a spectrum of femoral shortening, from congenital shortening of the femur (CSF) to complete absence of the proximal femur. It's often associated with other deficiencies, particularly fibula hemimelia. Management is either reconstructive or ablative, based on hip stability, lower leg function, bone deficiencies, and knee/ankle stability. Surgery is typically delayed until ages 2-3, with options including lengthening, knee fusion with foot ablation, rotationplasty, or femoro-pelvic fusion.

Tibial hemimelia is less common than fibula hemimelia and often associated with other anomalies, including pre-axial polydactyly and equinovarus foot deformities. Management depends on knee extension and dictates whether reconstruction or prosthesis is used after foot ablation. The primary aim is to achieve a functional, braceable foot.

Femoral torsion refers to the normal anteversion of the femur, which decreases from approximately 40 degrees at birth to 10-15 degrees by skeletal maturity. Significant anteversion (>70 degrees IR, <10 degrees ER in an older child) can cause in-toeing, awkward gait, or anterior knee pain (miserable malalignment syndrome). Management is usually conservative, with surgical rotational osteotomy considered for symptomatic older children or those with significant psychological distress.

Tibial torsion is assessed by the thigh-foot angle, with normal external torsion increasing from birth. Internal tibial torsion is the most common cause of in-toeing and is often a packaging disorder, resolving spontaneously. Surgery (supramalleolar osteotomy) is reserved for symptomatic children over 10 years old. External tibial torsion can be compensatory for femoral anteversion.

Metatarsus adductus is forefoot adduction with a normal hindfoot, seen in about 12% of newborns and often associated with DDH. Most cases resolve spontaneously by age 4. Flexible deformities are managed with stretching, while stiffer cases in younger children may benefit from serial casting. Surgery (medial column lengthening or lateral column shortening osteotomies) is for older children (>7 years) with stiff deformities.

Skewfoot is a complex condition with forefoot adduction and hindfoot valgus, typically a packaging disorder. Symptomatic cases are rare and difficult to treat non-operatively, often requiring combination osteotomies to correct both components.

topic: Paediatric Rotational Abnormalities: Examination of Lower Limb Deformities
text: Examination of paediatric lower limb angular deformities involves assessing overall appearance (height, weight, scars, bowing), gait (limp, thrust, compensatory mechanisms), palpation (pelvic tilt, correctability of deformities), and range of motion. Full standing X-rays and CT scanograms are crucial for accurate assessment and planning, alongside a family history.

topic: Paediatric Lower Limb Deformities: Genu Varum and Blount's Disease
text: Genu varum in children can be physiologic or pathological, with Blount's disease being the most common pathological cause. Blount's disease involves progressive varus and internal rotation deformity due to overload on the medial tibial physis, classified by Langenskold. Management aims to restore the mechanical axis, with non-operative treatment for mild cases and operative correction (osteotomy, physeal bar resection) for progressive or severe deformities. Physiologic bowing typically resolves spontaneously and is milder than Blount's disease.

topic: Paediatric Lower Limb Deformities: Genu Valgum
text: Genu valgum can be physiologic up to age 7, with abnormal findings including valgus >15 degrees, progressive valgus, or intermalleolar distance >10cm. Causes include obesity, trauma (Cozen's fracture), rickets, and skeletal dysplasias like MED. Management depends on the cause and severity, ranging from observation to guided growth (tethering of the lateral physis) or hemiepiphysiodesis, with osteotomy for older children or severe deformities.

topic: Paediatric Lower Limb Deformities: Tibial Bowing
text: Tibial bowing can be posteromedial (often physiologic due to intrauterine packaging) or anterolateral, which is strongly associated with congenital pseudoarthrosis of the tibia (CPT) and may require bracing or surgical intervention. Posteromedial bowing is usually self-limiting, though leg length discrepancy may require correction. Anterolateral bowing with pseudoarthrosis is a challenging condition often associated with NF1, managed with IM nailing, Ilizarov fixation, vascularized fibula transfer, or amputation.

topic: Paediatric Upper Limb Conditions: Brachial Plexus Birth Palsy
text: Brachial Plexus Birth Palsy (BPBP) results from traction injury to the brachial plexus during birth. Erb's palsy (C5/6) is most common with the best prognosis, while Klumpke's (C8/T1) and total plexus injuries have poorer outcomes. Poor prognostic factors include pre-ganglionic injury and lack of biceps recovery by 5-6 months. Management involves observation for recovery, ROM exercises, and surgical options like nerve grafting or tendon transfers for persistent deficits. Paralytic posterior shoulder dislocation can occur with severe cases, potentially requiring shoulder fusion.

topic: Paediatric Upper Limb Conditions: Congenital Pseudoarthrosis of the Clavicle
text: Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the clavicle results from failure of ossification centers to unite, presenting as a firm mass. Unlike tibial pseudoarthrosis, it rarely causes functional deficit or pain. Surgical excision of the pseudoarthrosis with ORIF and bone grafting has high union rates and is considered if appearance or function is compromised.

topic: Paediatric Upper Limb Conditions: Sprengel's Deformity
text: Sprengel's deformity is a developmental disorder causing incomplete descent of the scapula, leading to hypoplastic shoulder musculature and dysfunction, particularly in abduction. It is associated with scoliosis, Klippel-Feil syndrome, and omovertebral bars (which require excision). Management involves non-operative observation for mild cases or the Woodward procedure (scapulothoracic release, omovertebral bar excision, and scapular translation) for most patients, often with clavicle osteotomy to prevent brachial plexus neuropraxia.

topic: Paediatric Upper Limb Conditions: Congenital Synostosis of the Forearm
text: Congenital synostosis of the forearm is a failure of differentiation of the forearm bones, usually resulting in a fixed pronation deformity. It can be isolated or associated with other developmental anomalies. Surgery, such as rotational osteotomy, is rarely indicated and has a high complication rate.

topic: Paediatric Upper Limb Conditions: Trigger Finger/Thumb
text: Trigger thumb is more common than trigger digits in children, presenting with painful triggering and a palpable nodule. Conservative management involves observation until age one, as spontaneous resolution can occur. Surgical release of the A1 pulley is indicated for persistent or painful cases, with care taken to avoid the digital nerve.

Congenital dislocation of the knee is a rare disorder, often associated with breech presentation or ACL deficiency. Management usually involves closed reduction and serial casting. Congenital dislocation of the patella is less common and presents with knee hyperextension and a laterally displaced patella, requiring surgical correction involving soft tissue releases and retinacular repair.

Congenital radial head dislocation, most commonly anterior, is often associated with other anomalies like achondroplasia or Nail Patella Syndrome. It is usually an incidental finding, but may cause pain or reduced ROM in adolescence. Surgical options like radial head excision (after skeletal maturity) or annular ligament reconstruction are considered for symptomatic cases, often requiring equalization of forearm bone lengths.

Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21) is the most common chromosomal disorder, associated with hypotonia, mental retardation, heart disease, and various orthopaedic manifestations. These include atlantoaxial instability (requiring screening and potential fusion), scoliosis, spondylolisthesis, hip dislocation, and foot deformities. Management focuses on addressing these specific orthopaedic issues, particularly spinal instability.

topic: Chromosomal & Teratologic Disorders: Turner's and Noonan's Syndromes
text: Turner's syndrome (45, XO) in females presents with short stature, hypogonadism, webbed neck, cubitus valgum, and scoliosis. Noonan syndrome shares similar features but has normal sexual development and more severe scoliosis. Prader-Willi syndrome involves hypotonia, obesity, and intellectual impairment, with juvenile scoliosis being an orthopaedic concern. Rett's syndrome causes progressive spasticity and abnormal hand movements, while Beckwith-Wiedman syndrome features organomegaly and potential scoliosis or hemihypertrophy.

topic: Chromosomal & Teratologic Disorders: Nail Patella Syndrome
text: Nail Patella Syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder with four cardinal features: dysplastic nails, hypoplastic or absent patellae, conical iliac horns, and dysplastic radial heads. It can lead to future complications like radial head dislocation, elbow arthritis, anterior knee pain, and autoimmune nephropathy, requiring periodic screening for renal involvement and management of symptomatic orthopaedic issues.

Gaucher's disease is an AR lysosomal storage disorder causing accumulation of cerebroside, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and orthopaedic manifestations. These include bone pain (Gaucher crisis), expanded metaphyses, osteopenia, and AVN of the femoral head, which can mimic Perthes disease. Management focuses on treating symptoms and addressing bone complications.

Leukemia is the most common childhood malignancy, often presenting with musculoskeletal pain and bone changes like periostitis and lytic lesions. Thalassaemia, an AR disorder, can cause bone pain, leg ulcers, metaphyseal expansion, and premature physeal closure, with skeletal manifestations similar to sickle cell disease.

Sickle Cell Disease (SCD) is an autosomal recessive disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), leading to vaso-occlusive crises, AVN of the femoral head, osteomyelitis, and characteristic fish vertebrae. Sickle cell crises, triggered by stress or trauma, cause severe bone pain due to infarction. Pre-operative screening, oxygenation, and hydroxyurea are key management strategies. Differentiating infection from a sickle cell crisis can be challenging, requiring culture of aspirates.

Paediatric acute osteomyelitis is typically haematogenous, originating in the metaphysis and spreading to the subperiosteal space or joint. Staph aureus is the most common pathogen. Diagnosis involves clinical assessment, blood tests (CRP, ESR), imaging (XR, bone scan, MRI), and aspiration. Management includes antibiotics, with surgical drainage indicated for subperiosteal abscesses or failure to improve. Brodie's abscess is a subacute form often requiring surgical intervention.

Septic arthritis is more common than osteomyelitis in children, particularly in those under 5 years old. Infection can occur via haematogenous seeding, contiguous spread, or direct inoculation. Rapid degradation of articular cartilage occurs within 8 hours. Diagnosis relies on clinical suspicion (toxicity, pain, joint effusion) and joint aspiration, supported by inflammatory markers and imaging. Management involves prompt joint aspiration and irrigation (arthrotomy), along with antibiotics.

topic: Osteoarticular Infection: Neonatal and Special Situations
text: Neonatal infections are more aggressive due to the immature immune system. Shoe-puncture wounds typically involve Pseudomonas and Staph aureus. Kingella kingae is an emerging pathogen causing osteomyelitis with negative cultures. Discitis and vertebral osteomyelitis are usually treated with antibiotics, with biopsy reserved for non-responsive cases. Sickle cell disease significantly increases the risk of osteomyelitis and septic arthritis due to bone infarcts and impaired immunity.

topic: Osteoarticular Infection: Tuberculosis and Lyme Disease
text: Tuberculosis can affect the spine (most common skeletal site), hip, knee, and long bones, presenting with cold bone scans, mild inflammatory markers, and diagnostic biopsies. Management involves antibiotics and surgical intervention for abscesses or instability. Lyme disease causes arthritis, typically affecting the knee, with diagnosis confirmed by Lyme assays and treatment with antibiotics.

topic: Osteoarticular Infection: Chronic Recurrent Multifocal Osteomyelitis (CRMO)
text: CRMO is a multifocal, likely inflammatory bone condition in children, characterized by a waxing and waning course of bone pain and low-grade fever, often affecting the clavicle and metaphyses symmetrically. It mimics haematologic malignancy. Management involves excluding other causes, NSAIDs, and surgical biopsy for diagnosis.

Transfusion reactions can be allergic (most common, mild), febrile (due to antibody formation), or haemolytic (severe, requiring immediate cessation and intensive support). Transfusion-associated infections (Hep C, Hep B, HIV) are rare due to rigorous screening.

topic: Blood Management: Alternatives to Transfusion and Cell Saver
text: Alternatives to allogeneic transfusion include autologous deposition (storing patient's own blood pre-operatively) and intraoperative cell salvage. Cell saver collects, washes, and re-transfuses shed blood, but the removed blood is of lower quality due to cytokine and debris removal. Autotransfusion involves direct re-introduction of lost blood, but without washing, increasing reaction risk.

Massive transfusion is defined as >4 units of blood in 1 hour, often occurring in trauma patients and leading to post-transfusion coagulopathy. Protocols often recommend a 1:1 ratio of FFP to RBCs initially, with early addition of platelets and FFP to reduce mortality and coagulopathy. Identification of at-risk patients is based on injury mechanism, vital signs, and biochemical parameters.

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) possesses mechanisms to evade host defenses, including the mecA gene conferring resistance to beta-lactams and biofilm formation. Community-acquired MRSA is more virulent. Nasal carriage is a significant risk factor for surgical site infections (SSIs). Pre-operative screening and decolonization (e.g., mupirocin nasal ointment, chlorhexidine washes) can significantly reduce SSIs. Vancomycin prophylaxis is recommended for MRSA-colonized patients undergoing arthroplasty.

SSI prevention involves pre-operative optimization (managing comorbidities, smoking cessation, MRSA screening), peri-operative measures (hair clipping, skin prep with chlorhexidine or povidone-iodine, appropriate antibiotic prophylaxis, laminar flow, minimizing theatre traffic, meticulous hand hygiene, sterile drapes/gowns, sound surgical technique, minimal soft tissue handling, haemostasis, aseptic wound closure, and maintaining patient normothermia), and post-operative care (minimizing dressing changes, aseptic technique, ring-fenced beds).

Informed consent is a cornerstone of medical practice, requiring a partnership between patient and doctor based on openness, trust, and clear communication. Patients must have the capacity to understand, retain, and analyze information about the procedure, including common and serious risks. Consent should be obtained in a quiet environment, with ample opportunity for questions, and ideally re-signed on the day of surgery.

Diathermy uses high-frequency electrical current to generate heat for cutting or coagulation. Monopolar diathermy uses an active electrode and a large indifferent plate to concentrate heat at the tip, while bipolar diathermy uses current between the instrument tips, making it safer for patients with pacemakers. Risks include burns from improper plate application, arcing with implants, and fire hazards with flammable skin preps.

topic: Plaster Casts: Plaster of Paris vs. Synthetic
text: Plaster of Paris casts are made of gypsum and are cheap, mouldable, and expand slightly with swelling, but are heavy and not waterproof. Synthetic casts (e.g., fiberglass) are stronger, lighter, waterproof, available in colors, and harden quickly, but are less mouldable and less expansile. The choice depends on factors like cost, required strength, and patient needs.

Surgical tourniquets, primarily pneumatic, are used to create a bloodless field. Contraindications include severe crush injuries, compartment syndrome, sickle cell disease, and relative contraindications for PVD. Nerve injury is typically due to direct compression at the cuff edge, not ischemia. Proper cuff width and pressure are crucial to minimize risk, with lower pressures achieved by gradually increasing pressure until distal pulse is lost. Limb exanguination is effective but contraindicated in infection, metastatic disease, or venous thrombosis. Tourniquet use should be limited in duration (ideally <2 hours) to minimize complications like neuropraxia and muscle ischemia.

A comprehensive hip examination involves assessing the patient standing (pelvic obliquity, scars, muscle wasting, leg length discrepancy, gait, Trendelenburg test), lying down (pelvic squareness, leg lengths, assessing correctability of deformities), palpation (greater trochanter, groin, paraspinal muscles), and assessing range of motion (flexion, abduction, adduction, internal/external rotation) using tests like the Thomas test. Examining the spine, knee, and neurovascular status is also crucial.

In a patient with an arthrodesed hip, examination reveals pelvic obliquity, compensatory scoliosis, hyper-lordosis, leg length discrepancy requiring a shoe raise, and a surgical scar. There is no active hip flexion, abduction, or rotation, and any attempted motion results in pelvic tilt. Gait is asymmetric, slow, and involves compensatory mechanisms like equinus and contralateral knee flexion. A false positive Trendelenburg test can occur due to the fixed pelvis.

Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents with a 'question mark' posture, loss of lumbar lordosis, reduced forward gaze, and flexed hip and knee gait. Examination should also focus on assessing chest wall expansion, chin-brow angle, forward gaze angle, occiput-to-wall distance, and the risk of spinal or respiratory complications for anesthesia.

Spinal examination involves inspection from the front and back to assess alignment, asymmetry, skin changes, and muscle wasting. Gait assessment is crucial, evaluating for Trendelenburg, ataxia, heel-toe walking, pigeon walking, and Romberg's sign. Palpation of spinous processes and paraspinal muscles for spasm, and assessment of joint ROM with provocative tests (Spurling's, Lhermitte's for cervical; SLR, bowstring, femoral stretch for lumbar) are essential. A thorough neurological examination assessing tone, motor power (MRC grade), myotomes, sensation, and reflexes is mandatory.

LLD less than 2 cm is generally asymptomatic. True LLD must be differentiated from apparent LLD due to pelvic obliquity or contractures. Management aims to correct the limp and any psychologic distress. Growth prediction methods (Rule of Thumb, TW3 formula, Green & Anderson tables, Mosley graphs) help determine treatment. Options range from shoe raises for small discrepancies to epiphysiodesis, shortening, lengthening, or amputation for larger differences. Surgery is generally delayed until growth is predictable or near cessation.

Assessing rotational abnormalities involves evaluating the foot progression angle, thigh-foot angle (prone), femoral version (prone, e.g., Gage's test), and foot borders relative to the foot bisector axis. These help identify excessive femoral anteversion or tibial torsion, which often cause in-toeing and awkward gait. Management is usually conservative, with surgery reserved for symptomatic older children.

Examination of a patient with Spina Bifida involves assessing gait with and without orthotics, noting any deformities, muscle wasting, healed ulcers, or cutaneous stigmata of spinal dysraphism. A thorough sensory examination is crucial to determine the neurologic level, and passive range of motion of joints should be assessed for dislocations or contractures. Motor power assessment helps establish the motor level, particularly in the feet, to understand functional capabilities.

A comprehensive history for a child with Cerebral Palsy includes background information on pregnancy, birth, and developmental milestones, as well as details of any chronic orthopaedic issues (spine, hips, knees, feet), previous treatments (orthotics, medications, surgery), and current problems. Functional level (walking, sitting, self-care) and social circumstances are also important to understand the patient's needs and limitations.

Examination of a child with CP includes observing their posture at rest, assessing gait (if ambulatory), and evaluating joint range of motion for contractures. Specific attention is paid to the spine for coronal and sagittal balance, and the feet for deformities like hallux valgus or ulceration. The presence of an intrathecal baclofen pump should be noted. Assessment of passive ROM is crucial to quantify contractures, particularly in the hips, knees, and feet.

Examination of a patient with Achondroplasia reveals characteristic features from head to toe: frontal bossing, midface flattening, disproportionately short limbs with rhizomelic shortening, decreased elbow ROM, radial head dislocation, trident hands, lumbar hyperlordosis, kyphosis, and genu varum. Assessing for spinal stenosis, particularly at the foramen magnum and lumbar spine, is also important.

When examining a patient with MHE, carefully describe the exostotic lumps: their sessile or pedunculated nature, hardness, immobility with overlying soft tissues, and location adjacent to joints. Assess distal neurovascular status and check for limb length discrepancies or angular deformities. Examine for other osteochondromas throughout the body and inquire about mechanical symptoms or signs of malignant transformation (growth, night pain).

Assessing a patient with a limb deficiency requires a systematic approach: observing scars, overall shortening, angular deformities, muscle wasting, skin changes, and spinal alignment while standing. Palpate landmarks to assess for asymmetry and correctability. Evaluate gait for compensatory mechanisms and measure limb lengths. Lying down, assess the correctability of deformities and joint stability. A complete neurological and vascular assessment, along with a thorough history and limb X-rays, are essential.

topic: Examination of Paediatric Lower Limb Angular Deformity
text: Examining a paediatric lower limb for angular deformity involves assessing overall appearance (stature, scars, deformity location), gait (thrust, anatalgia), and palpating to measure intermalleolar distance and assess correctability. While lying down, square the pelvis and measure the deformity. Evaluate joint ROM and rotational profile. Finishing the examination with standing X-rays, CT scanograms, and a family history provides a comprehensive assessment.

topic: Examination of Patellofemoral Joint Rotational Abnormalities
text: Examination of the patellofemoral joint for rotational abnormalities includes assessing coronal alignment, Q angle, foot pronation, scars, quad bulk, swelling, and Beighton's score. Gait analysis should note foot progression angle and patella orientation. Sitting, assess extensor mechanism competence, crepitus, tracking, and patella alta. Lying down, evaluate for effusion, facet pain, MPFL tenderness, patella excursion, tilt, and ROM. Examination of the thigh-foot angle and femoral version (prone) is also crucial.

topic: Examination of the Shoulder: Rotator Cuff, Impingement, and ACJ Arthritis
text: Shoulder examination begins with inspection for asymmetry, scars, and muscle wasting in the deltoid, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus fossae. Palpate the clavicle, ACJ, acromion, LHB, and scapula. Assess active and passive ROM, noting pain, impingement arcs, and scapular winging. Special tests like Hawkins impingement, Jobes, and cross-arm adduction help identify rotator cuff pathology and ACJ involvement. Evaluating LHB and subscapularis strength is also important.

Assessing shoulder instability involves looking for asymmetry, wasting, and signs of hyperlaxity (Beighton's score). Palpate the axillary nerve for function. Special tests include the sulcus sign, anterior and posterior load shift tests (sitting), and the anterior apprehension test (lying). Testing the long head of biceps (LHB) if other tests are equivocal is also part of the assessment.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: General Assessment
text: General elbow examination involves inspecting for scars, asymmetry, carrying angle, swelling, and obvious loss of motion. Assess active and passive ROM in extension, flexion, supination, and pronation, comparing to the contralateral side. Palpate systematically for pain over the lateral epicondyle, RC joint, olecranon, medial epicondyle, and ulna nerve, assessing for subluxation or tenderness.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Cubitus Valgus/Varus and Nerve Status
text: Assessing cubitus valgus or varus involves evaluating ROM and palpating the medial epicondyle and ulna nerve for pain or subluxation. Crucially, examine the ulnar nerve's status in the hand, assessing sensation in the little finger and ulnar side of the dorsum, and motor function of intrinsic muscles and the flexor digitorum profundus to the ring finger. Tests like Tinel's at the cubital tunnel and the Wartenberg sign help localize nerve issues.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Tennis or Golfer's Elbow
