text: For suspected tennis or golfer's elbow, provocative tests include resisted wrist extension and third finger extension for tennis elbow, and resisted finger flexion for golfer's elbow. Assessment also involves palpating the epicondyles for tenderness and evaluating elbow ROM for any pain or restriction.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Stiff Elbow
text: Evaluating a stiff elbow involves assessing both active and passive range of motion to identify any pain within the arc of movement and quantify the degree of stiffness. Functional assessment includes the ability to bring the hand to the mouth and perineum. The presence of crepitus or pain with varus/valgus stress is also noted.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Congenital Radial Head Dislocation
text: Congenital dislocation of the radial head, most commonly anterior, presents with a fullness over the radial aspect, restricted supination and extension, and may be associated with cubitus valgus or varus. Examine the contralateral elbow and screen for associated conditions like Nail Patella syndrome or achondroplasia. Management is usually non-operative unless there is significant pain or reduced ROM.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Radio-Ulnar Synostosis
text: Radio-ulnar synostosis involves the failure of differentiation of the radius and ulna, typically resulting in a fixed pronation deformity. Examination may reveal scars from trauma, limb shortening, and restricted pronation/supination. Traumatic synostosis is associated with high-energy injuries, head injuries, and restricted post-operative ROM. Management is often non-operative due to poor surgical outcomes.

topic: Examination of the Elbow: Rheumatoid Arthritis
text: Examining an elbow with rheumatoid arthritis involves noting the typical rheumatoid features in the hand, wrist, and shoulder, along with any scars on the elbow. Assess elbow ROM, noting pain, crepitus, and warmth. Examine the ulnar nerve for neurological deficits and screen for spinal involvement. Functional assessment includes grip strength and the ability to perform daily activities.

topic: Hand Examination: Screen and Refined Assessment
text: The initial hand screen involves exposing the arms above the elbows, making a fist, opening the hands, and raising the arms to assess elbows and posterior arms. A refined examination involves inspecting and palpating for swelling, tenderness, mobility, and skin changes, and assessing distal neurological and vascular status. Special tests like Allen's test and specific tests for Dupuytren's contracture (Hueson's table test) are then performed.

In rheumatoid arthritis, the hand examination reveals extensor surface changes like ulnar deviation, MCPJ subluxation, Z-thumb deformity, Boutonniere/Swan neck deformities, rheumatoid nodules, and joint inflammation. Flexor surface findings include trigger fingers and other deformities. Functional assessment includes grip, pinch, and chuck pinch strength.

Assessing nerve lesions involves evaluating sensation and motor function for radial, ulnar, median, musculocutaneous, and axillary nerves. Specific myotomes and dermatomes are tested to localize the lesion. Special tests like Tinel's, Phalen's, and Froment's sign help differentiate nerve entrapment or injury sites.

Wrist examination involves inspecting for scars, deformities, and assessing ROM in all planes, including pronation, supination, and radial/ulnar deviation. Palpate systematically for tenderness around the wrist, and perform special tests like the Finklestein test (de Quervain's tenosynovitis), Watson test (scapholunate instability), and DRUJ ballotment (piano key sign) to identify specific pathologies.

Assessing for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome involves examining the neck and shoulders for associated issues, screening hands and wrists for scars and thenar wasting, and evaluating sensation in the radial three digits and thenar eminence. Motor assessment includes APB and FDS power. Special tests like Tinel's sign over the carpal tunnel and Durkin's compression test help confirm the diagnosis.

topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: History and Inspection
text: Brachial plexus examination begins with a history of birth trauma, prematurity, or associated conditions. Inspection includes observing limb posture, muscle wasting, fasciculations, scars (indicating previous exploration or nerve transfers), bony malunion, Horner's syndrome, and any walking aids or orthoses. Assessing the C-spine is also important due to potential associated injuries.

topic: Examination of the Brachial Plexus: Palpation and Movement
text: Palpation involves assessing bony landmarks for old fractures and evaluating sensation along dermatomes and peripheral nerve distributions. Motor testing is performed systematically by nerve root (C5-T1), trunk, cord, and branch levels to assess specific muscle groups like the rhomboids, serratus anterior, deltoid, biceps, and intrinsic hand muscles.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Wagner Classification of Diabetic Foot Ulcers
text: The Wagner classification grades diabetic foot ulcers from 0 (at-risk foot) to 5 (gangrene of the whole foot), with intermediate grades representing superficial, deep, abscess/osteomyelitis, and forefoot gangrene. This system helps stratify ulcer severity and guide treatment.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Eichenholz Classification of Charcot Foot
text: The Eichenholz classification stages Charcot foot progression from Stage 0 (pre-fragmentation with regional demineralization) through Stage 1 (fragmentation with dislocations), Stage 2 (coalescence with sclerosis), to Stage 3 (remodeling with ankylosed joints). Each stage describes characteristic radiographic and clinical features.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Osteochondral Defects of the Talus
text: The Berndt & Hardy classification of osteochondral defects of the talus, based on X-rays, describes four stages: Stage 1 (subchondral fracture), Stage 2 (partially detached fragment), Stage 3 (detached but stable fragment), and Stage 4 (detached and unstable fragment). MRI provides a more detailed assessment, with the Bristol Group classification offering further staging.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Occipital Condyle Fractures (Levine Classification)
text: Occipital condyle fractures are classified by Levine into Type A (transverse process), Type B (posterior arch), Type C (anterior arch), Type D (lateral mass), and Type E (burst, with or without transverse ligament disruption). Type E fractures with >7.5mm widening indicate transverse ligament disruption and are considered unstable.

Hangman's fracture (traumatic C2 spondylolisthesis) is classified by Levine & Edwards into Type 1 (<3mm displacement, intact disc), Type 2 (>3mm displacement, usually intact disc), Type 2a (angulation with potential disc extrusion), and Type 3 (concurrent facet dislocation, disc extrusion, high neurologic injury risk). Type 2a fractures, while benign-looking, represent severe injuries.

Peg fractures (odontoid fractures) are classified by Anderson into Type 1 (avulsion from tip), Type 2 (waist, non-comminuted), Type 2a (waist, comminuted - most unstable), and Type 3 (into C2 body/facets). Type 2a fractures are the most common and unstable.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Types
text: SMA is classified into three types based on age of onset and severity: SMA1 (onset <6 months, death <2 years), SMA2 (onset <2 years, death by 20 years), and SMA3 (onset >2 years, normal life expectancy). Orthopaedic management aims to address scoliosis, hip dislocations, and foot deformities, prioritizing function and respiratory health.

Hereditary Motor Sensory Neuropathy (HMSN) subtypes include HMSN1 (demyelinating, absent reflexes, NCS abnormal), HMSN2 (axonal, reflexes present, NCS near normal), and HMSN3 (Dejerine-Sottas, infantile onset, severe). Management for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (HMSN1/2) often involves tendon transfers and osteotomies to maintain foot flexibility and avoid fusion where possible.

Spina Bifida is classified by the extent of spinal cord and meningeal involvement: Occulta (posterior element defect, no extrusion), Meningocele (dural sac extrusion only), Myelomeningocele (meninges and neural elements extruded), and Rachischisis (fully exposed neural elements). Management is guided by the lowest functional level of the lesion.

Capitellar fractures are classified by Bryan & Morrey into Type 1 (complete, minimal trochlear extension), Type 2 (osteochondritis dissecans), Type 3 (comminuted, compressed), and Type 4 (complete with significant trochlear extension). These classifications help guide treatment, particularly surgical fixation versus non-operative management.

Radial head fractures are classified by Mason into Type 1 (undisplaced), Type 2 (marginal fracture, displaced), Type 3 (displaced, comminuted), and Type 4 (fracture with elbow dislocation). This classification influences treatment decisions, with non-operative management for Type 1 and surgical intervention for Types 2-4.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Coronoid Process Fractures (Morrey & O'Driscoll)
text: Coronoid process fractures are classified by Morrey based on height (<2mm, >2mm) and by O'Driscoll based on location and extent (tip, rim, body, anteromedial basal fracture). The latter classification further subtypes rim and body fractures, aiding in understanding the injury's severity and guiding treatment, especially in the context of associated elbow instability.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Tibialis Posterior Insufficiency (Johnson-Myerson Grade 4)
text: The Johnson-Myerson classification for tibialis posterior tendon insufficiency stages progression from asymptomatic MRI changes (Grade 0) to painful but competent tendon (Grade 1), incompetent tendon with flexible planovalgus (Grade 2), incompetent tendon with fixed planovalgus (Grade 3), and finally fixed planovalgus with talar tilt (Grade 4). Management shifts from conservative to surgical with increasing grades.

Hallux Valgus severity is assessed using the Hallux Valgus Angle (HVA) and the Intermetatarsal Angle (IMA). Mild valgus is typically HVA <19 degrees and IMA <8 degrees. Moderate is HVA 20-40 degrees and IMA 8-20 degrees. Severe is HVA >40 degrees and IMA >20 degrees. These measurements guide treatment decisions, with surgical intervention considered for moderate to severe cases.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Avascular Necrosis of the Hip (FICAT & Steinberg)
text: Avascular Necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head is staged by FICAT and Steinberg classifications. FICAT Stage 1: normal XR, positive MRI/bone scan. Stage 2: sclerosis/cysts. Stage 3: subchondral collapse (crescent sign). Stage 4: significant collapse/flattening/arthrosis. Steinberg adds Stage 0 (all imaging normal) and Stage 5/6 (joint space narrowing, severe arthrosis), providing a comprehensive grading from early changes to end-stage arthritis.

Pipkin fractures describe dislocations of the femoral head with associated fractures. Type 1: fracture inferior to the fovea (low AVN risk). Type 2: fracture superior to the fovea (low AVN risk). Type 3: includes a neck fracture (high AVN risk). Type 4: includes an acetabular fracture (moderate AVN risk). The presence of neck or acetabular fractures significantly impacts prognosis and treatment.

Schatzker classification of tibial plateau fractures includes Type 1 (split), Type 2 (split-depression), Type 3 (depression), Type 4 (medial plateau only, often with knee dislocation), Type 5 (both plateaus with metaphyseal continuity, axial compression), and Type 6 (both plateaus with metaphyseal discontinuity, axial compression). This classification guides surgical approach and fixation.

Elbow instability is staged by Schenk: Stage 1 involves only the lateral collateral ligament disruption (posterolateral subluxation). Stage 2 involves all lateral collateral ligaments disrupted (posterolateral dislocation). Stage 3 involves disruption of both lateral and medial collateral ligaments, with subtypes 3A-3C indicating progressive instability and susceptibility to displacement even in a cast.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: ASIA Scale of Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
text: The ASIA Impairment Scale grades SCI severity: Grade A (complete injury, no motor or sensory function below level), Grade B (incomplete, sensory but no motor function), Grade C (incomplete, motor function present but muscles have grade 2 or less power), Grade D (incomplete, motor function grade 3 or more), and Grade E (normal motor and sensory function). This scale is critical for prognosis and rehabilitation planning.

Glenoid fractures are classified by Ideberg (modified by Goss) into types based on location and pattern: Type 1A (anterior rim), 1B (posterior rim), Type 2 (transverse exiting inferiorly), Type 3 (transverse exiting medial to coracoid), Type 4 (transverse exiting medial border), Type 5 (combination of 2 and 4), and Type 6 (comminuted).

The Sanders classification of calcaneal fractures is based on coronal CT scans of the posterior facet. Grade 1: undisplaced. Grade 2 (A, B, C): one fracture line with two displaced fragments. Grade 3 (A, B, C): two fracture lines with three displaced fragments. Grade 4: three or more fracture lines with multiple fragments. Higher grades indicate greater severity and worse prognosis.

The Tscherne classification for soft tissue injuries related to fractures grades damage from 0 (indirect force, negligible soft tissue damage) to 3 (extensive crushing with impending compartment syndrome or amputation). This classification highlights the importance of soft tissue management in fracture treatment, particularly in high-energy injuries.

The Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fractures assesses severity based on wound size and soft tissue damage: Type 1 (<1cm puncture, simple fracture), Type 2 (>1cm laceration, simple fracture), Type 3a (large/contaminated injury, primary closure possible), Type 3b (large/contaminated injury requiring plastics for coverage), and Type 3c (associated vascular injury). This guides antibiotic choice and surgical management.

Letournel's classification of acetabular fractures categorizes them into elemental types (posterior wall, posterior column, anterior wall, anterior column, transverse, both columns) and associated types where two elemental patterns combine. This detailed classification is crucial for surgical planning and achieving anatomical reduction.

The Tile classification of pelvic fractures categorizes them based on stability: Type A (stable in all planes), Type B (rotationally unstable), and Type C (rotationally and vertically unstable, indicating posterior ligamentous disruption). This system is vital for determining treatment strategies, from conservative management to surgical fixation.

The Young & Burgess classification categorizes pelvic fractures based on mechanism of injury: Anterior-Posterior Compression (APC), Lateral Compression (LC), and Vertical Shear (VS), with combinations of these. It describes the degree of diastasis and ligamentous injury, crucial for assessing stability and guiding treatment.

The Vancouver classification of periprosthetic hip fractures categorizes them based on location and stem stability: AG (greater trochanter), AL (lesser trochanter), B1 (stable stem, good bone stock), B2 (loose stem, good bone stock), B3 (loose stem, poor bone stock), and C (fracture distal to the stem). This guides treatment choices, from simple fixation to revision arthroplasty.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the likelihood of an impending pathologic fracture based on location (upper limb, lower limb, proximal femur), appearance (sclerotic, mixed, lytic), size (<1/3, <2/3, >2/3), and pain level (no pain, moderate pain, unable to WB). A score of 8 or more suggests an impending fracture requiring intervention.

Monteggia fractures involve a fracture of the ulna with associated dislocation of the radial head. Bado's classification describes Type 1 (anterior radial head dislocation), Type 2 (posterior), Type 3 (lateral), and Type 4 (associated radial shaft fracture). Type 2a, with angulation and disc extrusion, is a severe injury despite a benign appearance.

The MESS (Mangled Extremity Severity Score) assesses the viability of a limb after severe trauma based on factors like skeletal/soft tissue injury, limb ischemia, neurological deficit, and patient age/shock. A score of 8 or more suggests the limb may not be viable, guiding decisions regarding amputation versus salvage.

Nalebuff's classification of rheumatoid thumb deformities describes types based on the primary issue: Type 1 (Boutonniere deformity), Type 2 (Boutonniere with CMCJ arthritis), Type 3 (Swan neck with CMCJ adduction/flexion), Type 4 (ulnar collateral ligament laxity), Type 5 (Swan neck without adduction), and Type 6 (mutilating disease). This guides surgical correction.

Palmer's classification of Triangular Fibrocartilage Complex (TFCC) tears distinguishes between traumatic (Type 1: A-D based on location of tear/avulsion) and degenerative (Type 2: A-E based on progressive arthrosis). This classification helps in planning treatment, from debridement to fusion.

Scaphoid fractures are classified by Russe based on pattern (transverse, horizontal oblique, vertical oblique - most unstable) and by Herbert based on stability (Stable: <1mm displacement; Unstable: >1mm displacement, gap, comminution, or specific fracture patterns). Anatomic location (proximal pole, waist, distal pole, tuberosity) is also considered.

Lichtman's staging of Keinbock's disease (avascular necrosis of the lunate) progresses from Stage 1 (normal XR, positive MRI) through Stage 2 (sclerosis) and Stage 3 (collapse, instability) to Stage 4 (pancarpal arthrosis). Treatment options vary from non-operative surveillance to core decompression, vascularized grafting, limited fusion, or wrist fusion, depending on the stage.

Snyder's classification of SLAP tears describes types based on labral and biceps anchor involvement: Type 1 (fraying), Type 2 (unstable biceps anchor), Type 3 (bucket-handle labral tear, intact biceps), Type 4 (bucket-handle tear extending into biceps tendon). Types 5-7 describe combinations with other tears or capsular involvement, guiding debridement or repair.

Larsen's classification of rheumatoid elbow changes grades the severity of arthritis from Grade 1 (soft tissue inflammation, osteoporosis) to Grade 5 (severe arthritis with deformity), with intermediate grades reflecting joint space narrowing and bony erosion. This helps in assessing disease progression and planning treatment.

Eaton's classification of thumb CMCJ arthritis stages the degeneration from Stage 1 (joint space widening, minimal osteophytes) through Stage 2 (narrowing, osteophytes, subluxation) to Stage 3 (sclerosis, cysts, significant subluxation) and Stage 4 (associated STT arthritis). This guides treatment from conservative measures to surgical reconstruction.

Coughlin's grading of Hallux Rigidus (stiff big toe) assesses severity based on X-ray findings, pain level, and MTPJ motion limitation. Grade 0 is normal, while Grade 4 represents severe arthrosis with pain at mid-range motion and no normal motion. This guides treatment from cheilectomy to MTPJ fusion.

Creuss classification of AVN of the humeral head stages the condition from Stage 1 (normal XR, abnormal MRI) to Stage 5 (humeral head and glenoid arthrosis/erosion). Stages 2-4 describe increasing sclerosis, subchondral collapse (crescent sign), and head deformation, indicating progressive osteonecrosis and subsequent arthritis.

Cerebral Palsy is classified by type (Spastic, Athetoid, Ataxic), geographic distribution (Quadriplegic, Diplegic, Hemiplegic), and functional level using the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS), which ranges from GMFCS 1 (walks independently) to GMFCS 5 (wheelchair-bound, head support needed). This classification helps tailor treatment and predict functional outcomes.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Perthes Disease - Herring Lateral Pillar Height
text: Herring's classification of Perthes disease assesses lateral pillar height: Stage A (normal), Stage B (>50% height), Stage B/C (50% with physeal narrowing), and Stage C (<50% height). This classification is crucial for prognosis and guiding treatment, as lateral pillar collapse significantly impacts outcomes.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Cervical Spine Rheumatoid Arthritis Severity (Ranawat)
text: Ranawat's classification of cervical spine rheumatoid arthritis stages severity based on neurological involvement: Stage 1 (pain only), Stage 2 (subjective neurology), Stage 3a (objective neurology, ambulatory), and Stage 3b (objective neurology, non-ambulatory). Patients with Stage 3b disease have a poor surgical prognosis, indicating the need for earlier intervention if possible.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Ferguson Mechanistic Classification of Sub-Axial Fractures
text: Ferguson's classification categorizes sub-axial cervical spine fractures based on the primary mechanism: Flexion (teardrop, compression, distraction, facet dislocation), Extension (burst, posterior element fractures), and Lateral Compression. It highlights the correlation between mechanism, fracture pattern, and the risk of neurologic injury, guiding management decisions.

Spondylolisthesis is classified by Wiltse based on aetiology (Dysplastic, Isthmic, Degenerative, Traumatic, Pathologic, Iatrogenic) and by Myerding based on the degree of slippage (Grade 1: 0-25% to Grade 5: >100%). Isthmic Type 2a (stress fracture of pars) is common, while dysplastic types have a higher risk of progression and neurologic injury.

topic: Nerve Injury Classification: Seddon and Sunderland
text: Seddon's classification categorizes nerve injuries into neuropraxia (segmental demyelination, conduction block), axonotmesis (axonal damage with intact endoneurium), and neurotmesis (complete nerve disruption). Sunderland's equivalent grading (1-5) provides a more detailed description of the extent of axonal and connective tissue damage, correlating with prognosis and the need for surgical repair.

Denis's classification of sacral fractures divides them into three zones based on location relative to the sacral foramina. Zone 1 (lateral to foramina) has a low neurologic injury rate. Zone 2 (through foramina) has moderate risk. Zone 3 (medial to foramina) has the highest risk of neurologic injury and spinal/pelvic instability, particularly with vertical fractures.

Enneking's classification of bone tumors categorizes them by grade (low/high), compartment (intraosseous/extraosseous), and metastatic status (none, metastasis present). This framework guides treatment strategies, aiming for wide or radical resection based on tumor biology and extent.

Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic), post-radiotherapy, and Paget's disease-associated osteosarcomas. Intramedullary is most common, often around the knee, while parosteal is low-grade and on the bone surface. Prognosis correlates with grade, subtype, and presence of metastases.

Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, de-differentiated, clear cell, mesenchymal), post-radiotherapy, and Paget's disease-associated. Prognosis correlates with grade; de-differentiated chondrosarcoma has the worst prognosis. Histologic features like 'soap bubble appearance' or 'chicken wire calcification' aid in diagnosis.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Tibial Bone Defects in Total Knee Replacement (TKR)
text: Paprosky's classification of tibial defects in TKR ranges from Type 1 (minimal metaphyseal loss) to Type 4 (inadequate diaphyseal bone for long stem fixation). Management options for larger defects (Type 2-4) include cement with screws, metallic augments, allograft, metaphyseal sleeves, or revision stems, depending on the extent of bone loss and defect containment.

Schenk's stages of knee dislocation describe the extent of ligamentous injury: KD1 (ACL or PCL only), KD2 (ACL and PCL), KD3 (involving collateral ligaments - MCL or LCL), KD4 (all major ligaments), and KD5 (fracture-dislocation). This classification is crucial for understanding knee instability and guiding treatment.

Neer's classification of clavicle fractures categorizes them by location: Type 1 (middle third), Type 2 (distal third, further subdivided by CC ligament integrity and displacement), and Type 3 (proximal third). Type 2 fractures are further subtyped based on displacement and involvement of the conoid and trapezoid ligaments, influencing treatment.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Graf Classification of DDH
text: Graf's classification of Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) is based on the alpha angle (bony acetabular coverage) and beta angle (cartilaginous coverage). Type 1 is normal, Type 2 is borderline, Type 3 indicates subluxation, and Type 4 indicates dislocation. This classification is used in infants under 4 months before the femoral head ossifies.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Denis 3-Column Theory of Spinal Stability
text: Denis's 3-column theory describes spinal stability based on column disruption: Compression fractures affect only the anterior column. Flexion-distraction (Chance) fractures disrupt the middle and posterior columns. Burst fractures involve the anterior and middle columns. Fracture-dislocations disrupt all three columns, indicating severe instability.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Swanson's Classification of Congenital Hand Anomalies
text: Swanson's classification categorizes congenital hand anomalies by aetiology: failure of formation (amelia, longitudinal arrest), failure of differentiation (syndactyly, camptodactyly), duplication (polydactyly), overgrowth/undergrowth (hyperplasia/hypoplasia), and constriction bands. General syndromes and Madelung's deformity are also considered.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Wassel's Classification of Thumb Duplications
text: Wassel's classification of thumb polydactyly describes types based on the pattern of duplication: Type 1 (bifid P3), Type 2 (duplicated P3), Type 3 (bifid P2), Type 4 (duplicated P2 - most common), Type 5 (bifid P1), Type 6 (duplicated P1), and Type 7 (triphalangism). This guides surgical management, aiming for the most functional duplication.

Jackson's classification of articular cartilage degeneration grades changes from Grade 1 (softening) to Grade 4 (full-thickness defects with exposed subchondral bone), with intermediate grades including fibrillation/fissuring and partial-thickness defects. This system helps evaluate the severity of cartilage damage, particularly in osteoarthritis.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Lauge Hansen Ankle Fractures
text: The Lauge Hansen classification of ankle fractures is based on foot position and talar rotation at injury: Supination-Adduction (Weber A), Supination-External Rotation (Weber B with posterior/anterior fragments), Pronation-External Rotation (Weber C, often with posterior malleolus), and Pronation-Abduction (Weber C, often with medial bone component). This system guides treatment based on the fracture pattern and stability.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Paprosky Classification of Acetabular Defects
text: Paprosky's classification of acetabular defects in revision hip arthroplasty considers migration, bone loss on AP X-ray, and cup stability. Type 1 has minimal loss. Type 2 involves superior or medial migration with bone loss but stable cup. Type 3 indicates significant migration and bone loss with partial or unstable cup stability, requiring advanced reconstructive techniques.

topic: Useful Tables: Collagen Types and Related Diseases
text: Different collagen types have specific tissue distributions and are associated with various diseases. Type I collagen is found in bone and skin and is implicated in Osteogenesis Imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Type II is in hyaline cartilage and linked to SED and Kniest's syndrome. Type III is in granulation tissue and associated with Dupuytren's contracture. Type IV is in basement membranes.

topic: Useful Tables: Changes in Articular Cartilage with Aging and OA
text: Articular cartilage undergoes changes with aging and osteoarthritis. With aging, water content and collagen concentration decrease, while chondrocyte size increases. In OA, water content increases, proteoglycan content decreases, and chondrocytes show increased synthetic activity, leading to cartilage breakdown.

topic: Useful Tables: Energy Expenditure by Amputation Level for Ambulation
text: The energy expenditure for ambulation increases significantly with more proximal amputations. Transfemoral amputations require about 65% more energy than a long transtibial amputation, which itself requires 10% more than an intact limb. Bilateral transtibial amputations also demand substantial energy.

topic: Useful Tables: Young's Modulus for Orthopaedic Materials
text: Young's modulus quantifies material stiffness. Ceramics are the stiffest (250 GPa), followed by CoCr (225 GPa) and Titanium (100 GPa). Cortical bone is around 20 GPa, while PMMA is 2 GPa, and polyethylene is 1.5 GPa. Softer tissues like tendon (0.1 GPa) and cartilage (0.02 GPa) have much lower moduli.

topic: Useful Tables: Genes and Inheritance Patterns in Orthopaedic Disease
text: Many orthopaedic conditions have genetic links. Achondroplasia is AD due to FGFR3 mutation, while Cleidocranial dysplasia involves CBFA1. Ehlers-Danlos and Marfan syndromes are AD due to collagen defects. Neurofibromatosis Type 1 is AD due to the neurofibromin gene. Pseudoachondroplasia involves the COMP gene.

topic: Useful Tables: Differences Between Tendons and Ligaments
text: Tendons and ligaments differ in their properties. Ligaments have higher elastin content and are weaker, with layered collagen arrangements. Tendons are stronger, have less elastin, longitudinal collagen, and can have direct or indirect insertions. Tendons also have varied vascularity (paratenon vs. vinculae), unlike ligaments which primarily receive supply via their insertion sites.

topic: Useful Tables: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
text: Bone cement is typically a two-part mixture: a liquid monomer (MMA) with accelerator and inhibitor, and a powder polymer (PMMA) with initiator and dye. It undergoes phases of mixing, waiting (dough phase), working, and hardening, influenced by temperature. Proper mixing and manipulation are crucial for optimal strength and to avoid complications like porosity or premature setting.

topic: Useful Tables: Order of Soft Tissue Releases in Total Knee Replacement (TKR)
text: The order of soft tissue releases in TKR depends on the deformity. For varus, releases proceed from osteophytes to the medial capsule, deep MCL, PCL, and sequential superficial MCL release. For valgus, it involves lateral capsule, ITB/popliteus, LCL, and posterolateral capsule. For flexion contractures, posterior capsule, PCL, and tibial plateau/femur adjustments are performed.

Patellar height is assessed using the Insall-Salvetti ratio (patellar tendon length to patella length) and Blackburn-Peel ratio (distal pole to joint line). Ratios >1.2 or >1.0 respectively suggest patella alta. Patellar tilt is measured on CT, with >7 degrees considered abnormal. The tibial tuberosity-to-trochlear groove (TTTG) distance is also assessed on CT, with >20mm indicating significant lateralization.

topic: Useful Tables: Knee Ligament Stability Tests
text: Knee ligament stability is assessed through various tests. Lachman test (30° flexion) evaluates the ACL, grading laxity based on translation. The pivot shift test assesses anterolateral rotatory instability. The posterior sag sign evaluates the PCL, and varus/valgus stress tests assess collateral ligament integrity at different degrees of flexion.

Waddell's signs are a set of non-organic findings suggestive of psychological overlay in low back pain. They include non-anatomical tenderness, simulation of symptoms, distraction-induced pain reduction, regional sensory or motor disturbances, and overreaction during examination.

topic: Useful Tables: Knee Ligament Injury Classification (Schenk Stages)
text: Schenk's classification of knee dislocations stages the injury based on the number of disrupted major ligaments: KD1 (ACL or PCL), KD2 (ACL & PCL), KD3 (ACL, PCL, & collateral ligament), KD4 (all major ligaments), and KD5 (fracture-dislocation). This helps determine treatment and prognosis.

topic: Useful Tables: Radial Head (Mason) and Coronoid Process (Morrey/O'Driscoll) Fractures
text: Radial head fractures are classified by Mason (Type 1-4) based on displacement and association with elbow dislocation. Coronoid process fractures are classified by Morrey (height) and O'Driscoll (location/subtype), important for assessing elbow stability, especially after posterolateral rotatory instability.

Hawkins classification of talar neck fractures correlates with AVN risk: Type 1 (undisplaced) has a 10% AVN risk. Type 2 (displaced with STJ subluxation) has a 50% AVN risk. Type 3 (displaced with STJ & ankle subluxation) has a 90% AVN risk. Type 4 (displaced with STJ, TTJ & TNJ subluxation) has a 100% AVN risk.

The Southwick angle quantifies the severity of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SUFE) by measuring the difference in the lateral epiphyseal angle between the affected and unaffected hips. Mild is <30 degrees, moderate is 30-50 degrees, and severe is >50 degrees. This influences prognosis and management.

Bone tumors are classified by Enneking based on grade, compartment, and metastatic status. Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic, post-radiotherapy, and Paget's. Chondrosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary (classic, de-differentiated), clear cell, mesenchymal, and post-radiotherapy. Histologic features are key for diagnosis.

Poor prognostic indicators for osteosarcoma include high LDH and alkaline phosphatase levels, absence of anti-shock protein 90, pelvic location, pathologic fracture at presentation, poor tumor necrosis after chemotherapy, vascular invasion, recurrence, and metastases.

topic: Useful Tables: Mean Surface Roughness of Orthopaedic Materials
text: The surface roughness of orthopaedic materials impacts articulation. Polished Exeter stems and ceramic heads have very low roughness (0.01-0.02), while polyethylene cups have higher roughness (2.0), and articular cartilage is around 3.0. This affects wear rates and friction.

topic: Useful Tables: Coefficients of Friction of Articulations
text: Native knee and hip joints have very low coefficients of friction (0.005-0.01). Metal-on-polyethylene articulations are around 0.02, while metal-on-metal articulations have a significantly higher coefficient (0.8), contributing to higher wear rates.

topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
text: Joint lubrication mechanisms include Boundary lubrication (single molecular layer, predominant in prostheses), Squeeze Film lubrication (fluid pressure resisting load, predominant in native joints), Elastohydrodynamic lubrication (fluid deformation), Hydrodynamic lubrication (fluid film lifting surfaces), Weeping lubrication (compression elutes fluid), and Boosted lubrication (pressurized fluid leaves viscous residue). These work in concert during the gait cycle.

topic: Useful Tables: Conditions Affecting Physis and Epiphysis
text: Various conditions affect different zones of the physis and epiphysis. Epiphyseal involvement includes MED, SED, and Trevor's disease. The reserve zone can be affected by pseudoachondroplasia and Gaucher's. Proliferative zone by achondroplasia and gigantism. Hypertrophic zone by SUFE and trauma. Provisional calcification zone by rickets and osteomyelitis.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity (TP/TP+FN), Specificity (TN/TN+FP), PPV (TP/TP+FP), NPV (TN/TN+FN), Accuracy, Reliability (inter/intra-observer), Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, Incidence, P-value, Type 1 & 2 errors, and Power. These terms are crucial for interpreting research and clinical data.

Statistical tests used in research include the Student T-test (parametric, 2 variables), ANOVA (parametric, multiple variables), Chi-Squared test (non-parametric, discrete variables), Mann-Whitney U (non-parametric, continuous data), and Kruskal-Wallis (non-parametric, multiple variables). Yates' correction and Fisher's exact test are used for small sample sizes with Chi-Squared.

topic: Useful Tables: Trauma Severity Scores (AIS & ISS)
text: The Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) grades injuries from 1 (minor) to 6 (unsurvivable). The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by squaring the AIS of the three most severely injured body regions. ISS >25 indicates severe injury, and ISS >40 indicates life-threatening injury. NISS allows multiple injuries from the same body region.

topic: Useful Tables: Muscle Layers of the Foot
text: The intrinsic muscles of the foot are organized into four plantar layers and one dorsal layer. Plantar layers include abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, lumbricals, adductor hallucis, flexor hallucis brevis, flexor digiti minimi, and interossei. The dorsal layer contains the extensor digitorum brevis and extensor hallucis brevis.

topic: Useful Tables: Surgical Approaches in the Foot and Ankle
text: Various surgical approaches are used for the foot and ankle, each with specific muscle planes and dangers. For the ankle, anterior approaches involve EDL/EHL, posterolateral accesses PB/FHL, posteromedial targets the posterior tibial nerve, and anterolateral/anteromedial approaches involve different combinations of muscles and nerves.

topic: Useful Tables: Angles in the Foot and Ankle
text: Key angles in the foot and ankle include Kite's angle (talus-calcaneus axis), calcaneal pitch (calcaneus-1st MT axis), Meary's angle (talus-1st MT axis), Bohler's angle (tuberocities and posterior facet), and Crucial angle of Gissane (cortical struts). Hallux valgus is measured by HVA, IMA, and phalangeal angles.

topic: Useful Tables: Types of Pelvic Osteotomies
text: Pelvic osteotomies for hip dysplasia include Salter (redirectional, hinges on sciatic notch), Ganz (redirectional, close to acetabulum), Pemberton (volume-reducing, hinges on triradiate), Dega (volume-reducing, near sciatic notch), Chiari (salvage, volume-increasing), and Shelf procedures (salvage, augmenting acetabulum). These aim to improve acetabular coverage and hip stability.

topic: Useful Tables: Stabilizers of the Elbow
text: Elbow stability is maintained by primary static stabilizers (ulna collateral, radial head) and secondary dynamic stabilizers (anconeus, brachialis, flexor/extensor muscles). The anterior band of the MCL and the coronoid process are critical for valgus stability, while the LCL and posterior structures resist posterolateral instability.

topic: Useful Tables: MRC Muscle Power Grades
text: The MRC (Medical Research Council) scale grades muscle power from 0 (no movement) to 5 (normal power against resistance). Grade 1 is a flicker, Grade 2 is movement with gravity eliminated, and Grade 3 is movement against gravity. This scale is used to quantify muscle weakness.

Orthopaedic screw sets are categorized into small and large fragment sets, each containing cortical, cancellous, and locking screws of various diameters and corresponding drill bit and tap sizes. These are essential for fracture fixation and provide different strengths and holding capabilities.

Various radiographic views are used for shoulder assessment: True AP (GHJ pathology), Axillary views (dislocations, head shape), Stryker notch (Hill-Sachs), Zanca (ACJ), and Garth (instability). These views provide different perspectives to diagnose specific shoulder pathologies.

topic: Useful Tables: Positions for Arthrodesis of Joints
text: Optimal positions for joint arthrodesis vary. For the hip, it's 30° flexion, 5° adduction, 10° ER. Knee: 0-10° flexion, 5° valgus. Ankle: 0° flexion, 5° valgus. Thumb CMCJ: 30° abduction, 30° extension, 15° pronation. Shoulder: 30° flexion, 30° abduction, 30° IR (most crucial for function).

topic: Useful Tables: Ligamentous Stability of the Shoulder
text: Shoulder stability relies on ligaments like the SGHL (restrains ER in adduction), MGHL (anterior translation in mid-range abduction), and IGHL (anterior/posterior translation at 90° abduction). Damage to these ligaments leads to instability.

Key orthopaedic medications include analgesics (Paracetamol, NSAIDs), opioids, steroids (immunosuppressive, anti-inflammatory), local anesthetics (Na+ channel blockers), anticoagulants (Warfarin, Heparin, LMWH, Fondaparinaux, Rivaroxaban), antiplatelets (Aspirin), bisphosphonates (inhibit osteoclasts), Strontium (affects bone turnover), DMARDs (Methotrexate, Etanercept, Infliximab), and Penicillamine.

Intoeing in children can be caused by Metatarsus Adductus (benign, resolves with WB), Internal Tibial Torsion (resolves by age 2-4), Femoral Anteversion (normal variant, resolves by age 8-10), Club Foot (pathologic), or Cerebral Palsy (pathologic). Assessing the thigh-foot axis and foot progression angle helps differentiate these conditions.

Torticollis can be muscular (SCM contracture, common), acute idiopathic (muscle spasm), congenital (occipitocervical anomalies), neurogenic (nerve tumor), ocular (visual problem), or due to atlanto-axial rotatory instability (traumatic, syndromic, infective). Muscular torticollis is characterized by SCM mass and associated facial asymmetry.

topic: Causes of Paediatric Genu Valgum and Genu Varum
text: Paediatric genu varum can be caused by Blount's disease, rickets, achondroplasia, and multiple hereditary osteochondromatosis. Genu valgum can be physiologic, or pathological due to fibula hemimelia, Morquio syndrome, MED, cozen's fracture, or rickets. Identifying the underlying cause is crucial for management.

topic: Perthes Disease: Catterall's Head at Risk Signs
text: Catterall's 'Head at Risk' signs in Perthes disease indicate a poorer prognosis and include Gage's sign (lateral physeal lucency), lateral head subluxation, calcification lateral to the epiphysis, and a horizontal physis. Treatment aims to prevent head collapse and deformation, particularly in older children or those with these risk factors.

Acceptable C-spine measurements are crucial for assessing stability. ADI should be <5mm (child) or <3-5mm (adult), with changes on flexion/extension indicating instability. PADI/SAC <14mm suggests stenosis. Powers ratio <1 is normal. Pre-vertebral soft tissue swelling is also assessed. These values help diagnose instability and guide surgical intervention.

topic: Incidence of Concurrent Spinal Trauma in C-Spine Fractures
text: Spinal trauma is frequently associated with cervical spine fractures. The risk of concurrent injury decreases with level: C1 fractures have a 50% risk of associated spinal injury, C2 around 30%, and C3 around 20%. This highlights the importance of a complete spinal assessment in patients with cervical spine injuries.

Orthopaedic implants are made from various metals, each with distinct compositions and properties. Stainless Steel 316L contains iron, chromium, nickel, molybdenum, and low carbon. Titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V) are lightweight and strong. Cobalt-Chrome alloys offer high strength and corrosion resistance. Understanding these compositions is vital for implant selection and managing potential adverse reactions.

Nerve fibers are classified by type (Aα, Aβ, Aδ, B, C) based on myelination, diameter, and conduction velocity. Aα fibers are large, myelinated motor neurons. Aβ are organized sensory fibers. Aδ transmit pain and temperature. B fibers are pre-ganglionic autonomic, and C fibers are unmyelinated post-ganglionic autonomic, transmitting slow pain.

topic: Modic Changes in Degenerative Disc Disease
text: Modic changes describe vertebral endplate abnormalities seen on MRI in degenerative disc disease. Modic 1 (dark T1, bright T2) indicates active inflammation and pain. Modic 2 (bright T1, bright T2) signifies fatty infiltration and chronic pain. Modic 3 (dark T1, dark T2) represents subchondral sclerosis.

The cell cycle consists of Interphase (G1, S, G2) and Mitosis (M). G1 is for growth, S for DNA synthesis, G2 for further growth and preparation for mitosis. M phase involves nuclear division (mitosis) and cell division (cytokinesis). G0 is a quiescent state where cells exit the cycle.

The six dorsal wrist compartments contain specific tendons and nerves. Compartment 1: APL, EPB. Compartment 2: ECRL, ECRB. Compartment 3: EPL. Compartment 4: EDC, EIP, PIN. Compartment 5: EDM. Compartment 6: ECU. Understanding these compartments is crucial for diagnosing and treating conditions like De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

The sciatic notch transmits eleven structures: above the piriformis are the superior gluteal nerve/artery; below the piriformis are the inferior gluteal nerve/artery, pudendal nerve/artery, sciatic nerve, nerve to obturator internus, posterior femoral cutaneous nerve, and nerve to quadratus femoris. The piriformis muscle itself also exits the greater sciatic foramen.

Facet orientation varies along the spine. Cervical facets are oriented coronally at 0 degrees and sagittally at 45 degrees. Thoracic facets are at 20 degrees coronal and 55 degrees sagittal. Lumbar facets are oriented coronally at 50 degrees and sagittally at 90 degrees, allowing for greater flexion and extension but limiting rotation.

Pedicle size varies throughout the spine. The T4 pedicles are the smallest in the entire spine, while the L1 pedicles are the smallest in the lumbar spine. Conversely, T1 pedicles are the largest in the thoracic spine, reflecting the varying biomechanical demands along the vertebral column.

Vertebrae exhibit distinct anatomic features along the spine. Cervical vertebrae have foramina transversarium and bifid spinous processes. Thoracic vertebrae possess costal facets. Lumbar vertebrae have mamillary processes, are taller anteriorly contributing to lordosis, and have shorter, wider pedicles with flatter facet orientations.

Wiberg's classification describes patellar facet morphology: Type 1 has equal medial and lateral facets with a central ridge. Type 2 has a smaller medial facet with a medialized ridge. Type 3 features a tiny, medially deviated medial facet, resulting in an almost absent ridge. This classification is relevant in assessing patellofemoral pain and instability.

Prosthetic knees offer various articulation types: Polycentric (four-bar linkage) allows varied Center of Rotation (COR) for better gait. Hydraulic/pneumatic knees provide fluid gait and varied resistance. Constant/Variable friction knees offer basic damping. Stance control knees lock in extension for stability, and manual locking knees provide maximum safety for very weak patients.

topic: Factors Negatively Influencing Amputation Stump Healing
text: Several factors can impair amputation stump healing, including low serum albumin (<3.5 g/dL), low lymphocyte count (<1500/mm³), low serum transferrin, low ABPI (<0.45), low transcutaneous oxygen saturation (<20 mmHg), and Hb <10 g/dL. These indicate poor nutritional status, peripheral vascular disease, or anemia.

Ideal amputation levels are chosen to maximize function and prosthetic fitting. For the forearm, the junction of the proximal 2/3 and distal 1/3 is preferred. The middle third of the humerus is ideal. For transtibial amputations, maintaining about 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity (relative to height) is crucial. The middle third of the femur is preferred for transfemoral amputations.

A prosthesis consists of several key parts: the socket (interface with the residual limb), suspension (attachment method), struts (restore length), articulations (replace joint function), and the terminal device (cosmetic or functional hand/foot). The terminal device can be passively cosmetic or actively controlled via cables, struts, or myoelectric signals.

Hypersensitivity reactions are classified into four types based on the involved immune mechanism. Type 1 (IgE mediated) includes atopy and anaphylaxis. Type 2 (antibody-related cytotoxic) involves antibody binding to cells. Type 3 (immune complex mediated) involves antigen-antibody complexes. Type 4 (cell-mediated) involves T-cells and delayed reactions.

The complement system is a crucial part of innate immunity that 'complements' adaptive immunity. It enhances macrophage function, promotes chemotaxis, and aids in cytokine coordination, playing a vital role in pathogen elimination and inflammation.

Different medical imaging procedures involve varying radiation doses. Angiography can deliver up to 57 mSv over 15-20 years. A CT neck is about 0.6 mSv, CT Abdomen/Pelvis 10 mSv, and CXR 0.1 mSv. Bone scans (99mTc) are about 3 mSv. DEXA scans and limb X-rays have negligible doses (<1 day background).

topic: Differences Between Tendon and Ligament Composition
text: Tendons and ligaments are primarily composed of Type I collagen (90%) and proteoglycans (80% of the matrix). Ligaments have higher elastin content for recoil, while tendons have varied vascularity (paratenon vs. vinculae) and function to attach muscle to bone, acting as springs. Tendons also have tenocytes, while ligaments have fibroblasts.

Bone cementing techniques have evolved significantly. Early methods involved finger packing. Second-generation techniques introduced cement guns and retrograde pressurization. Third-generation methods focus on reducing porosity (vacuum mixing), using pulse lavage, centralizers, and rough-stem finishes to improve cement mantle quality and implant fixation.

Bone cement undergoes distinct phases: Mixing (performed in vacuum to reduce porosity), Waiting (dough phase, viscosity increases), Working (manipulation time), and Hardening (complete hardening, influenced by temperature). Setting time is when cement reaches half its maximal heat.

Patellar height is assessed using the Insall-Salvetti ratio (>1.2 suggests patella alta) and Blackburn-Peel ratio (<0.8 suggests patella baja). Patellar tilt, measured on CT, is abnormal if >7 degrees. The tibial tuberosity-to-trochlear groove (TTTG) distance, also on CT, indicates lateralization, with >20mm being significantly abnormal.

Key orthopaedic formulas include the Law of Wear (V=SL/H), Bending Rigidity (BR = SMI x Young's Modulus), and Torsional Rigidity (TR = PMI x Young's Modulus). These relate material properties and geometry to mechanical performance, influencing implant design and predicting wear.

topic: Newton's Law of Viscosity and Synovial Fluid
text: Newton's law of viscosity describes the relationship between shear stress and shear rate. Synovial fluid, however, is a non-Newtonian fluid that exhibits pseudoplasticity and thixotropy, meaning its viscosity changes with shear rate and time under load. This property is crucial for joint lubrication during movement.

Orthopaedic implants can undergo various types of corrosion: Uniform (affects entire surface), Galvanic (dissimilar metals create electrochemical gradient), Crevice (occurs in gaps), Pitting (localized corrosion), Fretting (combination of wear and corrosion), Intergranular (occurs at grain boundaries), Leaching (intra-granular corrosion), Inclusion (iatrogenic, due to retained fragments), and Stress corrosion (cyclic loading disrupts passive layer).

Bone healing occurs via primary or secondary intention. Primary bone healing (contact healing) involves minimal activity at direct contact points. Secondary bone healing involves inflammation, soft callus formation, hard callus formation, and remodeling, with 'cutting cones' tunneling across the gap to re-establish medullary continuity. This process can take 1-2 years for complete remodeling.

topic: Nerve Injury Classifications: Seddon and Sunderland
text: Seddon's classification describes nerve injuries as neuropraxia (demyelination), axonotmesis (axonal damage), and neurotmesis (complete nerve disruption). Sunderland's equivalent grading (1-5) further refines this based on the degree of connective tissue damage, offering a more detailed prognosis and guiding treatment decisions for nerve repair.

Denis's classification divides sacral fractures into three zones based on their proximity to the sacral foramina. Zone 1 (lateral to foramina) has a low risk of neurologic injury. Zone 2 (through foramina) carries a moderate risk. Zone 3 (medial to foramina) has the highest risk of neurologic injury and instability, particularly with vertical fractures.

Schatzker classification of tibial plateau fractures includes Type 1 (split), Type 2 (split-depression), Type 3 (depression), Type 4 (medial plateau only), Type 5 (both plateaus with metaphyseal continuity), and Type 6 (both plateaus with metaphyseal discontinuity). This system guides surgical management based on fracture pattern and stability.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: ASIA Scale of Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
text: The ASIA Impairment Scale grades SCI severity from A (complete) to E (normal). Grades B, C, and D represent incomplete injuries with varying degrees of preserved sensory and motor function below the neurological level. This scale is crucial for predicting neurological recovery and guiding rehabilitation.

Ideberg's classification of glenoid fractures, modified by Goss, describes types based on the rim fragment (1A anterior, 1B posterior) and transverse patterns (2-5) or comminution (6), aiding in surgical planning for shoulder stability.

Sanders classification of calcaneal fractures, based on CT scans, grades severity from 1 (undisplaced) to 4 (multiple fragments). Subtypes A, B, and C indicate the location of fracture lines within the posterior facet, impacting prognosis and treatment strategies.

Tscherne's classification of soft tissue injuries associated with fractures ranges from Grade 0 (no soft tissue damage) to Grade 3 (extensive crushing, degloving, or compartment syndrome), emphasizing the importance of soft tissue management in fracture care, particularly in high-energy trauma.

The Gustilo-Anderson classification for open fractures (Type 1-3c) assesses wound size, contamination, energy of injury, and vascular status. Type 3c indicates vascular injury, requiring immediate attention and specific management protocols to preserve limb viability.

Letournel's classification of acetabular fractures categorizes them into elemental types (posterior wall, posterior column, anterior wall, anterior column, transverse, both columns) and associated types, providing a comprehensive framework for surgical planning and reconstruction to restore joint congruity.

Tile's classification of pelvic fractures categorizes them by stability into Type A (stable), Type B (rotationally unstable), and Type C (rotationally and vertically unstable), based on the integrity of the pelvic ring and ligaments. This guides the decision for operative versus non-operative management.

Young & Burgess classify pelvic fractures by mechanism: APC (anterior-posterior compression), LC (lateral compression), and VS (vertical shear). They describe progressive injury patterns within each mechanism, with APC Type 3 and LC Type 3 indicating severe instability and high risk of hemorrhage.

Vancouver classification of periprosthetic hip fractures addresses location (AG, AL, C) and stem stability (B1-B3). B1 fractures are stable with good bone stock. B2 fractures are loose with good bone stock. B3 indicates loose stem with poor bone stock, often requiring revision arthroplasty with augments or stems.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: Impending Pathologic Fracture (Mirel's Score)
text: Mirel's score predicts the risk of impending pathologic fracture based on location, appearance (sclerotic, mixed, lytic), size, and pain. A score of 8 or more indicates a high risk, suggesting prophylactic fixation is warranted to prevent fracture.

Bado's classification of Monteggia fractures describes types based on the direction of radial head dislocation (anterior, posterior, lateral) relative to the ulna fracture. Type 4 involves an associated radial shaft fracture. Type 2a, with angulation and disc extrusion, is particularly severe.

The MESS (Mechanism, Ischemia, Severity of swelling, Sensory loss) score helps assess the viability of a traumatized limb. Higher scores correlate with poorer outcomes and increase the likelihood of amputation. A score of 7 or more is generally considered a strong indication for amputation.

Nalebuff's classification of rheumatoid thumb deformities describes progressive stages from mild (Type 1 Boutonniere) to severe mutilating disease (Type 6), including Swan neck deformities and UCL laxity. This guides the surgical approach, aiming to restore function and stability.

Palmer's classification of TFCC tears distinguishes between traumatic (Type 1: central perforation, ulnar styloid avulsion, distal avulsion, radial avulsion) and degenerative (Type 2: thinning to progressive arthrosis). This classification is key for guiding treatment, from arthroscopic debridement to wrist fusion.

Russe classification describes scaphoid fracture patterns (transverse, oblique, vertical oblique), while Herbert classifies them by stability (Stable: <1mm displacement; Unstable: >1mm displacement, gap, comminution, specific patterns). This distinction is critical for determining whether non-operative casting or surgical fixation is indicated.

Lichtman's staging of Keinbock's disease (avascular necrosis of the lunate) progresses from Stage 1 (normal XR, abnormal MRI) to Stage 4 (pancarpal arthrosis). Treatment options, such as core decompression, vascularized grafting, or limited/wrist fusion, are chosen based on the stage of disease and stability.

Snyder's classification of SLAP tears details labral and biceps anchor involvement: Type 1 (fraying), Type 2 (unstable anchor), Type 3 (bucket-handle tear with intact biceps), Type 4 (tear extending into biceps). Types 5-7 describe variations and combinations with other lesions, guiding surgical management (debridement vs. reattachment).

Larsen's classification of rheumatoid elbow changes describes progression from soft tissue inflammation (Grade 1) to severe arthritis with deformity (Grade 5), with intermediate stages reflecting joint space narrowing and bony erosion. This aids in assessing disease severity and therapeutic options.

Eaton's classification of thumb carpometacarpal (CMC) joint arthritis stages degeneration from Stage 1 (joint widening) to Stage 4 (associated STT arthritis), based on joint space narrowing, osteophytes, sclerosis, cysts, and subluxation. This guides treatment, from splinting to trapeziectomy with tendon interposition.

Coughlin's grading of Hallux Rigidus assesses severity based on X-ray findings (narrowing, osteophytes), pain (none to constant), and MTPJ motion restriction. Grade 4 represents severe arthrosis with pain at mid-range motion and no motion, typically requiring fusion.

Creuss classification of humeral head AVN stages changes from Stage 1 (normal XR) to Stage 5 (humeral head and glenoid arthrosis). Stages 2-4 describe increasing sclerosis, subchondral collapse (crescent sign), and head deformation, indicating progressive osteonecrosis and subsequent degenerative changes.

topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
text: Joint lubrication involves several mechanisms: Squeeze Film lubrication (fluid pressure), Elastohydrodynamic lubrication (fluid deformation), Hydrodynamic lubrication (fluid film), Weeping lubrication (fluid elution from cartilage), Boosted lubrication (pressurized fluid residue), and Boundary lubrication (molecular layer). These work dynamically during gait.

topic: Useful Tables: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
text: Bone cement typically consists of a liquid monomer (MMA) and a powder polymer (PMMA), with accelerators, initiators, and inhibitors. It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, influenced by temperature and handling techniques. Proper mixing is crucial to minimize porosity.

topic: Useful Tables: TKR Soft Tissue Releases
text: Soft tissue releases in TKR depend on the deformity. Varus correction involves releasing osteophytes, medial capsule, deep MCL, PCL, and sequential superficial MCL. Valgus correction addresses lateral capsule, ITB/popliteus, LCL, and posterolateral capsule. Flexion contractures require posterior capsule/PCL release and tibial slope adjustments.

Patellar height is assessed via Insall-Salvetti (>1.2 = alta) and Blackburn-Peel (<0.8 = baja) ratios. Patellar tilt (>7° on CT) and Trough-to-Tibial Tubercle distance (TTTG, >20mm) indicate lateralization. These measurements help diagnose patellofemoral instability.

topic: Useful Tables: Knee Ligament Stability Tests
text: Lachman test (30° flexion) assesses ACL laxity. Pivot shift evaluates anterolateral rotatory instability. Posterior sag sign assesses PCL integrity. Varus/valgus stress tests assess collateral ligaments. KT-1000 testing quantifies anterior translation, with >3mm delta or 11mm absolute laxity indicating significant ACL deficiency.

Waddell's signs are indicators of non-organic pain in low back pain assessment. They include non-anatomical tenderness, simulation of movement, distraction-induced pain reduction, regional sensory/motor deficits, and overreaction. Their presence suggests a psychological component.

topic: Useful Tables: Knee Ligament Injury Classification (Schenk Stages)
text: Schenk's classification of knee dislocations stages the injury based on ligamentous involvement: KD1 (ACL or PCL), KD2 (ACL & PCL), KD3 (major collateral involvement), KD4 (all major ligaments), KD5 (fracture-dislocation). This classification guides treatment and prognosis.

topic: Useful Tables: Radial Head and Coronoid Process Fractures
text: Mason classifies radial head fractures (Type 1-4) based on displacement and elbow dislocation. Coronoid process fractures are classified by Morrey (height) and O'Driscoll (location/subtype). These classifications are crucial for assessing elbow stability and guiding surgical repair, especially in conjunction with ligamentous injuries.

Hawkins classification of talar neck fractures correlates with AVN risk: Type 1 (undisplaced) has 10% AVN, Type 2 (STJ subluxation) 50%, Type 3 (STJ & ankle subluxation) 90%, and Type 4 (STJ, TTJ & TNJ subluxation) 100%. This impacts treatment and prognosis.

The Southwick angle quantifies SUFE severity based on the difference in lateral epiphyseal angle between hips. Mild (<30°), Moderate (30-50°), and Severe (>50°) classifications guide management, with higher degrees of slip associated with poorer outcomes and increased AVN risk.

Bone tumors are classified by Enneking (grade, compartment, metastasis) and by subtype (Osteosarcoma, Chondrosarcoma, etc.). Osteosarcoma subtypes include intramedullary, parosteal, periosteal, telangiectatic, and post-radiotherapy. Chondrosarcoma subtypes are intramedullary, de-differentiated, clear cell, mesenchymal, and post-radiotherapy. Prognosis correlates with grade and subtype.

Poor prognostic factors for osteosarcoma include high LDH/alkaline phosphatase, absence of anti-shock protein 90, pelvic location, pathologic fracture, poor tumor necrosis post-chemo, vascular invasion, recurrence, and metastases. Early detection and aggressive treatment are key.

topic: Useful Tables: Types of Joint Lubrication
text: Joint lubrication mechanisms include Boundary, Squeeze Film, Elastohydrodynamic, Hydrodynamic, Weeping, and Boosted lubrication. These work together during the gait cycle to reduce friction and wear between articular surfaces. Boundary lubrication is crucial for prosthetic joints.

topic: Useful Tables: Conditions Affecting Physis and Epiphysis
text: Various conditions affect the physis and epiphysis: Epiphyseal involvement includes MED, SED, and Trevor's disease. Proliferative zone issues relate to Achondroplasia and Gigantism. Hypertrophic zone can be affected by SUFE and trauma. Provisional calcification zone by rickets and osteomyelitis.

Key statistical terms include Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV, Accuracy, Reliability, Odds Ratio, Validity, Prevalence, Incidence, P-value, Type 1 and Type 2 errors, and Power. Understanding these is essential for interpreting research findings and making evidence-based decisions.

Common statistical tests include the Student T-test and ANOVA for parametric data, and Chi-Squared, Mann-Whitney U, and Kruskal-Wallis for non-parametric data. These tests help determine the significance of observed differences between groups.

topic: Useful Tables: Trauma Severity Scores (AIS & ISS)
text: The AIS grades injury severity (1-6), used to calculate the ISS. ISS >25 signifies severe injury, and ISS >40 indicates a life-threatening condition. NISS allows multiple injuries from the same body region, offering a more refined assessment of trauma severity.

topic: Useful Tables: Muscle Layers of the Foot
text: The intrinsic muscles of the foot are organized into four plantar layers and one dorsal layer, responsible for fine motor control and supporting the arches. Understanding these layers is important for diagnosing and treating foot deformities and injuries.

topic: Useful Tables: Surgical Approaches in the Foot and Ankle
text: Surgical approaches to the foot and ankle are tailored to the specific pathology, involving careful dissection through layers of muscles and nerves. Anteromedial and anterolateral approaches are common for ankle fractures, while posterolateral and posteromedial approaches are used for subtalar and posterior ankle pathology.

topic: Useful Tables: Angles in the Foot and Ankle
text: Various angles are measured on foot and ankle radiographs to assess alignment and diagnose deformities. Kite's angle, calcaneal pitch, Meary's angle, Bohler's angle, and the Crucial angle of Gissane are critical for evaluating conditions like flatfoot, cavus foot, and calcaneal fractures. Hallux valgus is assessed by HVA and IMA.

topic: Useful Tables: Types of Pelvic Osteotomy
text: Pelvic osteotomies like Salter, Ganz, Pemberton, Dega, Chiari, and Shelf procedures are used to correct hip dysplasia by improving acetabular coverage or reconstructing the pelvis. The choice depends on the patient's age, degree of dysplasia, and the specific goals of surgery.

topic: Useful Tables: Stabilizers of the Elbow
text: Elbow stability is provided by static stabilizers (collaterals, coronoid process) and dynamic stabilizers (muscles). The MCL and LCL are primary restraints against valgus and varus forces, respectively. The radial head and coronoid process are critical for resisting posterolateral rotatory instability.

topic: Useful Tables: MRC Muscle Power Grades
text: The MRC scale grades muscle strength from 0 (no contraction) to 5 (normal power against full resistance). This standardized assessment is essential for evaluating neurological deficits and monitoring recovery in patients with neuromuscular conditions or nerve injuries.

Orthopaedic screw sets are crucial for fracture fixation, categorized into small and large fragment sets. Each set includes cortical, cancellous, and locking screws with specific drill bit and tap sizes, allowing for tailored fixation based on bone quality and fracture pattern.

Various shoulder views are used to diagnose specific pathologies: True AP for general screening, Axillary views for dislocations and humeral head assessment, Stryker notch for Hill-Sachs lesions, and Zanca view for ACJ pathology. Understanding these views is vital for accurate diagnosis.

topic: Useful Tables: Positions for Joint Arthrodesis
text: Optimal positions for joint fusion vary to maximize function. For the hip, it's 30° flexion, 5° adduction, 10° ER. For the shoulder, 30° flexion, 30° abduction, 30° IR is critical for grip. Elbow arthrodesis aims for a functional arc of flexion.

topic: Useful Tables: Ligamentous Stability of the Shoulder
text: Shoulder stability is maintained by the glenohumeral ligaments (SGHL, MGHL, IGHL) which resist translation in different positions. The rotator cuff also plays a crucial role in dynamic stability. Assessing these structures is key in evaluating shoulder instability.

Orthopaedic medications include analgesics (Paracetamol, NSAIDs, Opioids), anti-inflammatories (Steroids), anticoagulants (Warfarin, Heparin, LMWH), antiplatelets (Aspirin), bone metabolism modulators (Bisphosphonates, Strontium), DMARDs (Methotrexate, Etanercept, Infliximab), and local anesthetics. Understanding their mechanisms and indications is vital.

Intoeing in children can stem from Metatarsus Adductus, Internal Tibial Torsion, Femoral Anteversion, Club Foot, or Cerebral Palsy. Assessing gait, limb alignment, and foot posture helps differentiate these causes, with most resolving spontaneously but some requiring intervention.

Torticollis, or wry neck, can be muscular (SCM contracture), acute idiopathic, congenital (occipitocervical anomalies), neurogenic, ocular, or due to atlanto-axial rotatory instability. Muscular torticollis is the most common orthopaedic cause, often linked to intrauterine factors.

topic: Causes of Paediatric Genu Valgum and Genu Varum
text: Paediatric genu varum can be caused by Blount's disease, rickets, achondroplasia, and multiple hereditary osteochondromatosis. Genu valgum may be physiologic or pathological, associated with MED, cozen's fracture, rickets, or skeletal dysplasias. Identifying the underlying cause guides treatment.

topic: Perthes Disease: Catterall's Head at Risk Signs
text: Catterall's 'Head at Risk' signs in Perthes disease predict a poorer outcome and include lateral subluxation, a horizontal physis, Gage's sign, calcification lateral to the epiphysis, and metaphyseal cysts. These signs indicate potential head collapse and deformation, necessitating intervention.

Normal C-spine measurements are crucial for assessing stability. ADI <5mm (child), PADI/SAC <14mm, Powers ratio <1, and Torg ratio <0.8 are important. Deviations can indicate instability, stenosis, or ligamentous injury, guiding treatment decisions.

topic: Incidence of Concurrent Spinal Trauma in C-Spine Fractures
text: Concurrent spinal trauma is common in cervical spine fractures, with higher risks at higher levels (C1: 50%, C2: 30%, C3: 20%). This underscores the need for a complete spinal assessment in patients with cervical spine injuries to identify associated lesions.

Orthopaedic implants utilize metals like Stainless Steel 316L, Titanium alloys (Ti-6Al-4V), and Cobalt-Chrome alloys. Each metal has a specific composition and properties influencing its strength, corrosion resistance, and biocompatibility, guiding implant selection for different applications.

Nerve fibers are classified by type (Aα, Aβ, Aδ, B, C) based on myelination, diameter, and conduction velocity. Aα fibers are large motor neurons, Aβ are sensory, Aδ transmit pain/temp, B are pre-ganglionic autonomic, and C are post-ganglionic autonomic. This classification helps understand nerve function and injury patterns.

topic: Modic Changes in Degenerative Disc Disease
text: Modic changes on MRI indicate degenerative disc disease. Modic 1 (dark T1, bright T2) suggests active inflammation and pain. Modic 2 (bright T1, bright T2) indicates fatty infiltration and chronic pain. Modic 3 (dark T1, dark T2) represents subchondral sclerosis. These changes help correlate imaging findings with clinical symptoms.

The cell cycle comprises Interphase (G1, S, G2) and Mitosis (M). G1 is for growth, S for DNA synthesis, G2 for further growth and preparation for division. M phase involves nuclear and cellular division. G0 represents cells that have exited the cycle, like neurons.

The six dorsal wrist compartments contain specific tendons and nerves crucial for wrist and finger function. Understanding their anatomy is vital for diagnosing and treating conditions like De Quervain's tenosynovitis (Compartment 1) and extensor tendon issues in other compartments.

The greater sciatic foramen transmits the superior gluteal nerve/artery above the piriformis, and the inferior gluteal nerve/artery, pudendal nerve/artery, sciatic nerve, nerve to obturator internus, and posterior femoral cutaneous nerve below it. The lesser sciatic foramen transmits the inferior gluteal nerve/artery and pudendal nerve/artery.

Facet orientation varies along the spine, influencing movement. Cervical facets are coronal (0°) and sagittal (45°). Thoracic facets are at 20° coronal and 55° sagittal. Lumbar facets are at 50° coronal and 90° sagittal, allowing significant flexion/extension but limiting rotation.

Pedicle size varies by spinal level, with T4 having the smallest pedicles in the spine and T1 the largest in the thoracic region. Lumbar pedicles are shorter and wider than thoracic pedicles, reflecting the biomechanical loads they support.

Vertebrae show regional variations: cervical vertebrae have foramina transversarium and bifid spinous processes. Thoracic vertebrae possess costal facets. Lumbar vertebrae have mamillary processes, are taller anteriorly (contributing to lordosis), and have shorter, wider pedicles with flatter facet orientations.

Wiberg's classification of patellar facets describes Types 1 (equal facets, central ridge), 2 (smaller medial facet, medialized ridge), and 3 (tiny, medial facet, absent ridge). This classification helps assess patellofemoral alignment and predict risk of instability or pain.

Prosthetic knees offer various articulations: Polycentric (4-bar linkage) for variable COR, hydraulic/pneumatic for fluid gait, constant/variable friction for basic damping, stance control for stability, and manual locking for maximum safety. Each type aims to optimize function for different user needs.

topic: Factors Negatively Influencing Amputation Stump Healing
text: Poor stump healing can result from low albumin, low lymphocyte count, low transferrin, low ABPI, poor transcutaneous oxygen saturation, and anemia. These factors indicate compromised systemic health and peripheral circulation, impairing wound healing.

Ideal amputation levels balance limb length for prosthetic function with minimizing complications. For the forearm and humerus, the middle third is often preferred. Transtibial amputations aim for about 15 cm below the tibial tuberosity, and transfemoral amputations target the middle third of the femur.

A prosthesis comprises a socket (interface), suspension system (attachment), struts (length restoration), articulations (joint function), and a terminal device (hand or foot). The terminal device can be passive or active, controlled by cables or myoelectric signals.

Hypersensitivity reactions are classified into four types based on immune mechanisms: Type 1 (IgE mediated, immediate), Type 2 (antibody-mediated cytotoxicity), Type 3 (immune complex deposition), and Type 4 (cell-mediated, delayed). Understanding these helps in diagnosing and managing adverse reactions to drugs or tissues.

The complement system is a cascade of proteins that enhances the immune response by promoting opsonization, inflammation, and cell lysis. It plays a crucial role in both innate and adaptive immunity, aiding in pathogen clearance and modulating inflammatory responses.

Medical imaging involves varying radiation doses: CT scans deliver higher doses (neck ~0.6 mSv, abdomen/pelvis ~10 mSv) compared to X-rays (limb ~0.001 mSv, spine ~1.5 mSv). Bone scans (99mTc) are around 3 mSv, while PET scans are significantly higher (~14 mSv).

Tendons and ligaments are primarily composed of Type I collagen and proteoglycans. Ligaments have higher elastin content for recoil and are weaker, with layered fibers. Tendons are stronger, have less elastin, longitudinal fibers, and receive vascular supply via paratenon or vinculae, enabling them to transmit muscle forces efficiently.

topic: Bone Cement Composition and Setting Phases
text: Bone cement typically consists of a liquid monomer (MMA) and a powder polymer (PMMA), with accelerators and initiators. It undergoes distinct phases: Mixing, Waiting (dough), Working, and Hardening, with temperature influencing setting time. Proper technique is crucial to minimize porosity and maximize strength.

Patellar height (alta/baja) is assessed using Insall-Salvetti and Blackburn-Peel ratios. Patellar tilt (>7° on CT) and TTTG distance (>20mm on CT) indicate lateralization. These measurements help diagnose patellofemoral instability and guide treatment.

Key orthopaedic formulas include the Law of Wear (V=SL/H), Bending Rigidity (BR = SMI x Young's Modulus), and Torsional Rigidity (TR = PMI x Young's Modulus). These principles are fundamental to understanding biomechanics and implant design.

topic: Newton's Law of Viscosity and Synovial Fluid
text: Synovial fluid is a non-Newtonian fluid, exhibiting pseudoplasticity and thixotropy, meaning its viscosity changes with shear rate and time under load. This property is essential for joint lubrication, allowing fluid to resist load during gait and providing a low-friction interface.

Orthopaedic implants are susceptible to various corrosion types: Uniform (overall surface attack), Galvanic (dissimilar metals), Crevice (in gaps), Pitting (localized), Fretting (wear + corrosion), Intergranular (at grain boundaries), Leaching (intra-granular), Inclusion (retained fragments), and Stress corrosion (cyclic loading). Understanding these is vital for implant longevity.

Bone healing occurs via primary (contact) or secondary intention. Secondary healing involves inflammation, callus formation (soft and hard), and remodeling. 'Cutting cones' tunnel across the fracture gap, followed by revascularization and osteoblast activity, leading to eventual corticalization and medullary canal reconstruction over months to years.

topic: Nerve Injury Classifications: Seddon and Sunderland
text: Seddon classifies nerve injuries as neuropraxia (demyelination), axonotmesis (axonal damage), and neurotmesis (complete disruption). Sunderland's grading (1-5) provides a more detailed description of the extent of nerve fiber damage, crucial for predicting recovery and guiding surgical intervention.

Denis's classification divides sacral fractures into three zones based on proximity to the sacral foramina. Zone 1 (lateral) has a low risk of neurologic injury. Zone 2 (through foramina) has moderate risk. Zone 3 (medial) has the highest risk of neurologic injury and instability, especially with vertical fractures.

Schatzker classification categorizes tibial plateau fractures by pattern and associated metaphyseal comminution: Type 1 (split), Type 2 (split-depression), Type 3 (depression), Type 4 (medial plateau), Type 5 (both plateaus, continuity), and Type 6 (both plateaus, discontinuity). This guides surgical management for stability and alignment.

topic: Orthopaedic Classifications: ASIA Scale of Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
text: The ASIA Impairment Scale (A-E) grades SCI severity based on preserved motor and sensory function below the neurological level. This scale is essential for assessing injury extent, predicting prognosis, and guiding rehabilitation strategies.
